SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: INTRODUCTION

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: The last few years have seen a large and generally unsystematic mass of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: translations from the Russian flung at the heads and hearts of English

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: readers. The ready acceptance of Chekhov has been one of the few

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: successful features of this irresponsible output. He has been welcomed

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: by British critics with something like affection. Bernard Shaw has

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: several times remarked: “Every time I see a play by Chekhov, I want to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: chuck all my own stuff into the fire.” Others, having no such valuable

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: property to sacrifice on the altar of Chekhov, have not hesitated

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: to place him side by side with Ibsen, and the other established

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: institutions of the new theatre. For these reasons it is pleasant to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: be able to chronicle the fact that, by way of contrast with the casual

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: treatment normally handed out to Russian authors, the publishers are

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: issuing the complete dramatic works of this author. In 1912 they brought

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: out a volume containing four Chekhov plays, translated by Marian Fell.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: All the dramatic works not included in her volume are to be found in the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: present one. With the exception of Chekhov’s masterpiece, “The Cherry

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Orchard” (translated by the late Mr. George Calderon in 1912), none of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: these plays have been previously published in book form in England or

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: America.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: It is not the business of a translator to attempt to outdo all others in

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: singing the praises of his raw material. This is a dangerous process and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: may well lead, as it led Mr. Calderon, to drawing the reader’s

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: attention to points of beauty not to be found in the original. A few

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: bibliographical details are equally necessary, and permissible, and the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: elementary principles of Chekhov criticism will also be found useful.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: The very existence of “The High Road” (1884); probably the earliest

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: of its author’s plays, will be unsuspected by English readers. During

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Chekhov’s lifetime it a sort of family legend, after his death it became

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: a family mystery. A copy was finally discovered only last year in the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Censor’s office, yielded up, and published. It had been sent in 1885

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: under the nom-de-plume “A. Chekhonte,” and it had failed to pass. The

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Censor, of the time being had scrawled his opinion on the manuscript,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: “a depressing and dirty piece,--cannot be licensed.” The name of the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: gentleman who held this view--Kaiser von Kugelgen--gives another reason

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: for the educated Russian’s low opinion of German-sounding institutions.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Baron von Tuzenbach, the satisfactory person in “The Three Sisters,”

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: it will be noted, finds it as well, while he is trying to secure the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: favours of Irina, to declare that his German ancestry is fairly remote.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: This is by way of parenthesis. “The High Road,” found after thirty

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: years, is a most interesting document to the lover of Chekhov. Every

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: play he wrote in later years was either a one-act farce or a four-act

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: drama. [Note: “The Swan Song” may occur as an exception. This, however,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: is more of a Shakespeare recitation than anything else, and so neither

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: here nor there.]

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: In “The High Road” we see, in an embryonic form, the whole later method

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: of the plays--the deliberate contrast between two strong characters

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: person in a fairly large group by way of an introduction to the main

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: theme, the concealment of the catastrophe, germ-wise, in the actual

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: character of the characters, and the of a distinctive group-atmosphere.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: It need scarcely be stated that “The High Road” is not a “dirty” piece

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: according to Russian or to German standards; Chekhov was incapable of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: writing a dirty play or story. For the rest, this piece differs from the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: others in its presentation, not of Chekhov’s favourite middle-classes,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: but of the moujik, nourishing, in a particularly stuffy atmosphere, an

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: intense mysticism and an equally intense thirst for vodka.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: “The Proposal” (1889) and “The Bear” (1890) may be taken as good

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: examples of the sort of humour admired by the average Russian. The

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: latter play, in another translation, was put on as a curtain-raiser to a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: cinematograph entertainment at a London theatre in 1914; and had quite a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: pleasant reception from a thoroughly Philistine audience. The humour is

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: very nearly of the variety most popular over here, the psychology is a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: shade subtler. The Russian novelist or dramatist takes to psychology as

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: some of his fellow-countrymen take to drink; in doing this he achieves

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: fame by showing us what we already know, and at the same time he kills

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: his own creative power. Chekhov just escaped the tragedy of suicide by

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: introspection, and was only enabled to do this by the possession of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: a sense of humour. That is why we should not regard “The Bear,” “The

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Wedding,” or “The Anniversary” as the work of a merely humorous young

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: man, but as the saving graces which made perfect “The Cherry Orchard.”

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: “The Three Sisters” (1901) is said to act better than any other of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Chekhov’s plays, and should surprise an English audience exceedingly. It

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: and “The Cherry Orchard” are the tragedies of doing nothing. The three

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: sisters have only one desire in the world, to go to Moscow and live

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: there. There is no reason on earth, economic, sentimental, or other, why

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: they should not pack their bags and take the next train to Moscow. But

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: they will not do it. They cannot do it. And we know perfectly well that

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: if they were transplanted thither miraculously, they would be extremely

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: unhappy as soon as ever the excitement of the miracle had worn off. In

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the other play Mme. Ranevsky can be saved from ruin if she will only

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: consent to a perfectly simple step--the sale of an estate. She cannot do

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: this, is ruined, and thrown out into the unsympathetic world. Chekhov is

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the dramatist, not of action, but of inaction. The tragedy of inaction

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: is as overwhelming, when we understand it, as the tragedy of an Othello,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: or a Lear, crushed by the wickedness of others. The former is being

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: enacted daily, but we do not stage it, we do not know how. But who

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: shall deny that the base of almost all human unhappiness is just this

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: inaction, manifesting itself in slovenliness of thought and execution,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: education, and ideal?

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: The Russian, painfully conscious of his own weakness, has accepted this

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: point of view, and regards “The Cherry Orchard” as its master-study in

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: dramatic form. They speak of the palpitating hush which fell upon the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: audience of the Moscow Art Theatre after the first fall of the curtain

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: at the first performance--a hush so intense as to make Chekhov’s friends

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: undergo the initial emotions of assisting at a vast theatrical failure.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: But the silence ryes almost a sob, to be followed, when overcome, by an

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: epic applause. And, a few months later, Chekhov died.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: This volume and that of Marian Fell--with which it is uniform--contain

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: all the dramatic works of Chekhov. It considered not worth while to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: translate a few fragments published posthumously, or a monologue “On the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Evils of Tobacco”--a half humorous lecture by “the husband of his wife;”

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: which begins “Ladies, and in some respects, gentlemen,” as this is

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: hardly dramatic work. There is also a very short skit on the efficiency

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: of provincial fire brigades, which was obviously not intended for the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: stage and has therefore been omitted.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Lastly, the scheme of transliteration employed has been that, generally

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: speaking, recommended by the Liverpool School of Russian Studies. This

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: is distinctly the best of those in the field, but as it would compel

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: one, e.g., to write a popular female name, “Marya,” I have not treated

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: it absolute respect. For the sake of uniformity with Fell’s volume, the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: author’s name is spelt Tchekoff on the title-page and cover.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: J. W.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: RUSSIAN WEIGHTS AND MEASURES

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: AND MONEY EMPLOYED IN THE PLAYS, WITH ENGLISH EQUIVALENTS

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: 1 verst = 3600 feet = 2/3 mile (almost)

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: 1 arshin = 28 inches

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: 1 dessiatin = 2.7 acres

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: 1 copeck = 1/4 d

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: 1 rouble = 100 copecks = 2s. 1d.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: ON THE HIGH ROAD

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: A DRAMATIC STUDY

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: CHARACTERS

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: TIHON EVSTIGNEYEV, the proprietor of a inn on the main road

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: SEMYON SERGEYEVITCH BORTSOV, a ruined landowner

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: MARIA EGOROVNA, his wife

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: SAVVA, an aged pilgrim

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: NAZAROVNA and EFIMOVNA, women pilgrims

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: FEDYA, a labourer

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: EGOR MERIK, a tramp

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: KUSMA, a driver

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: POSTMAN

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: BORTSOV’S WIFE’S COACHMAN

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: PILGRIMS, CATTLE-DEALERS, ETC.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: The action takes place in one of the provinces of Southern Russia

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: shelves with bottles. At the back is a door leading out of the house.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Over it, on the outside, hangs a dirty red lantern. The floor and the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: forms, which stand against the wall, are closely occupied by pilgrims

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: and passers-by. Many of them, for lack of space, are sleeping as they

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: sit. It is late at night. As the curtain rises thunder is heard, and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: lightning is seen through the door.]

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: of the forms, and is quietly playing on a concertina. Next to him

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: is BORTSOV, wearing a shabby summer overcoat. SAVVA, NAZAROVNA, and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: EFIMOVNA are stretched out on the floor by the benches.]

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: [To NAZAROVNA] Give the old man a nudge dear! Can’t get any

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: answer out of him.

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: [Lifting the corner of a cloth covering of SAVVA’S face] Are

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: you alive or are you dead, you holy man?

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Why should I be dead? I’m alive, mother! [Raises himself on his

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: elbow] Cover up my feet, there’s a saint! That’s it. A bit more on the

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: right one. That’s it, mother. God be good to us.

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: [Wrapping up SAVVA’S feet] Sleep, little father.

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: What sleep can I have? If only I had the patience to endure this

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: pain, mother; sleep’s quite another matter. A sinner doesn’t deserve to

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: be given rest. What’s that noise, pilgrim-woman?

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: God is sending a storm. The wind is wailing, and the rain is

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: pouring down, pouring down. All down the roof and into the windows like

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: dried peas. Do you hear? The windows of heaven are opened... [Thunder]

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: Holy, holy, holy...

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: And it roars and thunders, and rages, sad there’s no end to

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: it! Hoooo... it’s like the noise of a forest.... Hoooo.... The wind is

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: wailing like a dog.... [Shrinking back] It’s cold! My clothes are wet,

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: it’s all coming in through the open door... you might put me through a

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: wringer.... [Plays softly] My concertina’s damp, and so there’s no music

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: for you, my Orthodox brethren, or else I’d give you such a concert, my

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: word!--Something marvellous! You can have a quadrille, or a polka, if

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: you like, or some Russian dance for two.... I can do them all. In the

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: town, where I was an attendant at the Grand Hotel, I couldn’t make any

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: money, but I did wonders on my concertina. And, I can play the guitar.

SPEAKER: A VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: A silly speech from a silly fool.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: I can hear another of them. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: [To SAVVA] If you’d only lie where it was warm now, old man,

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: and warm your feet. [Pause.] Old man! Man of God! [Shakes SAVVA] Are you

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: going to die?

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: You ought to drink a little vodka, grandfather. Drink, and it’ll

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: burn, burn in your stomach, and warm up your heart. Drink, do!

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: Don’t swank, young man! Perhaps the old man is giving back

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: his soul to God, or repenting for his sins, and you talk like that, and

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: play your concertina.... Put it down! You’ve no shame!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: And what are you sticking to him for? He can’t do anything and

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: you... with your old women’s talk... He can’t say a word in reply, and

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: you’re glad, and happy because he’s listening to your nonsense.... You

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: go on sleeping, grandfather; never mind her! Let her talk, don’t you

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: take any notice of her. A woman’s tongue is the devil’s broom--it will

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: sweep the good man and the clever man both out of the house. Don’t

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: you mind.... [Waves his hands] But it’s thin you are, brother of mine!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Terrible! Like a dead skeleton! No life in you! Are you really dying?

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Why should I die? Save me, O Lord, from dying in vain.... I’ll

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: suffer a little, and then get up with God’s help.... The Mother of God

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: won’t let me die in a strange land.... I’ll die at home.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Are you from far off?

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: From Vologda. The town itself.... I live there.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: And where is this Vologda?

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: The other side of Moscow....

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Well, well, well.... You have come a long way, old man! On foot?

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: On foot, young man. I’ve been to Tihon of the Don, and I’m

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: going to the Holy Hills. [Note: On the Donetz, south-east of Kharkov; a

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: monastery containing a miraculous ikon.]... From there, if God wills it,

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: to Odessa.... They say you can get to Jerusalem cheap from there, for

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: twenty-ones roubles, they say....

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: And have you been to Moscow?

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Rather! Five times....

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Is it a good town? [Smokes] Well-standing?

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Sews. There are many holy places there, young man.... Where there are

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: many holy places it’s always a good town....

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Goes up to the counter, to TIHON] Once more, please! For the

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: sake of Christ, give it to me!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: The chief thing about a town is that it should be clean. If it’s

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: dusty, it must be watered; if it’s dirty, it must be cleaned. There

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: ought to be big houses... a theatre... police... cabs, which... I’ve

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: lived in a town myself, I understand.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Just a little glass. I’ll pay you for it later.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: That’s enough now.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: I ask you! Do be kind to me!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Get away!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: You don’t understand me.... Understand me, you fool, if there’s

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: a drop of brain in your peasant’s wooden head, that it isn’t I who am

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: asking you, but my inside, using the words you understand, that’s what’s

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: asking! My illness is what’s asking! Understand!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: We don’t understand anything.... Get back!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Because if I don’t have a drink at once, just you understand

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: this, if I don’t satisfy my needs, I may commit some crime. God only

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: knows what I might do! In the time you’ve kept this place, you rascal,

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: haven’t you seen a lot of drunkards, and haven’t you yet got to

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: understand what they’re like? They’re diseased! You can do anything you

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: like to them, but you must give them vodka! Well, now, I implore you!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Please! I humbly ask you! God only knows how humbly!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: You can have the vodka if you pay for it.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Where am I to get the money? I’ve drunk it all! Down to the

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: ground! What can I give you? I’ve only got this coat, but I can’t give

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: you that. I’ve nothing on underneath.... Would you like my cap? [Takes

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: it off and gives it to TIHON]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Looks it over] Hm.... There are all sorts of caps.... It might

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: be a sieve from the holes in it....

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: [Laughs] A gentleman’s cap! You’ve got to take it off in front of

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: the mam’selles. How do you do, good-bye! How are you?

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Returns the cap to BORTSOV] I wouldn’t give anything for it.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: It’s muck.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: If you don’t like it, then let me owe you for the drink! I’ll

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: bring in your five copecks on my way back from town. You can take it and

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: choke yourself with it then! Choke yourself! I hope it sticks in your

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: throat! [Coughs] I hate you!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Banging the bar-counter with his fist] Why do you keep on like

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: that? What a man! What are you here for, you swindler?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: I want a drink! It’s not I, it’s my disease! Understand that!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Don’t you make me lose my temper, or you’ll soon find yourself

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: outside!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: What am I to do? [Retires from the bar-counter] What am I to

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: do? [Is thoughtful.]

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: It’s the devil tormenting you. Don’t you mind him, sir. The

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: damned one keeps whispering, “Drink! Drink!” And you answer him, “I

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: shan’t drink! I shan’t drink!” He’ll go then.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: It’s drumming in his head.... His stomach’s leading him on!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: use of standing like a scarecrow in the middle of the inn! This isn’t an

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: orchard!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Angrily] Shut up! Nobody spoke to you, you donkey.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Go on, go on! We’ve seen the like of you before! There’s a lot

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: like you tramping the high road! As to being a donkey, you wait till

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: I’ve given you a clout on the ear and you’ll howl worse than the wind.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Donkey yourself! Fool! [Pause] Scum!

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: The old man may be saying a prayer, or giving up his soul

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: to God, and here are these unclean ones wrangling with one another and

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: saying all sorts of... Have shame on yourselves!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Here, you cabbage-stalk, you keep quiet, even if you are in a

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: public-house. Just you behave like everybody else.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: What am I to do? What will become of me? How can I make him

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: understand? What else can I say to him? [To TIHON] The blood’s boiling

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: in my chest! Uncle Tihon! [Weeps] Uncle Tihon!

SPEAKER: SAWA
TEXT: [Groans] I’ve got shooting-pains in my leg, like bullets of

SPEAKER: SAWA
TEXT: fire.... Little mother, pilgrim.

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: What is it, little father?

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Who’s that crying?

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: The gentleman.

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Ask him to shed a tear for me, that I might die in Vologda.

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Tearful prayers are heard.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: I’m not praying, grandfather! These aren’t tears! Just juice!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: My soul is crushed; and the juice is running. [Sits by SAVVA] Juice!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: But you wouldn’t understand! You, with your darkened brain, wouldn’t

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: understand. You people are all in the dark!

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Where will you find those who live in the light?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: They do exist, grandfather.... They would understand!

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Yes, yes, dear friend.... The saints lived in the light.... They

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: understood all our griefs.... You needn’t even tell them.... and they’ll

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: understand.... Just by looking at your eyes.... And then you’ll have

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: such peace, as if you were never in grief at all--it will all go!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: And have you ever seen any saints?

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: It has happened, young man.... There are many of all sorts on

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: this earth. Sinners, and servants of God.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: I don’t understand all this.... [Gets up quickly] What’s the

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: use of talking when you don’t understand, and what sort of a brain have

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: I now? I’ve only an instinct, a thirst! [Goes quickly to the counter]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Tihon, take my coat! Understand? [Tries to take it off] My coat...

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: And what is there under your coat? [Looks under it] Your naked

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: body? Don’t take it off, I shan’t have it.... I’m not going to burden my

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: soul with a sin.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Very well, I’ll take the sin on myself! Do you agree?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [In silence takes of his outer cloak and remains in a sleeveless

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: jacket. He carries an axe in his belt] A vagrant may sweat where a bear

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: will freeze. I am hot. [Puts his axe on the floor and takes off his

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: jacket] You get rid of a pailful of sweat while you drag one leg out of

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: the mud. And while you are dragging it out, the other one goes farther

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: in.

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: Yes, that’s true... is the rain stopping, dear?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Glancing at EFIMOVNA] I don’t talk to old women. [A pause.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [To TIHON] I’ll take the sin on myself. Do you hear me or don’t

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: you?

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: I don’t want to hear you, get away!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: It’s as dark as if the sky was painted with pitch. You can’t

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: see your own nose. And the rain beats into your face like a snowstorm!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: It’s a good thing for the likes of us thieves. When the cat’s

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: away the mice will play.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Who says that?

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Look and see... before you forget.

SPEAKER: MERIN
TEXT: We’ll make a note of it.... [Goes up to TIHON] How do you do, you

SPEAKER: MERIN
TEXT: with the large face! Don’t you remember me.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: If I’m to remember every one of you drunkards that walks the high

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: road, I reckon I’d need ten holes in my forehead.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Just look at me.... [A pause.]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Oh, yes; I remember. I knew you by your eyes! [Gives him his

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: hand] Andrey Polikarpov?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: I used to be Andrey Polikarpov, but now I am Egor Merik.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Why’s that?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: I call myself after whatever passport God gives me. I’ve been

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Merik for two months. [Thunder] Rrrr.... Go on thundering, I’m not

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: afraid! [Looks round] Any police here?

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: What are you talking about, making mountains out of

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: mole-hills?... The people here are all right... The police are fast

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: asleep in their feather beds now.... [Loudly] Orthodox brothers, mind

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: your pockets and your clothes, or you’ll have to regret it. The man’s a

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: rascal! He’ll rob you!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: They can look out for their money, but as to their clothes--I

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: shan’t touch them. I’ve nowhere to take them.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Where’s the devil taking you to?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: To Kuban.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: My word!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: To Kuban? Really? [Sitting up] It’s a fine place. You wouldn’t

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: see such a country, brother, if you were to fall asleep and dream for

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: three years. They say the birds there, and the beasts are--my God! The

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: grass grows all the year round, the people are good, and they’ve so much

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: land they don’t know what to do with it! The authorities, they say... a

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: soldier was telling me the other day... give a hundred dessiatins ahead.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: There’s happiness, God strike me!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Happiness.... Happiness goes behind you.... You don’t see it.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: It’s as near as your elbow is, but you can’t bite it. It’s all

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: silly.... [Looking round at the benches and the people] Like a lot of

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: prisoners.... A poor lot.

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: [To MERIK] What great, angry, eyes! There’s an enemy in you,

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: young man.... Don’t you look at us!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Yes, you’re a poor lot here.

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: Turn away! [Nudges SAVVA] Savva, darling, a wicked man is

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: looking at us. He’ll do us harm, dear. [To MERIK] Turn away, I tell you,

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: you snake!

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: He won’t touch us, mother, he won’t touch us.... God won’t let

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: him.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: All right, Orthodox brothers! [Shrugs his shoulders] Be quiet!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: You aren’t asleep, you bandy-legged fools! Why don’t you say something?

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: Take your great eyes away! Take away that devil’s own pride!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Be quiet, you crooked old woman! I didn’t come with the devil’s

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: pride, but with kind words, wishing to honour your bitter lot! You’re

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: huddled together like flies because of the cold--I’d be sorry for you,

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: speak kindly to you, pity your poverty, and here you go grumbling away!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: I live in these parts. I work at the Khamonyevsky brickworks.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Get up.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: [Raising himself] Well?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Get up, right up. I’m going to lie down here.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: What’s that.... It isn’t your place, is it?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Yes, mine. Go and lie on the ground!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: You get out of this, you tramp. I’m not afraid of you.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: You’re very quick with your tongue.... Get up, and don’t talk

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: about it! You’ll be sorry for it, you silly.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [To FEDYA] Don’t contradict him, young man. Never mind.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: What right have you? You stick out your fishy eyes and think

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: I’m afraid! [Picks up his belongings and stretches himself out on the

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: ground] You devil! [Lies down and covers himself all over.]

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Stretching himself out on the bench] I don’t expect you’ve ever

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: seen a devil or you wouldn’t call me one. Devils aren’t like that. [Lies

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: down, putting his axe next to him.] Lie down, little brother axe... let

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: me cover you.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Where did you get the axe from?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Stole it.... Stole it, and now I’ve got to fuss over it like a

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: child with a new toy; I don’t like to throw it away, and I’ve nowhere to

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: put it. Like a beastly wife.... Yes.... [Covering himself over] Devils

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: aren’t like that, brother.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: [Uncovering his head] What are they like?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Like steam, like air.... Just blow into the air. [Blows] They’re

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: like that, you can’t see them.

SPEAKER: A VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: You can see them if you sit under a harrow.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: I’ve tried, but I didn’t see any.... Old women’s tales, and silly

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: old men’s, too.... You won’t see a devil or a ghost or a corpse.... Our

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: eyes weren’t made so that we could see everything.... When I was a boy,

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: I used to walk in the woods at night on purpose to see the demon of the

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: woods.... I’d shout and shout, and there might be some spirit, I’d call

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: for the demon of the woods and not blink my eyes: I’d see all sorts of

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: little things moving about, but no demon. I used to go and walk about

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: the churchyards at night, I wanted to see the ghosts--but the women lie.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: I saw all sorts of animals, but anything awful--not a sign. Our eyes

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: weren’t...

SPEAKER: THE VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: Never mind, it does happen that you

SPEAKER: THE VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: do see.... In our village a man was gutting a wild boar... he was

SPEAKER: THE VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: separating the tripe when... something jumped out at him!

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: [Raising himself] Little children, don’t talk about these unclean

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: things! It’s a sin, dears!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Aaa... greybeard! You skeleton! [Laughs] You needn’t go to the

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: churchyard to see ghosts, when they get up from under the floor to give

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: advice to their relations.... A sin!... Don’t you teach people your

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: silly notions! You’re an ignorant lot of people living in darkness....

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: people. One night he stole a sack of apples from the village priest, and

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: he brings them along and tells us, “Look, children, mind you don’t eat

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: any apples before Easter, it’s a sin.” You’re like that.... You don’t

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: know what a devil is, but you go calling people devils.... Take this

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: crooked old woman, for instance. [Points to EFIMOVNA] She sees an enemy

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: in me, but is her time, for some woman’s nonsense or other, she’s given

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: her soul to the devil five times.

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: Hoo, hoo, hoo.... Gracious heavens! [Covers her face] Little

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: Savva!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: What are you frightening them for? A great pleasure! [The door

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: slams in the wind] Lord Jesus.... The wind, the wind!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Stretching himself] Eh, to show my strength! [The door slams

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: again] If I could only measure myself against the wind! Shall I tear the

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: door down, or suppose I tear up the inn by the roots! [Gets up and lies

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: down again] How dull!

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: You’d better pray, you heathen! Why are you so restless?

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: Don’t speak to him, leave him alone! He’s looking at us again.

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: devil before cockcrow!

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Let him look, pilgrims! You pray, and his eyes won’t do you any

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: harm.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: No, I can’t. It’s too much for my strength! [Goes up to the

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: counter] Listen, Tihon, I ask you for the last time.... Just half a

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: glass!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Shakes his head] The money!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: My God, haven’t I told you! I’ve drunk it all! Where am I to

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: get it? And you won’t go broke even if you do let me have a drop of

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: vodka on tick. A glass of it only costs you two copecks, and it will

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: save me from suffering! I am suffering! Understand! I’m in misery, I’m

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: suffering!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Go and tell that to someone else, not to me.... Go and ask the

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Orthodox, perhaps they’ll give you some for Christ’s sake, if they feel

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: like it, but I’ll only give bread for Christ’s sake.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: You can rob those wretches yourself, I shan’t.... I won’t do

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: it! I won’t! Understand? [Hits the bar-counter with his fist] I won’t.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: idea, all the same, Orthodox ones! Spare five copecks! My inside asks

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: for it. I’m ill!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Oh, you swindler, with your “spare five copecks.” Won’t you have

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: some water?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: How I am degrading myself! I don’t want it! I don’t want

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: anything! I was joking!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: You won’t get it out of him, sir.... He’s a famous skinflint....

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Wait, I’ve got a five-copeck piece somewhere.... We’ll have a glass

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: between us--half each [Searches in his pockets] The devil... it’s lost

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: somewhere.... Thought I heard it tinkling just now in my pocket.... No;

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: no, it isn’t there, brother, it’s your luck! [A pause.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: But if I can’t drink, I’ll commit a crime or I’ll kill

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: myself.... What shall I do, my God! [Looks through the door] Shall I go

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: out, then? Out into this darkness, wherever my feet take me....

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Why don’t you give him a sermon, you pilgrims? And you, Tihon,

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: why don’t you drive him out? He hasn’t paid you for his night’s

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: accommodation. Chuck him out! Eh, the people are cruel nowadays. There’s

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: no gentleness or kindness in them.... A savage people! A man is drowning

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: and they shout to him: “Hurry up and drown, we’ve got no time to look

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: at you; we’ve got to go to work.” As to throwing him a rope--there’s no

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: worry about that.... A rope would cost money.

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Don’t talk, kind man!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Quiet, old wolf! You’re a savage race! Herods! Sellers of your

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: souls! [To TIHON] Come here, take off my boots! Look sharp now!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Eh, he’s let himself go I [Laughs] Awful, isn’t it.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Go on, do as you’re told! Quick now! [Pause] Do you hear me, or

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: don’t you? Am I talking to you or the wall? [Stands up]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Well... give over.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: I want you, you fleecer, to take the boots off me, a poor tramp.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Well, well... don’t get excited. Here have a glass.... Have a

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: drink, now!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: People, what do I want? Do I want him to stand me vodka, or to

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: take off my boots? Didn’t I say it properly? [To TIHON] Didn’t you hear

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: me rightly? I’ll wait a moment, perhaps you’ll hear me then.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: themselves in order to look at TIHON and MERIK. They wait in silence.]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: The devil brought you here! [Comes out from behind the bar] What

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: a gentleman! Come on now. [Takes off MERIK’S boots] You child of Cain...

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: That’s right. Put them side by side.... Like that... you can go

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: now!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Returns to the bar-counter] You’re too fond of being clever. You

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: do it again and I’ll turn you out of the inn! Yes! [To BORTSOV, who is

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: approaching] You, again?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Look here, suppose I give you something made of gold.... I will

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: give it to you.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: What are you shaking for? Talk sense!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: It may be mean and wicked on my part, but what am I to do? I’m

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: doing this wicked thing, not reckoning on what’s to come.... If I was

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: tried for it, they’d let me off. Take it, only on condition that you

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: return it later, when I come back from town. I give it to you in front

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: of these witnesses. You will be my witnesses! [Takes a gold medallion

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: out from the breast of his coat] Here it is.... I ought to take the

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: portrait out, but I’ve nowhere to put it; I’m wet all over.... Well,

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: take the portrait, too! Only mind this... don’t let your fingers touch

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: that face.... Please... I was rude to you, my dear fellow, I was a fool,

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: but forgive me and... don’t touch it with your fingers.... Don’t look at

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: that face with your eyes. [Gives TIHON the medallion.]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Examining it] Stolen property.... All right, then, drink....

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Only don’t you touch it... with your fingers. [Drinks slowly,

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: with feverish pauses.]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Opens the medallion] Hm... a lady!... Where did you get hold of

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: this?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Let’s have a look. [Goes to the bar] Let’s see.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Pushes his hand away] Where are you going to? You look somewhere

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: else!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: [Gets up and comes to TIHON] I want to look too!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: grips TIHON’s hand firmly with both his, looks at the portrait, in the

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: medallion in silence. A pause.]

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: A pretty she-devil. A real lady....

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: A real lady.... Look at her cheeks, her eyes.... Open your hand,

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: I can’t see. Hair coming down to her waist.... It is lifelike! She might

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: be going to say something.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: It’s destruction for a weak man. A woman like that gets a hold on

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: one and... [Waves his hand] you’re done for!

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: There stands an inn upon my way. Shall I drive or walk past it,

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: say? You can pass your own father and not notice him, but you can see an

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: inn in the dark a hundred versts away. Make way, if you believe in God!

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Hullo, there! [Planks a five-copeck piece down on the counter] A glass

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: of real Madeira! Quick!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Oh, you devil!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Don’t wave your arms about, or you’ll hit somebody.

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: God gave us arms to wave about. Poor sugary things, you’re

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: half-melted. You’re frightened of the rain, poor delicate things.

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: You may well get frightened, good man, if you’re caught on

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: your way in a night like this. Now, thank God, it’s all right, there

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: are many villages and houses where you can shelter from the weather, but

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: before that there weren’t any. Oh, Lord, it was bad! You walk a hundred

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: versts, and not only isn’t there a village; or a house, but you don’t

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: even see a dry stick. So you sleep on the ground....

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Have you been long on this earth, old woman?

SPEAKER: EFIMOVNA
TEXT: Over seventy years, little father.

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Over seventy years! You’ll soon come to crow’s years. [Looks at

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: BORTSOV] And what sort of a raisin is this? [Staring at BORTSOV] Sir!

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: room, where he sits on a bench] Semyon Sergeyevitch! Is that you, or

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: isn’t it? Eh? What are you doing in this place? It’s not the sort of

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: place for you, is it?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Be quiet!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [To KUSMA] Who is it?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: A miserable sufferer. [Paces irritably by the counter] Eh? In an

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: inn, my goodness! Tattered! Drunk! I’m upset, brothers... upset....

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Sergeyevitch and Mr. Bortsov.... Have you ever seen such a state? What

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: does he look like? Just... it’s the drink that brought him to this....

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Give me some more! [Drinks] I come from his village, Bortsovka; you may

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: have heard of it, it’s 200 versts from here, in the Ergovsky district.

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: We used to be his father’s serfs.... What a shame!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Was he rich?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Very.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Did he drink it all?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: No, my friend, it was something else.... He used to be great and

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: rich and sober.... [To TIHON] Why you yourself used to see him riding,

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: as he used to, past this inn, on his way to the town. Such bold and

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: noble horses! A carriage on springs, of the best quality! He used to

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: own five troikas, brother.... Five years ago, I remember, he cam here

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: driving two horses from Mikishinsky, and he paid with a five-rouble

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: piece.... I haven’t the time, he says, to wait for the change.... There!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: His brain’s gone, I suppose.

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: His brain’s all right.... It all happened because of his

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: cowardice! From too much fat. First of all, children, because of a

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: woman.... He fell in love with a woman of the town, and it seemed to him

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: that there wasn’t any more beautiful thing in the wide world. A fool may

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: love as much as a wise man. The girl’s people were all right.... But

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: she wasn’t exactly loose, but just... giddy... always changing her mind!

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Always winking at one! Always laughing and laughing.... No sense at all.

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: The gentry like that, they think that’s nice, but we moujiks would soon

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: chuck her out.... Well, he fell in love, and his luck ran out. He began

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: to keep company with her, one thing led to another... they used to go

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: out in a boat all night, and play pianos....

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Don’t tell them, Kusma! Why should you? What has my life got to

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: do with them?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Forgive me, your honour, I’m only telling them a little... what

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: does it matter, anyway.... I’m shaking all over. Pour out some more.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [In a semitone] And did she love him?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: [In a semitone which gradually becomes his ordinary voice] How

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: shouldn’t she? He was a man of means.... Of course you’ll fall in love

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: when the man has a thousand dessiatins and money to burn.... He was a

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: solid, dignified, sober gentleman... always the same, like this... give

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: me your hand [Takes MERIK’S hand] “How do you do and good-bye, do me

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: the favour.” Well, I was going one evening past his garden--and what a

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: garden, brother, versts of it--I was going along quietly, and I look and

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: see the two of them sitting on a seat and kissing each other. [Imitates

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: the sound] He kisses her once, and the snake gives him back two.... He

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: was holding her white, little hand, and she was all fiery and kept on

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: getting closer and closer, too.... “I love you,” she says. And he, like

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: one of the damned, walks about from one place to another and brags,

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: the coward, about his happiness.... Gives one man a rouble, and two to

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: another.... Gives me money for a horse. Let off everybody’s debts....

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Oh, why tell them all about it? These people haven’t any

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: sympathy.... It hurts!

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: It’s nothing, sir! They asked me! Why shouldn’t I tell them?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: But if you are angry I won’t... I won’t.... What do I care for them....

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Don’t shout; tell us quietly....

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: I’ll tell you quietly.... He doesn’t want me to, but it can’t be

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: helped.... But there’s nothing more to tell. They got married, that’s

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: all. There was nothing else. Pour out another drop for Kusma the stony!

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: took place, when the gentlefolk sat down to supper afterwards, she went

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: off in a carriage... [Whispers] To the town, to her lover, a lawyer....

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Eh? What do you think of her now? Just at the very moment! She would be

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: let off lightly if she were killed for it!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Thoughtfully] Well... what happened then?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: He went mad.... As you see, he started with a fly, as they say,

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: and now it’s grown to a bumble-bee. It was a fly then, and now--it’s

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: a bumble-bee.... And he still loves her. Look at him, he loves her! I

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: expect he’s walking now to the town to get a glimpse of her with one

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: eye.... He’ll get a glimpse of her, and go back....

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: The post’s late to-day!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: bells ringing.]

SPEAKER: A VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: One could rob the post in weather like

SPEAKER: A VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: this--easy as spitting.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: I’ve been alive thirty-five years and I haven’t robbed the post

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: once.... [Pause] It’s gone now... too late, too late....

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Do you want to smell the inside of a prison?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: People rob and don’t go to prison. And if I do go! [Suddenly]

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: What else?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Do you mean that unfortunate?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Who else?

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: The second reason, brothers, why he was ruined was because of

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: his brother-in-law, his sister’s husband.... He took it into his head to

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: stand surety at the bank for 30,000 roubles for his brother-in-law. The

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: brother-in-law’s a thief.... The swindler knows which side his bread’s

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: buttered and won’t budge an inch.... So he doesn’t pay up.... So our man

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: had to pay up the whole thirty thousand. [Sighs] The fool is suffering

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: for his folly. His wife’s got children now by the lawyer and the

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: brother-in-law has bought an estate near Poltava, and our man goes

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: round inns like a fool, and complains to the likes of us: “I’ve lost all

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: faith, brothers! I can’t believe in anybody now!” It’s cowardly! Every

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: man has his grief, a snake that sucks at his heart, and does that mean

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: that he must drink? Take our village elder, for example. His wife plays

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: about with the schoolmaster in broad daylight, and spends his money on

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: drink, but the elder walks about smiling to himself. He’s just a little

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: thinner...

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [Sighs] When God gives a man strength....

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: There’s all sorts of strength, that’s true.... Well? How much

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: does it come to? [Pays] Take your pound of flesh! Good-bye, children!

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: Good-night and pleasant dreams! It’s time I hurried off. I’m bringing

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: my lady a midwife from the hospital.... She must be getting wet with

SPEAKER: KUSMA
TEXT: waiting, poor thing.... [Runs out. A pause.]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Oh, you! Unhappy man, come and drink this! [Pours out.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Comes up to the bar hesitatingly and drinks] That means I now

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: owe you for two glasses.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: You don’t owe me anything? Just drink and drown your sorrows!

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Drink mine, too, sir! Oh! [Throws down a five-copeck piece] If

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: you drink, you die; if you don’t drink, you die. It’s good not to drink

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: vodka, but by God you’re easier when you’ve got some! Vodka takes grief

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: away.... It is hot!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Boo! The heat!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Dive it here! [Takes the medallion from TIHON and examines her

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: portrait] Hm. Ran off after the wedding. What a woman!

SPEAKER: A VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: Pour him out another glass, Tihon. Let him

SPEAKER: A VOICE FROM THE CORNER
TEXT: drink mine, too.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Dashes the medallion to the ground] Curse her! [Goes quickly to

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: his place and lies down, face to the wall. General excitement.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Here, what’s that? [Picks up the medallion] How dare you, you

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: beast? What right have you? [Tearfully] Do you want me to kill you? You

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: moujik! You boor!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Don’t be angry, sir.... It isn’t glass, it isn’t broken.... Have

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: another drink and go to sleep. [Pours out] Here I’ve been listening to

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: you all, and when I ought to have locked up long ago. [Goes and looks

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: door leading out.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Drinks] How dare he? The fool! [to MERIK] Do you understand?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: You’re a fool, a donkey!

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: Children! If you please! Stop that talking! What’s the good of

SPEAKER: SAVVA
TEXT: making a noise? Let people go to sleep.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Lie down, lie down... be quiet! [Goes behind the counter and

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: locks the till] It’s time to sleep.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: It’s time! [Lies down] Pleasant dreams, brothers!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Gets up and spreads his short fur and coat the bench] Come on,

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: lie down, sir.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: And where will you sleep.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Oh, anywhere.... The floor will do.... [Spreads a coat on the

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: floor] It’s all one to me [Puts the axe by him] It would be torture for

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: him to sleep on the floor. He’s used to silk and down....

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: [To BORTSOV] Lie down, your honour! You’ve looked at that

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: portrait long enough. [Puts out a candle] Throw it away!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Swaying about] Where can I lie down?

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: In the tramp’s place! Didn’t you hear him giving it up to you?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Going up to the vacant place] I’m a bit... drunk... after all

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: that.... Is this it?... Do I lie down here? Eh?

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Yes, yes, lie down, don’t be afraid. [Stretches himself out on

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: the counter.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Lying down] I’m... drunk.... Everything’s going round....

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: a queer little woman Masha.... Looking at me out of the frame and

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: laughing.... [Laughs] I’m drunk! And should you laugh at a man because

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: he’s drunk? You look out, as Schastlivtsev says, and... love the

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: drunkard.

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: How the wind howls. It’s dreary!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Laughs] What a woman.... Why do you keep on going round? I

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: can’t catch you!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: He’s wandering. Looked too long at the portrait. [Laughs] What

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: a business! Educated people go and invent all sorts of machines and

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: medicines, but there hasn’t yet been a man wise enough to invent a

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: medicine against the female sex.... They try to cure every sort of

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: disease, and it never occurs to them that more people die of women

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: than of disease.... Sly, stingy, cruel, brainless.... The mother-in-law

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: torments the bride and the bride makes things square by swindling the

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: husband... and there’s no end to it....

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: The women have ruffled his hair for him, and so he’s bristly.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: It isn’t only I.... From the beginning of the ages, since the

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: world has been in existence, people have complained.... It’s not for

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: nothing that in the songs and stories, the devil and the woman are put

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: side by side.... Not for nothing! It’s half true, at any rate... [Pause]

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Here’s the gentleman playing the fool, but I had more sense, didn’t I,

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: when I left my father and mother, and became a tramp?

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Because of women?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Just like the gentleman... I walked about like one of the damned,

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: bewitched, blessing my stars... on fire day and night, until at last my

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: eyes were opened... It wasn’t love, but just a fraud....

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: What did you do to her?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Never you mind.... [Pause] Do you think I killed her?... I

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: wouldn’t do it.... If you kill, you are sorry for it.... She can live

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: and be happy! If only I’d never set eyes on you, or if I could only

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: forget you, you viper’s brood! [A knocking at the door.]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Whom have the devils brought.... Who’s there? [Knocking] Who

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: knocks? [Gets up and goes to the door] Who knocks? Go away, we’ve locked

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: up!

SPEAKER: A VOICE
TEXT: Please let me in, Tihon. The carriage-spring’s broken! Be a

SPEAKER: A VOICE
TEXT: father to me and help me! If I only had a little string to tie it round

SPEAKER: A VOICE
TEXT: with, we’d get there somehow or other.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Who are you?

SPEAKER: THE VOICE
TEXT: My lady is going to Varsonofyev from the town.... It’s only

SPEAKER: THE VOICE
TEXT: five versts farther on.... Do be a good man and help!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Go and tell the lady that if she pays ten roubles she can have

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: her string and we’ll mend the spring.

SPEAKER: THE VOICE
TEXT: Have you gone mad, or what? Ten roubles! You mad dog!

SPEAKER: THE VOICE
TEXT: Profiting by our misfortunes!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Just as you like.... You needn’t if you don’t want to.

SPEAKER: THE VOICE
TEXT: Very well, wait a bit. [Pause] She says, all right.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Pleased to hear it!

SPEAKER: COACHMAN
TEXT: Good evening, Orthodox people! Well, give me the string!

SPEAKER: COACHMAN
TEXT: Quick! Who’ll go and help us, children? There’ll be something left over

SPEAKER: COACHMAN
TEXT: for your trouble!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: There won’t be anything left over.... Let them sleep, the two of

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: us can manage.

SPEAKER: COACHMAN
TEXT: Foo, I am tired! It’s cold, and there’s not a dry spot in all

SPEAKER: COACHMAN
TEXT: the mud.... Another thing, dear.... Have you got a little room in here

SPEAKER: COACHMAN
TEXT: for the lady to warm herself in? The carriage is all on one side, she

SPEAKER: COACHMAN
TEXT: can’t stay in it....

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: What does she want a room for? She can warm herself in here, if

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: she’s cold.... We’ll find a place [Clears a space next to BORTSOV] Get

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: up, get up! Just lie on the floor for an hour, and let the lady get

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: warm. [To BORTSOV] Get up, your honour! Sit up! [BORTSOV sits up] Here’s

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: a place for you. [Exit COACHMAN.]

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: Here’s a visitor for you, the devil’s brought her! Now there’ll

SPEAKER: FEDYA
TEXT: be no sleep before daylight.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: I’m sorry I didn’t ask for fifteen.... She’d have given them....

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: must say. [Enter MARIA EGOROVNA, followed by the COACHMAN. TIHON bows.]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Please, your highness! Our room is very humble, full of blackbeetles!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: But don’t disdain it!

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: I can’t see anything.... Which way do I go?

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: This way, your highness! [Leads her to the place next to BORTSOV]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: This way, please. [Blows on the place] I haven’t any separate rooms,

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: excuse me, but don’t you be afraid, madam, the people here are good and

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: quiet....

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: [Sits next to BORTSOV] How awfully stuffy! Open the

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: door, at any rate!

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Yes, madam. [Runs and opens the door wide.]

SPEAKER: MARIA
TEXT: We’re freezing, and you open the door! [Gets up and slams it] Who

SPEAKER: MARIA
TEXT: are you to be giving orders? [Lies down]

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Excuse me, your highness, but we’ve a little fool here... a bit

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: cracked.... But don’t you be frightened, he won’t do you any harm....

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Only you must excuse me, madam, I can’t do this for ten roubles.... Make

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: it fifteen.

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: Very well, only be quick.

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: This minute... this very instant. [Drags some string out from

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: under the counter] This minute. [A pause.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: [Looking at MARIA EGOROVNA] Marie... Masha...

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: [Looks at BORTSOV] What’s this?

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Marie... is it you? Where do you come from? [MARIA EGOROVNA

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: recognizes BORTSOV, screams and runs off into the centre of the floor.

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: BORTSOV follows] Marie, it is I... I [Laughs loudly] My wife! Marie!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Where am I? People, a light!

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: Get away from me! You lie, it isn’t you! It can’t be!

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Her voice, her movements.... Marie, it is I! I’ll stop in

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: a moment.... I was drunk.... My head’s going round.... My God! Stop,

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: stop.... I can’t understand anything. [Yells] My wife! [Falls at her

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: feet and sobs. A group collects around the husband and wife.]

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: Stand back! [To the COACHMAN] Denis, let’s go! I can’t

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: stop here any longer!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Jumps up and looks her steadily in the face] The portrait!

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: Get away, fellow! [Tries to tear her hand away from him]

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: Denis, why do you stand there staring? [DENIS and TIHON run up to her

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: and get hold of MERIK’S arms] This thieves’ kitchen! Let go my hand! I’m

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: not afraid!... Get away from me!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Note: Throughout this speech, in the original, Merik uses the

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: familiar second person singular.] Wait a bit, and I’ll let go.... Just

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: let me say one word to you.... One word, so that you may understand....

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Just wait.... [Turns to TIHON and DENIS] Get away, you rogues, let go! I

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: shan’t let you go till I’ve had my say! Stop... one moment. [Strikes

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: his forehead with his fist] No, God hasn’t given me the wisdom! I can’t

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: think of the word for you!

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: [Tears away her hand] Get away! Drunkards... let’s go,

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: Denis!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Just throw a glance at him, with only one eye if you like! Or say

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: only just one kind little word to him! God’s own sake!

SPEAKER: MARIA EGOROVNA
TEXT: Take away this... fool.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Then the devil take you, you accursed woman!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: with cries of horror. SAVVA stands between MERIK and MARIA EGOROVNA....

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: DENIS forces MERIK to one side and carries out his mistress. After this

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: all stand as if turned to stone. A prolonged pause. BORTSOV suddenly

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: waves his hands in the air.]

SPEAKER: BORTSOV
TEXT: Marie... where are you, Marie!

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: My God, my God! You’ve torn up my your murderers! What an

SPEAKER: NAZAROVNA
TEXT: accursed night!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: [Lowering his hand; he still holds the axe] Did I kill her or no?

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: HIGH ROAD

SPEAKER: TIHON
TEXT: Thank God, your head is safe....

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Then I didn’t kill her.... [Totters to his bed] Fate hasn’t sent

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: me to my death because of a stolen axe.... [Falls down and sobs] Woe!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Woe is me! Have pity on me, Orthodox people!

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: THE PROPOSAL

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: CHARACTERS

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: STEPAN STEPANOVITCH CHUBUKOV, a landowner

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: NATALYA STEPANOVNA, his daughter, twenty-five years old

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: IVAN VASSILEVITCH LOMOV, a neighbour of Chubukov, a large and

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: hearty, but very suspicious landowner

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: The scene is laid at CHUBUKOV’s country-house

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: A drawing-room in CHUBUKOV’S house.

SPEAKER: MERIK
TEXT: to meet him.]

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: My dear fellow, whom do I see! Ivan Vassilevitch! I am

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: extremely glad! [Squeezes his hand] Now this is a surprise, my

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: darling... How are you?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Thank you. And how may you be getting on?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: We just get along somehow, my angel, to your prayers, and

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: so on. Sit down, please do.... Now, you know, you shouldn’t forget all

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: about your neighbours, my darling. My dear fellow, why are you so formal

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: in your get-up? Evening dress, gloves, and so on. Can you be going

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: anywhere, my treasure?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: No, I’ve come only to see you, honoured Stepan Stepanovitch.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Then why are you in evening dress, my precious? As if you’re

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: paying a New Year’s Eve visit!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Well, you see, it’s like this. [Takes his arm] I’ve come to you,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: honoured Stepan Stepanovitch, to trouble you with a request. Not once or

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: twice have I already had the privilege of applying to you for help, and

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: you have always, so to speak... I must ask your pardon, I am getting

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: excited. I shall drink some water, honoured Stepan Stepanovitch.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [Aside] He’s come to borrow money! Shan’t give him any!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: You see, Honour Stepanitch... I beg pardon, Stepan Honouritch...

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I mean, I’m awfully excited, as you will please notice.... In short, you

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: alone can help me, though I don’t deserve it, of course... and haven’t

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: any right to count on your assistance....

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Oh, don’t go round and round it, darling! Spit it out! Well?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: One moment... this very minute. The fact is, I’ve come to ask the

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: hand of your daughter, Natalya Stepanovna, in marriage.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [Joyfully] By Jove! Ivan Vassilevitch! Say it again--I didn’t

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: hear it all!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I have the honour to ask...

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [Interrupting] My dear fellow... I’m so glad, and so on....

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Yes, indeed, and all that sort of thing. [Embraces and kisses LOMOV]

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: I’ve been hoping for it for a long time. It’s been my continual desire.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: own son. May God give you both His help and His love and so on, and I

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: did so much hope... What am I behaving in this idiotic way for? I’m off

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: my balance with joy, absolutely off my balance! Oh, with all my soul...

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: I’ll go and call Natasha, and all that.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: [Greatly moved] Honoured Stepan Stepanovitch, do you think I may

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: count on her consent?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Why, of course, my darling, and... as if she won’t consent!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: She’s in love; egad, she’s like a love-sick cat, and so on.... Shan’t be

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: long! [Exit.]

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: It’s cold... I’m trembling all over, just as if I’d got an

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: examination before me. The great thing is, I must have my mind made up.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: If I give myself time to think, to hesitate, to talk a lot, to look for

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: an ideal, or for real love, then I’ll never get married.... Brr!... It’s

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: cold! Natalya Stepanovna is an excellent housekeeper, not bad-looking,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: well-educated.... What more do I want? But I’m getting a noise in

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: my ears from excitement. [Drinks] And it’s impossible for me not to

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: marry.... In the first place, I’m already 35--a critical age, so to

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: speak. In the second place, I ought to lead a quiet and regular life....

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I suffer from palpitations, I’m excitable and always getting awfully

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: upset.... At this very moment my lips are trembling, and there’s a

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: twitch in my right eyebrow.... But the very worst of all is the way

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I sleep. I no sooner get into bed and begin to go off when suddenly

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: something in my left side--gives a pull, and I can feel it in my

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: shoulder and head.... I jump up like a lunatic, walk about a bit, and

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: lie down again, but as soon as I begin to get off to sleep there’s

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: another pull! And this may happen twenty times....

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Well, there! It’s you, and papa said, “Go; there’s a

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: merchant come for his goods.” How do you do, Ivan Vassilevitch!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: How do you do, honoured Natalya Stepanovna?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: You must excuse my apron and négligé... we’re

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: shelling peas for drying. Why haven’t you been here for such a long

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: time? Sit down. [They seat themselves] Won’t you have some lunch?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: No, thank you, I’ve had some already.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Then smoke.... Here are the matches.... The weather

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: is splendid now, but yesterday it was so wet that the workmen didn’t

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: do anything all day. How much hay have you stacked? Just think, I felt

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: greedy and had a whole field cut, and now I’m not at all pleased about

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: it because I’m afraid my hay may rot. I ought to have waited a bit. But

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: what’s this? Why, you’re in evening dress! Well, I never! Are you going

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: to a ball, or what?--though I must say you look better. Tell me, why are

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: you got up like that?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: [Excited] You see, honoured Natalya Stepanovna... the fact is,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I’ve made up my mind to ask you to hear me out.... Of course you’ll be

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: surprised and perhaps even angry, but a... [Aside] It’s awfully cold!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What’s the matter? [Pause] Well?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I shall try to be brief. You must know, honoured Natalya

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Stepanovna, that I have long, since my childhood, in fact, had the

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: privilege of knowing your family. My late aunt and her husband, from

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: whom, as you know, I inherited my land, always had the greatest respect

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: for your father and your late mother. The Lomovs and the Chubukovs

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: have always had the most friendly, and I might almost say the most

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: affectionate, regard for each other. And, as you know, my land is a near

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: neighbour of yours. You will remember that my Oxen Meadows touch your

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: birchwoods.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Excuse my interrupting you. You say, “my Oxen

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Meadows....” But are they yours?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Yes, mine.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What are you talking about? Oxen Meadows are ours,

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: not yours!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: No, mine, honoured Natalya Stepanovna.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Well, I never knew that before. How do you make that

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: out?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: How? I’m speaking of those Oxen Meadows which are wedged in

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: between your birchwoods and the Burnt Marsh.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Yes, yes.... They’re ours.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: No, you’re mistaken, honoured Natalya Stepanovna, they’re mine.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Just think, Ivan Vassilevitch! How long have they

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: been yours?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: How long? As long as I can remember.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Really, you won’t get me to believe that!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: But you can see from the documents, honoured Natalya Stepanovna.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Oxen Meadows, it’s true, were once the subject of dispute, but now

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: everybody knows that they are mine. There’s nothing to argue about.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: You see, my aunt’s grandmother gave the free use of these Meadows in

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: perpetuity to the peasants of your father’s grandfather, in return for

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: which they were to make bricks for her. The peasants belonging to your

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: father’s grandfather had the free use of the Meadows for forty years,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: and had got into the habit of regarding them as their own, when it

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: happened that...

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: No, it isn’t at all like that! Both my grandfather

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: and great-grandfather reckoned that their land extended to Burnt

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Marsh--which means that Oxen Meadows were ours. I don’t see what there

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: is to argue about. It’s simply silly!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I’ll show you the documents, Natalya Stepanovna!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: No, you’re simply joking, or making fun of me....

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What a surprise! We’ve had the land for nearly three hundred years, and

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: then we’re suddenly told that it isn’t ours! Ivan Vassilevitch, I can

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: hardly believe my own ears.... These Meadows aren’t worth much to me.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: They only come to five dessiatins [Note: 13.5 acres], and are worth

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: perhaps 300 roubles [Note: £30.], but I can’t stand unfairness. Say what

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: you will, but I can’t stand unfairness.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Hear me out, I implore you! The peasants of your father’s

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: grandfather, as I have already had the honour of explaining to you, used

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: to bake bricks for my aunt’s grandmother. Now my aunt’s grandmother,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: wishing to make them a pleasant...

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: I can’t make head or tail of all this about aunts

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: and grandfathers and grandmothers! The Meadows are ours, and that’s all.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Mine.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Ours! You can go on proving it for two days on end,

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: you can go and put on fifteen dress-jackets, but I tell you they’re

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: ours, ours, ours! I don’t want anything of yours and I don’t want to

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: give up anything of mine. So there!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Natalya Ivanovna, I don’t want the Meadows, but I am acting on

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: principle. If you like, I’ll make you a present of them.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: I can make you a present of them myself, because

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: they’re mine! Your behaviour, Ivan Vassilevitch, is strange, to say the

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: least! Up to this we have always thought of you as a good neighbour, a

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: friend: last year we lent you our threshing-machine, although on that

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: account we had to put off our own threshing till November, but you

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: behave to us as if we were gipsies. Giving me my own land, indeed!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: No, really, that’s not at all neighbourly! In my opinion, it’s even

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: impudent, if you want to know....

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Then you make out that I’m a land-grabber? Madam, never in my

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: life have I grabbed anybody else’s land, and I shan’t allow anybody to

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: accuse me of having done so.... [Quickly steps to the carafe and drinks

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: more water] Oxen Meadows are mine!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: It’s not true, they’re ours!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Mine!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: It’s not true! I’ll prove it! I’ll send my mowers

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: out to the Meadows this very day!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: What?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: My mowers will be there this very day!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I’ll give it to them in the neck!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: You dare!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: [Clutches at his heart] Oxen Meadows are mine! You understand?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Mine!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Please don’t shout! You can shout yourself hoarse in

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: your own house, but here I must ask you to restrain yourself!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: If it wasn’t, madam, for this awful, excruciating palpitation,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: if my whole inside wasn’t upset, I’d talk to you in a different way!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Ours!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Mine!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Ours!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Mine!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: What’s the matter? What are you shouting at?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Papa, please tell to this gentleman who owns Oxen

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Meadows, we or he?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [To LOMOV] Darling, the Meadows are ours!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: But, please, Stepan Stepanitch, how can they be yours? Do be a

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: reasonable man! My aunt’s grandmother gave the Meadows for the temporary

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: and free use of your grandfather’s peasants. The peasants used the land

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: for forty years and got as accustomed to it as if it was their own, when

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: it happened that...

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Excuse me, my precious.... You forget just this, that the

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: peasants didn’t pay your grandmother and all that, because the Meadows

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: were in dispute, and so on. And now everybody knows that they’re ours.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: It means that you haven’t seen the plan.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I’ll prove to you that they’re mine!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: You won’t prove it, my darling.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I shall!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Dear one, why yell like that? You won’t prove anything just

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: by yelling. I don’t want anything of yours, and don’t intend to give up

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: what I have. Why should I? And you know, my beloved, that if you propose

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: to go on arguing about it, I’d much sooner give up the meadows to the

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: peasants than to you. There!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I don’t understand! How have you the right to give away somebody

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: else’s property?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: You may take it that I know whether I have the right or not.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Because, young man, I’m not used to being spoken to in that tone of

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: voice, and so on: I, young man, am twice your age, and ask you to speak

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: to me without agitating yourself, and all that.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: No, you just think I’m a fool and want to have me on! You call

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: my land yours, and then you want me to talk to you calmly and politely!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Good neighbours don’t behave like that, Stepan Stepanitch! You’re not a

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: neighbour, you’re a grabber!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: What’s that? What did you say?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Papa, send the mowers out to the Meadows at once!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: What did you say, sir?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
