TEXT: Oxen Meadows are ours, and I shan’t give them up,

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: shan’t give them up, shan’t give them up!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: We’ll see! I’ll have the matter taken to court, and then I’ll

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: show you!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: To court? You can take it to court, and all that! You can! I

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: know you; you’re just on the look-out for a chance to go to court, and

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: all that.... You pettifogger! All your people were like that! All of

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: them!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Never mind about my people! The Lomovs have all been honourable

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: people, and not one has ever been tried for embezzlement, like your

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: grandfather!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: You Lomovs have had lunacy in your family, all of you!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: All, all, all!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Your grandfather was a drunkard, and your younger aunt,

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Nastasya Mihailovna, ran away with an architect, and so on.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: And your mother was hump-backed. [Clutches at his heart]

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Something pulling in my side.... My head.... Help! Water!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Your father was a guzzling gambler!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: And there haven’t been many backbiters to equal your

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: aunt!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: My left foot has gone to sleep.... You’re an intriguer.... Oh,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: my heart!... And it’s an open secret that before the last elections you

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: bri... I can see stars.... Where’s my hat?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: It’s low! It’s dishonest! It’s mean!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: And you’re just a malicious, double-faced intriguer! Yes!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Here’s my hat.... My heart!... Which way? Where’s the door?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Oh!... I think I’m dying.... My foot’s quite numb.... [Goes to the

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: door.]

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [Following him] And don’t set foot in my house again!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Take it to court! We’ll see!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Devil take him! [Walks about in excitement.]

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What a rascal! What trust can one have in one’s

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: neighbours after that!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: The villain! The scarecrow!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: The monster! First he takes our land and then he has

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: the impudence to abuse us.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: And that blind hen, yes, that turnip-ghost has the confounded

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: cheek to make a proposal, and so on! What? A proposal!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What proposal?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Why, he came here so as to propose to you.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: To propose? To me? Why didn’t you tell me so before?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: So he dresses up in evening clothes. The stuffed sausage! The

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: wizen-faced frump!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: To propose to me? Ah! [Falls into an easy-chair and

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: wails] Bring him back! Back! Ah! Bring him here.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Bring whom here?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Quick, quick! I’m ill! Fetch him! [Hysterics.]

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: What’s that? What’s the matter with you? [Clutches at his

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: head] Oh, unhappy man that I am! I’ll shoot myself! I’ll hang myself!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: We’ve done for her!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: I’m dying! Fetch him!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Tfoo! At once. Don’t yell!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What have they done to me! Fetch him back! Fetch

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: him! [A pause.]

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: He’s coming, and so on, devil take him! Ouf! Talk to him

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: yourself; I don’t want to....

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: [Wails] Fetch him!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [Yells] He’s coming, I tell you. Oh, what a burden, Lord,

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: to be the father of a grown-up daughter! I’ll cut my throat! I will,

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: indeed! We cursed him, abused him, drove him out, and it’s all you...

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: you!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: No, it was you!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: I tell you it’s not my fault. [LOMOV appears at the door] Now

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: you talk to him yourself [Exit.]

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: My heart’s palpitating awfully.... My foot’s gone to sleep....

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: There’s something keeps pulling in my side.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Forgive us, Ivan Vassilevitch, we were all a little

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: heated.... I remember now: Oxen Meadows really are yours.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: My heart’s beating awfully.... My Meadows.... My eyebrows are

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: both twitching....

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: The Meadows are yours, yes, yours.... Do sit

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: down.... [They sit] We were wrong....

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I did it on principle.... My land is worth little to me, but the

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: principle...

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Yes, the principle, just so.... Now let’s talk of

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: something else.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: The more so as I have evidence. My aunt’s grandmother gave the

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: land to your father’s grandfather’s peasants...

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Yes, yes, let that pass.... [Aside] I wish I knew

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: how to get him started.... [Aloud] Are you going to start shooting soon?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I’m thinking of having a go at the blackcock, honoured Natalya

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Stepanovna, after the harvest. Oh, have you heard? Just think, what a

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: misfortune I’ve had! My dog Guess, whom you know, has gone lame.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What a pity! Why?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I don’t know.... Must have got twisted, or bitten by some other

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: dog.... [Sighs] My very best dog, to say nothing of the expense. I gave

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Mironov 125 roubles for him.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: It was too much, Ivan Vassilevitch.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I think it was very cheap. He’s a first-rate dog.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Papa gave 85 roubles for his Squeezer, and Squeezer

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: is heaps better than Guess!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Squeezer better than. Guess? What an idea! [Laughs] Squeezer

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: better than Guess!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Of course he’s better! Of course, Squeezer is

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: young, he may develop a bit, but on points and pedigree he’s better than

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: anything that even Volchanetsky has got.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Excuse me, Natalya Stepanovna, but you forget that he is

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: overshot, and an overshot always means the dog is a bad hunter!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Overshot, is he? The first time I hear it!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I assure you that his lower jaw is shorter than the upper.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Have you measured?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Yes. He’s all right at following, of course, but if you want him

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: to get hold of anything...

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: In the first place, our Squeezer is a thoroughbred

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: animal, the son of Harness and Chisels, while there’s no getting at

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: the pedigree of your dog at all.... He’s old and as ugly as a worn-out

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: cab-horse.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: He is old, but I wouldn’t take five Squeezers for him.... Why,

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: how can you?... Guess is a dog; as for Squeezer, well, it’s too funny to

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: argue.... Anybody you like has a dog as good as Squeezer... you may find

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: them under every bush almost. Twenty-five roubles would be a handsome

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: price to pay for him.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: There’s some demon of contradiction in you to-day,

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Ivan Vassilevitch. First you pretend that the Meadows are yours; now,

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: that Guess is better than Squeezer. I don’t like people who don’t say

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: what they mean, because you know perfectly well that Squeezer is a

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: hundred times better than your silly Guess. Why do you want to say it

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: isn’t?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I see, Natalya Stepanovna, that you consider me either blind or a

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: fool. You must realize that Squeezer is overshot!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: It’s not true.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: He is!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: It’s not true!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Why shout, madam?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Why talk rot? It’s awful! It’s time your Guess was

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: shot, and you compare him with Squeezer!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Excuse me; I cannot continue this discussion: my heart is

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: palpitating.

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: I’ve noticed that those hunters argue most who know

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: least.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Madam, please be silent.... My heart is going to pieces....

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: I shan’t shut up until you acknowledge that Squeezer

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: is a hundred times better than your Guess!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: A hundred times worse! Be hanged to your Squeezer! His head...

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: eyes... shoulder...

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: There’s no need to hang your silly Guess; he’s

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: half-dead already!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: [Weeps] Shut up! My heart’s bursting!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: I shan’t shut up.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: What’s the matter now?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Papa, tell us truly, which is the better dog, our

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Squeezer or his Guess.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Stepan Stepanovitch, I implore you to tell me just one thing: is

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: your Squeezer overshot or not? Yes or no?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: And suppose he is? What does it matter? He’s the best dog in

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: the district for all that, and so on.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: But isn’t my Guess better? Really, now?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Don’t excite yourself, my precious one.... Allow me.... Your

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Guess certainly has his good points.... He’s pure-bred, firm on his

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: feet, has well-sprung ribs, and all that. But, my dear man, if you want

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: to know the truth, that dog has two defects: he’s old and he’s short in

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: the muzzle.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Excuse me, my heart.... Let’s take the facts.... You will

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: remember that on the Marusinsky hunt my Guess ran neck-and-neck with the

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Count’s dog, while your Squeezer was left a whole verst behind.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: He got left behind because the Count’s whipper-in hit him with

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: his whip.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: And with good reason. The dogs are running after a fox, when

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Squeezer goes and starts worrying a sheep!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: It’s not true!... My dear fellow, I’m very liable to lose my

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: temper, and so, just because of that, let’s stop arguing. You started

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: because everybody is always jealous of everybody else’s dogs. Yes, we’re

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: all like that! You too, sir, aren’t blameless! You no sooner notice that

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: some dog is better than your Guess than you begin with this, that... and

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: the other... and all that.... I remember everything!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I remember too!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [Teasing him] I remember, too.... What do you remember?

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: My heart... my foot’s gone to sleep.... I can’t...

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: [Teasing] My heart.... What sort of a hunter are

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: you? You ought to go and lie on the kitchen oven and catch blackbeetles,

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: not go after foxes! My heart!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Yes really, what sort of a hunter are you, anyway? You ought

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: to sit at home with your palpitations, and not go tracking animals. You

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: could go hunting, but you only go to argue with people and interfere

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: with their dogs and so on. Let’s change the subject in case I lose my

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: temper. You’re not a hunter at all, anyway!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: And are you a hunter? You only go hunting to get in with the

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Count and to intrigue.... Oh, my heart!... You’re an intriguer!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: What? I an intriguer? [Shouts] Shut up!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Intriguer!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Boy! Pup!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Old rat! Jesuit!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Shut up or I’ll shoot you like a partridge! You fool!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Everybody knows that--oh my heart!--your late wife used to beat

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: you.... My feet... temples... sparks.... I fall, I fall!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: And you’re under the slipper of your housekeeper!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: There, there, there... my heart’s burst! My shoulder’s come

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: off.... Where is my shoulder? I die. [Falls into an armchair] A doctor!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Boy! Milksop! Fool! I’m sick! [Drinks water] Sick!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: What sort of a hunter are you? You can’t even sit on

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: a horse! [To her father] Papa, what’s the matter with him? Papa! Look,

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: papa! [Screams] Ivan Vassilevitch! He’s dead!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: I’m sick!... I can’t breathe!... Air!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: He’s dead. [Pulls LOMOV’S sleeve] Ivan Vassilevitch!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Ivan Vassilevitch! What have you done to me? He’s dead. [Falls into an

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: armchair] A doctor, a doctor! [Hysterics.]

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Oh!... What is it? What’s the matter?

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: [Wails] He’s dead... dead!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Who’s dead? [Looks at LOMOV] So he is! My word! Water! A

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: doctor! [Lifts a tumbler to LOMOV’S mouth] Drink this!... No, he doesn’t

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: drink.... It means he’s dead, and all that.... I’m the most unhappy of

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: men! Why don’t I put a bullet into my brain? Why haven’t I cut my throat

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: yet? What am I waiting for? Give me a knife! Give me a pistol! [LOMOV

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: moves] He seems to be coming round.... Drink some water! That’s

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: right....

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: I see stars... mist.... Where am I?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Hurry up and get married and--well, to the devil with you!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: She’s willing! [He puts LOMOV’S hand into his daughter’s] She’s willing

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: and all that. I give you my blessing and so on. Only leave me in peace!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: [Getting up] Eh? What? To whom?

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: She’s willing! Well? Kiss and be damned to you!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: [Wails] He’s alive... Yes, yes, I’m willing....

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Kiss each other!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Eh? Kiss whom? [They kiss] Very nice, too. Excuse me, what’s

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: it all about? Oh, now I understand... my heart... stars... I’m happy.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Natalya Stepanovna.... [Kisses her hand] My foot’s gone to sleep....

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: I... I’m happy too....

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: What a weight off my shoulders.... Ouf!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: But... still you will admit now that Guess is worse

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: than Squeezer.

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: Better!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Worse!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Well, that’s a way to start your family bliss! Have some

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: champagne!

SPEAKER: LOMOV
TEXT: He’s better!

SPEAKER: NATALYA STEPANOVNA
TEXT: Worse! worse! worse!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: [Trying to shout her down] Champagne! Champagne!

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: THE WEDDING

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: CHARACTERS

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: EVDOKIM ZAHAROVITCH ZHIGALOV, a retired Civil Servant.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA, his wife

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: DASHENKA, their daughter

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: EPAMINOND MAXIMOVITCH APLOMBOV, Dashenka’s bridegroom

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: FYODOR YAKOVLEVITCH REVUNOV-KARAULOV, a retired captain

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: ANDREY ANDREYEVITCH NUNIN, an insurance agent

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: ANNA MARTINOVNA ZMEYUKINA, a midwife, aged 30, in a brilliantly red dress

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: IVAN MIHAILOVITCH YATS, a telegraphist

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: HARLAMPI SPIRIDONOVITCH DIMBA, a Greek confectioner

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: DMITRI STEPANOVITCH MOZGOVOY, a sailor of the Imperial Navy (Volunteer

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: Fleet)

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: GROOMSMEN, GENTLEMEN, WAITERS, ETC.

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: The scene is laid in one of the rooms of Andronov’s Restaurant

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: in dress-jackets are fussing round the table. An orchestra behind the

SPEAKER: CHUBUKOV
TEXT: scene is playing the music of the last figure of a quadrille.]

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: No, no, no!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: [Following her] Have pity on us! Have pity!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: No, no, no!

SPEAKER: GROOMSMAN
TEXT: [Chasing them] You can’t go on like this! Where are you off

SPEAKER: GROOMSMAN
TEXT: to? What about the _grand ronde? Grand ronde, s’il vous plait_! [They

SPEAKER: GROOMSMAN
TEXT: all go off.]

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: You had much better be dancing than upsetting me

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: with your speeches.

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: I’m not a Spinosa or anybody of that sort, to go making

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: figures-of-eight with my legs. I am a serious man, and I have a

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: character, and I see no amusement in empty pleasures. But it isn’t just

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: a matter of dances. You must excuse me, maman, but there is a good deal

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: in your behaviour which I am unable to understand. For instance, in

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: addition to objects of domestic importance, you promised also to give

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: me, with your daughter, two lottery tickets. Where are they?

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: My head’s aching a little... I expect it’s on

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: account of the weather.... If only it thawed!

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: You won’t get out of it like that. I only found out to-day

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: that those tickets are in pawn. You must excuse me, _maman_, but

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: it’s only swindlers who behave like that. I’m not doing this out of

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: egoisticism [Note: So in the original]--I don’t want your tickets--but

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: on principle; and I don’t allow myself to be done by anybody. I have

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: made your daughter happy, and if you don’t give me the tickets to-day

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: I’ll make short work of her. I’m an honourable man!

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: [Looks round the table and counts up the covers]

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: One, two, three, four, five...

SPEAKER: A WAITER
TEXT: The cook asks if you would like the ices served with rum,

SPEAKER: A WAITER
TEXT: madeira, or by themselves?

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: With rum. And tell the manager that there’s not enough wine.

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Tell him to prepare some more Haut Sauterne. [To NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA]

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: You also promised and agreed that a general was to be here to supper.

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: And where is he?

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: That isn’t my fault, my dear.

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Whose fault, then?

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: It’s Andrey Andreyevitch’s fault.... Yesterday he

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: came to see us and promised to bring a perfectly real general. [Sighs] I

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: suppose he couldn’t find one anywhere, or he’d have brought him....

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: You think we don’t mind? We’d begrudge our child nothing. A general, of

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: course...

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: But there’s more.... Everybody, including yourself, _maman_,

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: is aware of the fact that Yats, that telegraphist, was after Dashenka

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: before I proposed to her. Why did you invite him? Surely you knew it

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: would be unpleasant for me?

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Oh, how can you? Epaminond Maximovitch was married

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: himself only the other day, and you’ve already tired me and Dashenka out

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: with your talk. What will you be like in a year’s time? You are horrid,

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: really horrid.

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Then you don’t like to hear the truth? Aha! Oh, oh! Then

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: behave honourably. I only want you to do one thing, be honourable!

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: other end. The first couple are DASHENKA with one of the GROOMSMEN. The

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: last are YATS and ZMEYUKINA. These two remain behind. ZHIGALOV and DIMBA

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: enter and go up to the table.]

SPEAKER: GROOMSMAN
TEXT: [Shouting] Promenade! Messieurs, promenade! [Behind]

SPEAKER: GROOMSMAN
TEXT: Promenade!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: [To ZMEYUKINA] Have pity! Have pity, adorable Anna Martinovna.

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: Oh, what a man!... I’ve already told you that I’ve no voice

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: to-day.

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: I implore you to sing! Just one note! Have pity! Just one note!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: I’m tired of you.... [Sits and fans herself.]

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: No, you’re simply heartless! To be so cruel--if I may express

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: myself--and to have such a beautiful, beautiful voice! With such

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: a voice, if you will forgive my using the word, you shouldn’t be a

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: midwife, but sing at concerts, at public gatherings! For example, how

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: divinely you do that _fioritura_... that... [Sings] “I loved you; love

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: was vain then....” Exquisite!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: [Sings] “I loved you, and may love again.” Is that it?

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: That’s it! Beautiful!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: No, I’ve no voice to-day.... There, wave this fan for

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: me... it’s hot! [To APLOMBOV] Epaminond Maximovitch, why are you so

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: melancholy? A bridegroom shouldn’t be! Aren’t you ashamed of yourself,

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: you wretch? Well, what are you so thoughtful about?

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Marriage is a serious step! Everything must be considered from

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: all sides, thoroughly.

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: What beastly sceptics you all are! I feel quite suffocated

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: with you all around.... Give me atmosphere! Do you hear? Give me

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: atmosphere! [Sings a few notes.]

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: Beautiful! Beautiful!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: Fan me, fan me, or I feel I shall have a heart attack in a

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: minute. Tell me, please, why do I feel so suffocated?

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: It’s because you’re sweating....

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: Foo, how vulgar you are! Don’t dare to use such words!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: Beg pardon! Of course, you’re used, if I may say so, to

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: aristocratic society and....

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: Oh, leave me alone! Give me poetry, delight! Fan me, fan me!

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: [To DIMBA] Let’s have another, what? [Pours out] One can

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: always drink. So long only, Harlampi Spiridonovitch, as one doesn’t

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: forget one’s business. Drink and be merry.... And if you can drink at

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: somebody else’s expense, then why not drink? You can drink.... Your

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: health! [They drink] And do you have tigers in Greece?

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: And lions?

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: And lions too. In Russia zere’s nussing, and in Greece zere’s

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: everysing--my fazer and uncle and brozeres--and here zere’s nussing.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: H’m.... And are there whales in Greece?

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Yes, everysing.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: [To her husband] What are they all eating and

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: drinking like that for? It’s time for everybody to sit down to supper.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Don’t keep on shoving your fork into the lobsters.... They’re for the

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: general. He may come yet....

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: And are there lobsters in Greece?

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Yes... zere is everysing.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: Hm.... And Civil Servants.

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: I can imagine what the atmosphere is like in Greece!

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: There must be a lot of swindling. The Greeks are just like the

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: Armenians or gipsies. They sell you a sponge or a goldfish and all the

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: time they are looking out for a chance of getting something extra out of

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: you. Let’s have another, what?

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: What do you want to go on having another for? It’s

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: time everybody sat down to supper. It’s past eleven.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: If it’s time, then it’s time. Ladies and gentlemen, please!

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Dear visitors, please be seated!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: [Sitting down at the table] Give me poetry.

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: “And he, the rebel, seeks the storm,

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: As if the storm can give him peace.”

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: Give me the storm!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: [Aside] Wonderful woman! I’m in love! Up to my ears!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: etc. They all noisily seat themselves at the table. There is a minute’s

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: pause, while the band plays a march.]

SPEAKER: MOZGOVOY
TEXT: [Rising] Ladies and gentlemen! I must tell you this.... We are

SPEAKER: MOZGOVOY
TEXT: going to have a great many toasts and speeches. Don’t let’s wait, but

SPEAKER: MOZGOVOY
TEXT: begin at once. Ladies and gentlemen, the newly married!

SPEAKER: MOZGOVOY
TEXT: DASHENKA kiss each other.]

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: Beautiful! Beautiful! I must say, ladies and gentlemen, giving

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: honour where it is due, that this room and the accommodation generally

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: are splendid! Excellent, wonderful! Only you know, there’s one thing

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: we haven’t got--electric light, if I may say so! Into every country

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: electric light has already been introduced, only Russia lags behind.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: [Meditatively] Electricity... h’m.... In my opinion electric

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: lighting is just a swindle.... They put a live coal in and think you

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: don’t see them! No, if you want a light, then you don’t take a coal, but

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: something real, something special, that you can get hold of! You must

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: have a fire, you understand, which is natural, not just an invention!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: If you’d ever seen an electric battery, and how it’s made up,

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: you’d think differently.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: Don’t want to see one. It’s a swindle, a fraud on the

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: public.... They want to squeeze our last breath out of us.... We know

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: then, these... And, young man, instead of defending a swindle, you would

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: be much better occupied if you had another yourself and poured out some

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: for other people--yes!

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: I entirely agree with you, papa. Why start a learned

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: discussion? I myself have no objection to talking about every possible

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: scientific discovery, but this isn’t the time for all that! [To

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: DASHENKA] What do you think, _ma chère_?

SPEAKER: DASHENKA
TEXT: They want to show how educated they are, and so they always

SPEAKER: DASHENKA
TEXT: talk about things we can’t understand.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Thank God, we’ve lived our time without being

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: educated, and here we are marrying off our third daughter to an honest

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: man. And if you think we’re uneducated, then what do you want to come

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: here for? Go to your educated friends!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: I, Nastasya Timofeyevna, have always held your family in respect,

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: and if I did start talking about electric lighting it doesn’t mean that

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: I’m proud. I’ll drink, to show you. I have always sincerely wished Daria

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: Evdokimovna a good husband. In these days, Nastasya Timofeyevna, it is

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: difficult to find a good husband. Nowadays everybody is on the look-out

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: for a marriage where there is profit, money....

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: That’s a hint!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: [His courage failing] I wasn’t hinting at anything.... Present

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: company is always excepted.... I was only in general.... Please!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: Everybody knows that you’re marrying for love... the dowry is quite

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: trifling.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: No, it isn’t trifling! You be careful what you

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: say. Besides a thousand roubles of good money, we’re giving three

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: dresses, the bed, and all the furniture. You won’t find another dowry

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: like that in a hurry!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: I didn’t mean... The furniture’s splendid, of course, and... and

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: the dresses, but I never hinted at what they are getting offended at.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Don’t you go making hints. We respect you on

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: account of your parents, and we’ve invited you to the wedding, and here

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: you go talking. If you knew that Epaminond Maximovitch was marrying for

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: profit, why didn’t you say so before? [Tearfully] I brought her up,

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: I fed her, I nursed her.... I cared for her more than if she was an

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: emerald jewel, my little girl....

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: And you go and believe him? Thank you so much! I’m very

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: grateful to you! [To YATS] And as for you, Mr. Yats, although you are

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: acquainted with me, I shan’t allow you to behave like this in another’s

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: house. Please get out of this!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: I want you to be as straightforward as I am! In short, please

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: get out! [Band plays a flourish]

SPEAKER: THE GENTLEMEN
TEXT: Leave him alone! Sit down! Is it worth it! Let him be!

SPEAKER: THE GENTLEMEN
TEXT: Stop it now!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: I never... I... I don’t understand.... Please, I’ll go.... Only

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: you first give me the five roubles which you borrowed from me last year

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: on the strength of a _piqué_ waistcoat, if I may say so. Then I’ll just

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: have another drink and... go, only give me the money first.

SPEAKER: VARIOUS GENTLEMEN
TEXT: Sit down! That’s enough! Is it worth it, just for

SPEAKER: VARIOUS GENTLEMEN
TEXT: such trifles?

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: [Shouts] The health of the bride’s parents, Evdokim

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: Zaharitch and Nastasya Timofeyevna! [Band plays a flourish. Cheers.]

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: [Bows in all directions, in great emotion] I thank you! Dear

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: guests! I am very grateful to you for not having forgotten and for

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: having conferred this honour upon us without being standoffish And you

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: must not think that I’m a rascal, or that I’m trying to swindle anybody.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: I’m speaking from my heart--from the purity of my soul! I wouldn’t deny

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: anything to good people! We thank you very humbly! [Kisses.]

SPEAKER: DASHENKA
TEXT: [To her mother] Mama, why are you crying? I’m so happy!

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: _Maman_ is disturbed at your coming separation. But I should

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: advise her rather to remember the last talk we had.

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: Don’t cry, Nastasya Timofeyevna! Just think what are human tears,

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: anyway? Just petty psychiatry, and nothing more!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: And are there any red-haired men in Greece?

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Yes, everysing is zere.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: But you don’t have our kinds of mushroom.

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Yes, we’ve got zem and everysing.

SPEAKER: MOZGOVOY
TEXT: Harlampi Spiridonovitch, it’s your turn to speak! Ladies and

SPEAKER: MOZGOVOY
TEXT: gentlemen, a speech!

SPEAKER: ALL
TEXT: [To DIMBA] Speech! speech! Your turn!

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Why? I don’t understand.... What is it!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: No, no! You can’t refuse! It’s you turn! Get up!

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: [Gets up, confused] I can’t say what... Zere’s Russia and zere’s

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Greece. Zere’s people in Russia and people in Greece.... And zere’s

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: people swimming the sea in karavs, which mean sips, and people on

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: the land in railway trains. I understand. We are Greeks and you are

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: Russians, and I want nussing.... I can tell you... zere’s Russia and

SPEAKER: DIMBA
TEXT: zere’s Greece...

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Wait, ladies and gentlemen, don’t eat now! Wait! Just one minute,

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Nastasya Timofeyevna! Just come here, if you don’t mind! [Takes NASTASYA

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: TIMOFEYEVNA aside, puffing] Listen... The General’s coming... I

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: found one at last.... I’m simply worn out.... A real General, a solid

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: one--old, you know, aged perhaps eighty, or even ninety.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: When is he coming?

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: This minute. You’ll be grateful to me all your life. [Note: A

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: few lines have been omitted: they refer to the “General’s” rank and

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: its civil equivalent in words for which the English language has

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: no corresponding terms. The “General” is an ex-naval officer, a

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: second-class captain.]

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: You’re not deceiving me, Andrey darling?

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Well, now, am I a swindler? You needn’t worry!

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: [Sighs] One doesn’t like to spend money for

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: nothing, Andrey darling!

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Don’t you worry! He’s not a general, he’s a dream! [Raises his

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: voice] I said to him: “You’ve quite forgotten us, your Excellency!

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: It isn’t kind of your Excellency to forget your old friends! Nastasya

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Timofeyevna,” I said to him, “she’s very annoyed with you about it!”

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: I go when I don’t know the bridegroom?” “Oh, nonsense, your excellency,

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: why stand on ceremony? The bridegroom,” I said to him, “he’s a fine

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: fellow, very free and easy. He’s a valuer,” I said, “at the Law courts,

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: and don’t you think, your excellency, that he’s some rascal, some knave

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: of hearts. Nowadays,” I said to him, “even decent women are employed at

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: the Law courts.” He slapped me on the shoulder, we smoked a Havana cigar

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: each, and now he’s coming.... Wait a little, ladies and gentlemen, don’t

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: eat....

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: When’s he coming?

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: This minute. When I left him he was already putting on his

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: goloshes. Wait a little, ladies and gentlemen, don’t eat yet.

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: The band should be told to play a march.

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: [Shouts] Musicians! A march! [The band plays a march for a

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: minute.]

SPEAKER: A WAITER
TEXT: Mr. Revunov-Karaulov!

SPEAKER: A WAITER
TEXT: REVUNOV-KARAULOV.]

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: [Bowing] Please come in, your excellency! So glad

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: you’ve come!

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Awfully!

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: We, your excellency, aren’t celebrities, we aren’t important,

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: but quite ordinary, but don’t think on that account that there’s any

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: fraud. We put good people into the best place, we begrudge nothing.

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: Please!

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Awfully glad!

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Let me introduce to you, your excellency, the bridegroom,

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Epaminond Maximovitch Aplombov, with his newly born... I mean his newly

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: married wife! Ivan Mihailovitch Yats, employed on the telegraph! A

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: foreigner of Greek nationality, a confectioner by trade, Harlampi

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Spiridonovitch Dimba! Osip Lukitch Babelmandebsky! And so on, and so

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: on.... The rest are just trash. Sit down, your excellency!

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Awfully! Excuse me, ladies and gentlemen, I just want to say

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: two words to Andrey. [Takes NUNIN aside] I say, old man, I’m a little

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: put out.... Why do you call me your excellency? I’m not a general! I

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: don’t rank as the equivalent of a colonel, even.

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: [Whispers] I know, only, Fyodor Yakovlevitch, be a good man

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: and let us call you your excellency! The family here, you see, is

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: patriarchal; it respects the aged, it likes rank.

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Oh, if it’s like that, very well.... [Goes to the table]

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Awfully!

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Sit down, your excellency! Be so good as to have

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: some of this, your excellency! Only forgive us for not being used to

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: etiquette; we’re plain people!

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: [Not hearing] What? Hm... yes. [Pause] Yes.... In the old days

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: everybody used to live simply and was happy. In spite of my rank, I am

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: a man who lives plainly. To-day Andrey comes to me and asks me to come

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: here to the wedding. “How shall I go,” I said, “when I don’t know them?

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: It’s not good manners!” But he says: “They are good, simple, patriarchal

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: people, glad to see anybody.” Well, if that’s the case... why not?

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Very glad to come. It’s very dull for me at home by myself, and if my

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: presence at a wedding can make anybody happy, then I’m delighted to be

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: here....

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: Then that’s sincere, is it, your excellency? I respect that!

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: I’m a plain man myself, without any deception, and I respect others who

SPEAKER: ZHIGALOV
TEXT: are like that. Eat, your excellency!

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Is it long since you retired, your excellency?

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Eh? Yes, yes.... Quite true.... Yes. But, excuse me, what

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: is this? The fish is sour... and the bread is sour. I can’t eat this!

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: glad.... I love simplicity.... I’m an old man. I retired in 1865. I’m

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: 72. Yes, of course, in my younger days it was different, but--[Sees

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: MOZGOVOY] You there... a sailor, are you?

SPEAKER: MOZGOVOY
TEXT: Yes, just so.

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Aha, so... yes. The navy means hard work. There’s a lot to

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: think about and get a headache over. Every insignificant word has, so

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: to speak, its special meaning! For instance, “Hoist her top-sheets

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: and mainsail!” What’s it mean? A sailor can tell! He, he!--With almost

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: mathematical precision!

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: The health of his excellency Fyodor Yakovlevitch

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Revunov-Karaulov! [Band plays a flourish. Cheers.]

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: You, your excellency, have just expressed yourself on the subject

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: of the hard work involved in a naval career. But is telegraphy any

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: easier? Nowadays, your excellency, nobody is appointed to the telegraphs

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: if he cannot read and write French and German. But the transmission of

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: telegrams is the most difficult thing of all. Awfully difficult! Just

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: listen.

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: What does that mean?

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: It means, “I honour you, your excellency, for your virtues.” You

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: think it’s easy? Listen now. [Taps.]

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Louder; I can’t hear....

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: That means, “Madam, how happy I am to hold you in my embraces!”

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: What madam are you talking about? Yes.... [To MOZGOVOY] Yes, if

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: there’s a head-wind you must... let’s see... you must hoist your foretop

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: halyards and topsail halyards! The order is: “On the cross-trees to

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: the foretop halyards and topsail halyards” and at the same time, as

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: the sails get loose, you take hold underneath of the foresail and

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: fore-topsail halyards, stays and braces.

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: [Rising] Ladies and gentlemen...

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: [Cutting him short] Yes... there are a great many orders to

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: give. “Furl the fore-topsail and the foretop-gallant sail!!” Well,

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: what does that mean? It’s very simple! It means that if the top and

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: top-gallant sails are lifting the halyards, they must level the foretop

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: and foretop-gallant halyards on the hoist and at the same time the

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: top-gallants braces, as needed, are loosened according to the direction

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: of the wind...

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: [To REVUNOV] Fyodor Yakovlevitch, Mme. Zhigalov asks you to

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: talk about something else. It’s very dull for the guests, who can’t

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: understand....

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: What? Who’s dull? [To MOZGOVOY] Young man! Now suppose the ship

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: is lying by the wind, on the starboard tack, under full sail, and you’ve

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: got to bring her before the wind. What’s the order? Well, first you

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: whistle up above! He, he!

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Fyodor Yakovlevitch, that’s enough. Eat something.

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: As soon as the men are on deck you give the order, “To your

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: places!” What a life! You give orders, and at the same time you’ve

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: got to keep your eyes on the sailors, who run about like flashes of

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: lightning and get the sails and braces right. And at last you can’t

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: restrain yourself, and you shout, “Good children!” [He chokes and

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: coughs.]

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: [Making haste to use the ensuing pause to advantage] On

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: this occasion, so to speak, on the day on which we have met together to

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: honour our dear...

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: [Interrupting] Yes, you’ve got to remember all that! For

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: instance, “Hoist the topsail halyards. Lower the topsail gallants!”

SPEAKER: THE GROOMSMAN
TEXT: [Annoyed] Why does he keep on interrupting? We shan’t get

SPEAKER: THE GROOMSMAN
TEXT: through a single speech like that!

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: We are dull people, your excellency, and don’t

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: understand a word of all that, but if you were to tell us something

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: appropriate...

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: [Not hearing] I’ve already had supper, thank you. Did you say

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: there was goose? Thanks... yes. I’ve remembered the old days.... It’s

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: pleasant, young man! You sail on the sea, you have no worries, and [In

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: an excited tone of voice] do you remember the joy of tacking? Is there a

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: sailor who doesn’t glow at the memory of that manoeuvre? As soon as the

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: word is given and the whistle blown and the crew begins to go up--it’s

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: as if an electric spark has run through them all. From the captain to

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: the cabin-boy, everybody’s excited.

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: How dull! How dull! [General murmur.]

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: [Who has not heard it properly] Thank you, I’ve had supper.

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: He gives the command: “Stand by, gallants and topsail braces on the

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: starboard side, main and counter-braces to port!” Everything’s done in

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: a twinkling. Top-sheets and jib-sheets are pulled... taken to starboard.

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: senior officer orders, “To the braces,” and himself keeps his eye on the

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: mainsail, and when at last this sail is filling out and the ship begins

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: to turn, he yells at the top of his voice, “Let go the braces! Loose the

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: main halyards!” Everything flies about, there’s a general confusion for

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: a moment--and everything is done without an error. The ship has been

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: tacked!

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: [Exploding] General, your manners.... You ought to

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: be ashamed of yourself, at your age!

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Did you say sausage? No, I haven’t had any... thank you.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: [Loudly] I say you ought to be ashamed of yourself

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: at your age! General, your manners are awful!

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: [Confused] Ladies and gentlemen, is it worth it? Really...

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: In the first place, I’m not a general, but a second-class naval

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: captain, which, according to the table of precedence, corresponds to a

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: lieutenant-colonel.

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: If you’re not a general, then what did you go and

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: take our money for? We never paid you money to behave like that!

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: [Upset] What money?

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: You know what money. You know that you got 25

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: roubles from Andrey Andreyevitch.... [To NUNIN] And you look out,

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Andrey! I never asked you to hire a man like that!

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: There now... let it drop. Is it worth it?

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: Paid... hired.... What is it?

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Just let me ask you this. Did you receive 25 roubles from

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Andrey Andreyevitch?

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: What 25 roubles? [Suddenly realizing] That’s what it is! Now I

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: understand it all.... How mean! How mean!

SPEAKER: APLOMBOV
TEXT: Did you take the money?

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: I haven’t taken any money! Get away from me! [Leaves the table]

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: How mean! How low! To insult an old man, a sailor, an officer who has

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: served long and faithfully! If you were decent people I could call

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: somebody out, but what can I do now? [Absently] Where’s the door? Which

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: way do I go? Waiter, show me the way out! Waiter! [Going] How mean! How

SPEAKER: REVUNOV
TEXT: low! [Exit.]

SPEAKER: NASTASYA TIMOFEYEVNA
TEXT: Andrey, where are those 25 roubles?

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: Is it worth while bothering about such trifles? What does it

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: matter! Everybody’s happy here, and here you go.... [Shouts] The health

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: of the bride and bridegroom! A march! A march! [The band plays a march]

SPEAKER: NUNIN
TEXT: The health of the bride and bridegroom!

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: I’m suffocating! Give me atmosphere! I’m suffocating with you

SPEAKER: ZMEYUKINA
TEXT: all round me!

SPEAKER: YATS
TEXT: [In a transport of delight] My beauty! My beauty! [Uproar.]

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: [Trying to shout everybody else down] Ladies and gentlemen!

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: On this occasion, if I may say so...

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: THE BEAR

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: CHARACTERS

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: ELENA IVANOVNA POPOVA, a landowning little widow, with dimples on her

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: cheeks

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: GRIGORY STEPANOVITCH SMIRNOV, a middle-aged landowner

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: LUKA, Popova’s aged footman

SPEAKER: A GROOMSMAN
TEXT: is haranguing her.]

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: It isn’t right, madam.... You’re just destroying yourself. The

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: maid and the cook have gone off fruit picking, every living being is

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: rejoicing, even the cat understands how to enjoy herself and walks about

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: in the yard, catching midges; only you sit in this room all day, as if

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: this was a convent, and don’t take any pleasure. Yes, really! I reckon

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: it’s a whole year that you haven’t left the house!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I shall never go out.... Why should I? My life is already at an

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: end. He is in his grave, and I have buried myself between four walls....

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: We are both dead.

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Well, there you are! Nicolai Mihailovitch is dead, well, it’s the

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: will of God, and may his soul rest in peace.... You’ve mourned him--and

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: quite right. But you can’t go on weeping and wearing mourning for ever.

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: My old woman died too, when her time came. Well? I grieved over her, I

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: wept for a month, and that’s enough for her, but if I’ve got to weep

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: for a whole age, well, the old woman isn’t worth it. [Sighs] You’ve

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: forgotten all your neighbours. You don’t go anywhere, and you see

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: nobody. We live, so to speak, like spiders, and never see the light.

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: The mice have eaten my livery. It isn’t as if there were no good people

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: around, for the district’s full of them. There’s a regiment quartered at

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Riblov, and the officers are such beauties--you can never gaze your fill

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: at them. And, every Friday, there’s a ball at the camp, and every day

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: the soldier’s band plays.... Eh, my lady! You’re young and beautiful,

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: with roses in your cheek--if you only took a little pleasure. Beauty

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: won’t last long, you know. In ten years’ time you’ll want to be a

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: pea-hen yourself among the officers, but they won’t look at you, it will

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: be too late.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [With determination] I must ask you never to talk to me about

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: it! You know that when Nicolai Mihailovitch died, life lost all its

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: meaning for me. I vowed never to the end of my days to cease to wear

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: mourning, or to see the light.... You hear? Let his ghost see how well I

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: love him.... Yes, I know it’s no secret to you that he was often unfair

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: to me, cruel, and... and even unfaithful, but I shall be true till

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: death, and show him how I can love. There, beyond the grave, he will see

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: me as I was before his death....

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Instead of talking like that you ought to go and have a walk in

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: the garden, or else order Toby or Giant to be harnessed, and then drive

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: out to see some of the neighbours.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Oh! [Weeps.]

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Madam! Dear madam! What is it? Bless you!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: He was so fond of Toby! He always used to ride on him to the

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Korchagins and Vlasovs. How well he could ride! What grace there was

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: in his figure when he pulled at the reins with all his strength! Do you

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: remember? Toby, Toby! Tell them to give him an extra feed of oats.

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Yes, madam. [A bell rings noisily.]

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Shaking] Who’s that? Tell them that I receive nobody.

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Yes, madam. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Looks at the photograph] You will see, Nicolas, how I can love

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: and forgive.... My love will die out with me, only when this poor heart

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: will cease to beat. [Laughs through her tears] And aren’t you ashamed?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I am a good and virtuous little wife. I’ve locked myself in, and will

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: be true to you till the grave, and you... aren’t you ashamed, you bad

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: child? You deceived me, had rows with me, left me alone for weeks on

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: end....

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Madam, somebody is asking for you. He wants to see you....

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: But didn’t you tell him that since the death of my husband I’ve

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: stopped receiving?

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: I did, but he wouldn’t even listen; says that it’s a very pressing

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: affair.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I do not re-ceive!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: I told him so, but the... the devil... curses and pushes himself

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: right in.... He’s in the dining-room now.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Annoyed] Very well, ask him in.... What manners! [Exit LUKA]

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: How these people annoy me! What does he want of me? Why should he

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: disturb my peace? [Sighs] No, I see that I shall have to go into a

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: convent after all. [Thoughtfully] Yes, into a convent.... [Enter LUKA

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: with SMIRNOV.]

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [To LUKA] You fool, you’re too fond of talking.... Ass! [Sees

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: POPOVA and speaks with respect] Madam, I have the honour to present

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: myself, I am Grigory Stepanovitch Smirnov, landowner and retired

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: lieutenant of artillery! I am compelled to disturb you on a very

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: pressing affair.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Not giving him her hand] What do you want?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Your late husband, with whom I had the honour of being

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: acquainted, died in my debt for one thousand two hundred roubles, on

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: two bills of exchange. As I’ve got to pay the interest on a mortgage

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to-morrow, I’ve come to ask you, madam, to pay me the money to-day.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: One thousand two hundred.... And what was my husband in debt to

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: you for?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: He used to buy oats from me.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Sighing, to LUKA] So don’t you forget, Luka, to give Toby an

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: extra feed of oats. [Exit LUKA] If Nicolai Mihailovitch died in debt to

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: you, then I shall certainly pay you, but you must excuse me to-day, as I

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: haven’t any spare cash. The day after to-morrow my steward will be back

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: from town, and I’ll give him instructions to settle your account, but

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: at the moment I cannot do as you wish.... Moreover, it’s exactly seven

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: months to-day since the death of my husband, and I’m in a state of mind

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: which absolutely prevents me from giving money matters my attention.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: And I’m in a state of mind which, if I don’t pay the interest

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: due to-morrow, will force me to make a graceful exit from this life feet

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: first. They’ll take my estate!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: You’ll have your money the day after to-morrow.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I don’t want the money the day after tomorrow, I want it

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to-day.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: You must excuse me, I can’t pay you.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: And I can’t wait till after to-morrow.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Well, what can I do, if I haven’t the money now!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: You mean to say, you can’t pay me?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I can’t.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Hm! Is that the last word you’ve got to say?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Yes, the last word.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: The last word? Absolutely your last?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Absolutely.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Thank you so much. I’ll make a note of it. [Shrugs his

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: shoulders] And then people want me to keep calm! I meet a man on

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: the road, and he asks me “Why are you always so angry, Grigory

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Stepanovitch?” But how on earth am I not to get angry? I want the money

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: desperately. I rode out yesterday, early in the morning, and called on

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: all my debtors, and not a single one of them paid up! I was just about

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: dead-beat after it all, slept, goodness knows where, in some inn, kept

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: by a Jew, with a vodka-barrel by my head. At last I get here, seventy

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: versts from home, and hope to get something, and I am received by you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: with a “state of mind”! How shouldn’t I get angry.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I thought I distinctly said my steward will pay you when he

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: returns from town.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I didn’t come to your steward, but to you! What the devil,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: excuse my saying so, have I to do with your steward!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Excuse me, sir, I am not accustomed to listen to such

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: expressions or to such a tone of voice. I want to hear no more. [Makes a

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: rapid exit.]

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Well, there! “A state of mind.”... “Husband died seven months

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: ago!” Must I pay the interest, or mustn’t I? I ask you: Must I pay,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: or must I not? Suppose your husband is dead, and you’ve got a state

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: of mind, and nonsense of that sort.... And your steward’s gone away

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: somewhere, devil take him, what do you want me to do? Do you think I can

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: fly away from my creditors in a balloon, or what? Or do you expect me

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to go and run my head into a brick wall? I go to Grusdev and he isn’t at

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: home, Yaroshevitch has hidden himself, I had a violent row with Kuritsin

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: and nearly threw him out of the window, Mazugo has something the matter

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: with his bowels, and this woman has “a state of mind.” Not one of the

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: swine wants to pay me! Just because I’m too gentle with them, because

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I’m a rag, just weak wax in their hands! I’m much too gentle with them!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Well, just you wait! You’ll find out what I’m like! I shan’t let you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: play about with me, confound it! I shall jolly well stay here until she

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: pays! Brr!... How angry I am to-day, how angry I am! All my inside is

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: quivering with anger, and I can’t even breathe.... Foo, my word, I even

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: feel sick! [Yells] Waiter!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: What is it?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Get me some kvass or water! [Exit LUKA] What a way to reason! A

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: man is in desperate need of his money, and she won’t pay it because,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: you see, she is not disposed to attend to money matters!... That’s real

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: silly feminine logic. That’s why I never did like, and don’t like now,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to have to talk to women. I’d rather sit on a barrel of gunpowder than

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: talk to a woman. Brr!... I feel quite chilly--and it’s all on account of

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: that little bit of fluff! I can’t even see one of these poetic creatures

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: from a distance without breaking out into a cold sweat out of sheer

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: anger. I can’t look at them. [Enter LUKA with water.]

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Madam is ill and will see nobody.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Get out! [Exit LUKA] Ill and will see nobody! No, it’s all

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: right, you don’t see me.... I’m going to stay and will sit here till you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: give me the money. You can be ill for a week, if you like, and I’ll stay

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: here for a week.... If you’re ill for a year--I’ll stay for a year.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I’m going to get my own, my dear! You don’t get at me with your widow’s

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: weeds and your dimpled cheeks! I know those dimples! [Shouts through the

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: window] Simeon, take them out! We aren’t going away at once! I’m staying

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: here! Tell them in the stable to give the horses some oats! You

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: fool, you’ve let the near horse’s leg get tied up in the reins again!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: from the window] Oh, it’s bad.... The heat’s frightful, nobody pays up.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I slept badly, and on top of everything else here’s a bit of fluff in

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: mourning with “a state of mind.”... My head’s aching.... Shall I have

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: some vodka, what? Yes, I think I will. [Yells] Waiter!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: What is it?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: A glass of vodka! [Exit LUKA] Ouf! [Sits and inspects himself]

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I must say I look well! Dust all over, boots dirty, unwashed, unkempt,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: straw on my waistcoat.... The dear lady may well have taken me for a

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: brigand. [Yawns] It’s rather impolite to come into a drawing-room in

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: this state, but it can’t be helped.... I am not here as a visitor,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: but as a creditor, and there’s no dress specially prescribed for

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: creditors....

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: You allow yourself to go very far, sir....

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: SMIRNOV [Angrily] What?

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: I... er... nothing... I really...

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Whom are you talking to? Shut up!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: [Aside] The devil’s come to stay.... Bad luck that brought him....

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Oh, how angry I am! So angry that I think I could grind the

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: whole world to dust.... I even feel sick.... [Yells] Waiter!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Her eyes downcast] Sir, in my solitude I have grown

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: unaccustomed to the masculine voice, and I can’t stand shouting. I must

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: ask you not to disturb my peace.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Pay me the money, and I’ll go.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I told you perfectly plainly; I haven’t any money to spare; wait

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: until the day after to-morrow.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: And I told you perfectly plainly I don’t want the money the day

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: after to-morrow, but to-day. If you don’t pay me to-day, I’ll have to

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: hang myself to-morrow.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: But what can I do if I haven’t got the money? You’re so strange!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Then you won’t pay me now? Eh?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I can’t.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: In that case I stay here and shall wait until I get it. [Sits

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: down] You’re going to pay me the day after to-morrow? Very well! I’ll

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: stay here until the day after to-morrow. I’ll sit here all the time....

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: haven’t I? Or do you think I’m doing this for a joke?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Please don’t shout! This isn’t a stable!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I wasn’t asking you about a stable, but whether I’d got my

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: interest to pay to-morrow or not?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: You don’t know how to behave before women!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: No, I do know how to behave before women!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: No, you don’t! You’re a rude, ill-bred man! Decent people don’t

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: talk to a woman like that!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: What a business! How do you want me to talk to you? In French,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: or what? [Loses his temper and lisps] _Madame, je vous prie_.... How

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: happy I am that you don’t pay me.... Ah, pardon. I have disturbed you!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Such lovely weather to-day! And how well you look in mourning! [Bows.]

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: That’s silly and rude.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Teasing her] Silly and rude! I don’t know how to behave before

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: women! Madam, in my time I’ve seen more women than you’ve seen sparrows!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Three times I’ve fought duels on account of women. I’ve refused twelve

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: women, and nine have refused me! Yes! There was a time when I played the

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: fool, scented myself, used honeyed words, wore jewellery, made beautiful

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: bows. I used to love, to suffer, to sigh at the moon, to get sour, to

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: thaw, to freeze.... I used to love passionately, madly, every blessed

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: way, devil take me; I used to chatter like a magpie about emancipation,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: and wasted half my wealth on tender feelings, but now--you must excuse

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: me! You won’t get round me like that now! I’ve had enough! Black eyes,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: passionate eyes, ruby lips, dimpled cheeks, the moon, whispers, timid

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: breathing--I wouldn’t give a brass farthing for the lot, madam! Present

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: company always excepted, all women, great or little, are insincere,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: crooked, backbiters, envious, liars to the marrow of their bones, vain,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: trivial, merciless, unreasonable, and, as far as this is concerned [taps

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: his forehead] excuse my outspokenness, a sparrow can give ten points to

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: any philosopher in petticoats you like to name! You look at one of

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: these poetic creatures: all muslin, an ethereal demi-goddess, you have a

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: million transports of joy, and you look into her soul--and see a common

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: crocodile! [He grips the back of a chair; the chair creaks and breaks]

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: But the most disgusting thing of all is that this crocodile for some

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: reason or other imagines that its chef d’oeuvre, its privilege and

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: monopoly, is its tender feelings. Why, confound it, hang me on that nail

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: feet upwards, if you like, but have you met a woman who can love anybody

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: except a lapdog? When she’s in love, can she do anything but snivel and

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: slobber? While a man is suffering and making sacrifices all her love

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: expresses itself in her playing about with her scarf, and trying to hook

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: him more firmly by the nose. You have the misfortune to be a woman, you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: know from yourself what is the nature of woman. Tell me truthfully,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: have you ever seen a woman who was sincere, faithful, and constant? You

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: haven’t! Only freaks and old women are faithful and constant! You’ll

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: meet a cat with a horn or a white woodcock sooner than a constant woman!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Then, according to you, who is faithful and constant in love? Is

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: it the man?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Yes, the man!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: The man! [Laughs bitterly] Men are faithful and constant in

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: love! What an idea! [With heat] What right have you to talk like that?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Men are faithful and constant! Since we are talking about it, I’ll

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: tell you that of all the men I knew and know, the best was my late

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: husband.... I loved him passionately with all my being, as only a young

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: and imaginative woman can love, I gave him my youth, my happiness, my

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: life, my fortune, I breathed in him, I worshipped him as if I were a

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: heathen, and... and what then? This best of men shamelessly deceived me

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: at every step! After his death I found in his desk a whole drawerful

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: of love-letters, and when he was alive--it’s an awful thing to

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: remember!--he used to leave me alone for weeks at a time, and make love

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: to other women and betray me before my very eyes; he wasted my money,

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: and made fun of my feelings.... And, in spite of all that, I loved him

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: and was true to him. And not only that, but, now that he is dead, I

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: am still true and constant to his memory. I have shut myself for ever

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: within these four walls, and will wear these weeds to the very end....

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Laughs contemptuously] Weeds!... I don’t understand what you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: take me for. As if I don’t know why you wear that black domino and bury

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: yourself between four walls! I should say I did! It’s so mysterious, so

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: poetic! When some junker [Note: So in the original.] or some tame poet

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: goes past your windows he’ll think: “There lives the mysterious Tamara

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: who, for the love of her husband, buried herself between four walls.” We

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: know these games!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Exploding] What? How dare you say all that to me?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: You may have buried yourself alive, but you haven’t forgotten

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to powder your face!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: How dare you speak to me like that?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Please don’t shout, I’m not your steward! You must allow me to

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: call things by their real names. I’m not a woman, and I’m used to saying

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: what I think straight out! Don’t you shout, either!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I’m not shouting, it’s you! Please leave me alone!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Pay me my money and I’ll go.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I shan’t give you any money!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Oh, no, you will.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I shan’t give you a farthing, just to spite you. You leave me

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: alone!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I have not the pleasure of being either your husband or your

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: fiancé, so please don’t make scenes. [Sits] I don’t like it.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Choking with rage] So you sit down?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I do.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I ask you to go away!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Give me my money.... [Aside] Oh, how angry I am! How angry I

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: am!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I don’t want to talk to impudent scoundrels! Get out of this!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: No?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: No!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Very well then! [Rings, enter LUKA] Luka, show this gentleman

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: out!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: [Approaches SMIRNOV] Would you mind going out, sir, as you’re

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: asked to! You needn’t...

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Jumps up] Shut up! Who are you talking to? I’ll chop you into

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: pieces!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: [Clutches at his heart] Little fathers!... What people!... [Falls

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: into a chair] Oh, I’m ill, I’m ill! I can’t breathe!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Where’s Dasha? Dasha! [Shouts] Dasha! Pelageya! Dasha! [Rings.]

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Oh! They’ve all gone out to pick fruit.... There’s nobody at home!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: I’m ill! Water!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Get out of this, now.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Can’t you be more polite?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Clenches her fists and stamps her foot] You’re a boor! A coarse

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: bear! A Bourbon! A monster!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: What? What did you say?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I said you are a bear, a monster!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Approaching her] May I ask what right you have to insult me?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: And suppose I am insulting you? Do you think I’m afraid of you?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: And do you think that just because you’re a poetic creature you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: can insult me with impunity? Eh? We’ll fight it out!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Little fathers!... What people!... Water!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Pistols!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Do you think I’m afraid of you just because you have large fists

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: and a bull’s throat? Eh? You Bourbon!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: We’ll fight it out! I’m not going to be insulted by anybody,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: and I don’t care if you are a woman, one of the “softer sex,” indeed!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Trying to interrupt him] Bear! Bear! Bear!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: It’s about time we got rid of the prejudice that only men need

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: pay for their insults. Devil take it, if you want equality of rights you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: can have it. We’re going to fight it out!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: With pistols? Very well!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: This very minute.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: This very minute! My husband had some pistols.... I’ll bring

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: them here. [Is going, but turns back] What pleasure it will give me to

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: put a bullet into your thick head! Devil take you! [Exit.]

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I’ll bring her down like a chicken! I’m not a little boy or a

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: sentimental puppy; I don’t care about this “softer sex.”

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Gracious little fathers!... [Kneels] Have pity on a poor old man,

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: and go away from here! You’ve frightened her to death, and now you want

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: to shoot her!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Not hearing him] If she fights, well that’s equality of

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: rights, emancipation, and all that! Here the sexes are equal! I’ll shoot

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: her on principle! But what a woman! [Parodying her] “Devil take you!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I’ll put a bullet into your thick head.” Eh? How she reddened, how her

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: cheeks shone!... She accepted my challenge! My word, it’s the first time

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: in my life that I’ve seen....

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Go away, sir, and I’ll always pray to God for you!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: She is a woman! That’s the sort I can understand! A real woman!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Not a sour-faced jellybag, but fire, gunpowder, a rocket! I’m even sorry

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to have to kill her!

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: [Weeps] Dear... dear sir, do go away!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I absolutely like her! Absolutely! Even though her cheeks are

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: dimpled, I like her! I’m almost ready to let the debt go... and I’m not

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: angry any longer.... Wonderful woman!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Here are the pistols.... But before we fight you must show me

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: how to fire. I’ve never held a pistol in my hands before.

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: Oh, Lord, have mercy and save her.... I’ll go and find the

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: coachman and the gardener.... Why has this infliction come on us....

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Examining the pistols] You see, there are several sorts of

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: pistols.... There are Mortimer pistols, specially made for duels, they

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: fire a percussion-cap. These are Smith and Wesson revolvers, triple

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: action, with extractors.... These are excellent pistols. They can’t cost

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: less than ninety roubles the pair.... You must hold the revolver like

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: this.... [Aside] Her eyes, her eyes! What an inspiring woman!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Like this?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Yes, like this.... Then you cock the trigger, and take aim like

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: this.... Put your head back a little! Hold your arm out properly....

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Like that.... Then you press this thing with your finger--and that’s

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: all. The great thing is to keep cool and aim steadily.... Try not to

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: jerk your arm.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Very well.... It’s inconvenient to shoot in a room, let’s go

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: into the garden.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Come along then. But I warn you, I’m going to fire in the air.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: That’s the last straw! Why?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Because... because... it’s my affair.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Are you afraid? Yes? Ah! No, sir, you don’t get out of it! You

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: come with me! I shan’t have any peace until I’ve made a hole in your

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: forehead... that forehead which I hate so much! Are you afraid?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Yes, I am afraid.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: You lie! Why won’t you fight?

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Because... because you... because I like you.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Laughs] He likes me! He dares to say that he likes me! [Points

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: to the door] That’s the way.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Loads the revolver in silence, takes his cap and goes to the
