SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: door. There he stops for half a minute, while they look at each other

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: in silence, then he hesitatingly approaches POPOVA] Listen.... Are you

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: still angry? I’m devilishly annoyed, too... but, do you understand...

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: how can I express myself?... The fact is, you see, it’s like this, so to

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: speak.... [Shouts] Well, is it my fault that I like you? [He snatches at

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: the back of a chair; the chair creaks and breaks] Devil take it, how I’m

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: smashing up your furniture! I like you! Do you understand? I... I almost

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: love you!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Get away from me--I hate you!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: God, what a woman! I’ve never in my life seen one like her! I’m

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: lost! Done for! Fallen into a mousetrap, like a mouse!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Stand back, or I’ll fire!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Fire, then! You can’t understand what happiness it would be to

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: die before those beautiful eyes, to be shot by a revolver held in that

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: little, velvet hand.... I’m out of my senses! Think, and make up your

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: mind at once, because if I go out we shall never see each other again!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Decide now.... I am a landowner, of respectable character, have an

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: income of ten thousand a year. I can put a bullet through a coin tossed

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: into the air as it comes down.... I own some fine horses.... Will you be

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: my wife?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Indignantly shakes her revolver] Let’s fight! Let’s go out!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I’m mad.... I understand nothing. [Yells] Waiter, water!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Yells] Let’s go out and fight!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: I’m off my head, I’m in love like a boy, like a fool! [Snatches

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: her hand, she screams with pain] I love you! [Kneels] I love you as I’ve

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: never loved before! I’ve refused twelve women, nine have refused me,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: but I never loved one of them as I love you.... I’m weak, I’m wax, I’ve

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: melted.... I’m on my knees like a fool, offering you my hand.... Shame,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: shame! I haven’t been in love for five years, I’d taken a vow, and now

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: all of a sudden I’m in love, like a fish out of water! I offer you my

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: hand. Yes or no? You don’t want me? Very well! [Gets up and quickly goes

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to the door.]

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Stop.

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Stops] Well?

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Nothing, go away.... No, stop.... No, go away, go away! I hate

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: you! Or no.... Don’t go away! Oh, if you knew how angry I am, how angry

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: I am! [Throws her revolver on the table] My fingers have swollen because

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: of all this.... [Tears her handkerchief in temper] What are you waiting

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: for? Get out!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: Good-bye.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Yes, yes, go away!... [Yells] Where are you going? Stop.... No,

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: go away. Oh, how angry I am! Don’t come near me, don’t come near me!

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: [Approaching her] How angry I am with myself! I’m in love like

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: a student, I’ve been on my knees.... [Rudely] I love you! What do I want

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: to fall in love with you for? To-morrow I’ve got to pay the interest,

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: and begin mowing, and here you.... [Puts his arms around her] I shall

SPEAKER: SMIRNOV
TEXT: never forgive myself for this....

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Get away from me! Take your hands away! I hate you! Let’s go and

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: fight!

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: COACHMAN with a pitchfork, and WORKMEN with poles.]

SPEAKER: LUKA
TEXT: [Catches sight of the pair kissing] Little fathers! [Pause.]

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: [Lowering her eyes] Luka, tell them in the stables that Toby

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: isn’t to have any oats at all to-day.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: A TRAGEDIAN IN SPITE OF HIMSELF

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: CHARACTERS

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: IVAN IVANOVITCH TOLKACHOV, the father of a family

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: ALEXEY ALEXEYEVITCH MURASHKIN, his friend

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: The scene is laid in St. Petersburg, in MURASHKIN’S flat

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: desk. Enter TOLKACHOV holding in his hands a glass globe for a lamp,

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: a toy bicycle, three hat-boxes, a large parcel containing a dress, a

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: bin-case of beer, and several little parcels. He looks round stupidly

SPEAKER: POPOVA
TEXT: and lets himself down on the sofa in exhaustion.]

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: How do you do, Ivan Ivanovitch? Delighted to see you! What

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: brings you here?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: [Breathing heavily] My dear good fellow... I want to ask

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: you something.... I implore you lend me a revolver till to-morrow. Be a

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: friend!

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: What do you want a revolver for?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: I must have it.... Oh, little fathers!... give me some

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: water... water quickly!... I must have it... I’ve got to go through a

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: dark wood to-night, so in case of accidents... do, please, lend it to

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: me.

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: Oh, you liar, Ivan Ivanovitch! What the devil have you got to

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: do in a dark wood? I expect you are up to something. I can see by your

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: face that you are up to something. What’s the matter with you? Are you

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: ill?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Wait a moment, let me breathe.... Oh little mothers! I am

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: dog-tired. I’ve got a feeling all over me, and in my head as well, as if

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: I’ve been roasted on a spit. I can’t stand it any longer. Be a friend,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: and don’t ask me any questions or insist on details; just give me the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: revolver! I beseech you!

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: Well, really! Ivan Ivanovitch, what cowardice is this? The

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: father of a family and a Civil Servant holding a responsible post! For

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: shame!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: What sort of a father of a family am I! I am a martyr. I am

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: a beast of burden, a nigger, a slave, a rascal who keeps on waiting here

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: for something to happen instead of starting off for the next world. I am

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: a rag, a fool, an idiot. Why am I alive? What’s the use? [Jumps up] Well

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: now, tell me why am I alive? What’s the purpose of this uninterrupted

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: series of mental and physical sufferings? I understand being a martyr

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: to an idea, yes! But to be a martyr to the devil knows what, skirts and

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: lamp-globes, no! I humbly decline! No, no, no! I’ve had enough! Enough!

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: Don’t shout, the neighbours will hear you!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Let your neighbours hear; it’s all the same to me! If you

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: don’t give me a revolver somebody else will, and there will be an end of

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: me anyway! I’ve made up my mind!

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: Hold on, you’ve pulled off a button. Speak calmly. I still

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: don’t understand what’s wrong with your life.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: What’s wrong? You ask me what’s wrong? Very well, I’ll tell

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: you! Very well! I’ll tell you everything, and then perhaps my soul will

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: be lighter. Let’s sit down. Now listen... Oh, little mothers, I am out

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: of breath!... Just let’s take to-day as an instance. Let’s take to-day.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: As you know, I’ve got to work at the Treasury from ten to four. It’s

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: hot, it’s stuffy, there are flies, and, my dear fellow, the very dickens

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: of a chaos. The Secretary is on leave, Khrapov has gone to get married,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: and the smaller fry is mostly in the country, making love or occupied

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: with amateur theatricals. Everybody is so sleepy, tired, and done up

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: that you can’t get any sense out of them. The Secretary’s duties are in

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: the hands of an individual who is deaf in the left ear and in love; the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: public has lost its memory; everybody is running about angry and raging,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: and there is such a hullabaloo that you can’t hear yourself speak.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Confusion and smoke everywhere. And my work is deathly: always the same,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: always the same--first a correction, then a reference back, another

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: correction, another reference back; it’s all as monotonous as the waves

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: of the sea. One’s eyes, you understand, simply crawl out of one’s head.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Give me some water.... You come out a broken, exhausted man. You would

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: like to dine and fall asleep, but you don’t!--You remember that you live

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: in the country--that is, you are a slave, a rag, a bit of string, a bit

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: of limp flesh, and you’ve got to run round and do errands. Where we live

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: a pleasant custom has grown up: when a man goes to town every wretched

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: female inhabitant, not to mention one’s own wife, has the power and the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: right to give him a crowd of commissions. The wife orders you to run

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: into the modiste’s and curse her for making a bodice too wide across the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: chest and too narrow across the shoulders; little Sonya wants a new pair

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: of shoes; your sister-in-law wants some scarlet silk like the pattern

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: at twenty copecks and three arshins long.... Just wait; I’ll read you.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: pound of pork sausages; five copecks’ worth of cloves and cinnamon;

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: castor-oil for Misha; ten pounds of granulated sugar. To bring with you

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: from home: a copper jar for the sugar; carbolic acid; insect powder, ten

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: copecks’ worth; twenty bottles of beer; vinegar; and corsets for Mlle.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Shanceau at No. 82.... Ouf! And to bring home Misha’s winter coat and

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: goloshes. That is the order of my wife and family. Then there are

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: the commissions of our dear friends and neighbours--devil take them!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: To-morrow is the name-day of Volodia Vlasin; I have to buy a bicycle

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: for him. The wife of Lieutenant-Colonel Virkhin is in an interesting

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: condition, and I am therefore bound to call in at the midwife’s every

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: day and invite her to come. And so on, and so on. There are five notes

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: in my pocket and my handkerchief is all knots. And so, my dear fellow,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: you spend the time between your office and your train, running about the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: town like a dog with your tongue hanging out, running and running and

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: cursing life. From the clothier’s to the chemist’s, from the chemist’s

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: to the modiste’s, from the modiste’s to the pork butcher’s, and then

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: back again to the chemist’s. In one place you stumble, in a second you

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: lose your money, in a third you forget to pay and they raise a hue and

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: cry after you, in a fourth you tread on the train of a lady’s dress....

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Tfoo! You get so shaken up from all this that your bones ache all night

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: and you dream of crocodiles. Well, you’ve made all your purchases, but

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: how are you to pack all these things? For instance, how are you to put a

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: heavy copper jar together with the lamp-globe or the carbolic acid with

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: the tea? How are you to make a combination of beer-bottles and this

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: bicycle? It’s the labours of Hercules, a puzzle, a rebus! Whatever

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: tricks you think of, in the long run you’re bound to smash or scatter

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: something, and at the station and in the train you have to stand with

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: your arms apart, holding up some parcel or other under your chin, with

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: parcels, cardboard boxes, and such-like rubbish all over you. The train

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: starts, the passengers begin to throw your luggage about on all sides:

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: you’ve got your things on somebody else’s seat. They yell, they call for

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: the conductor, they threaten to have you put out, but what can I do? I

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: just stand and blink my eyes like a whacked donkey. Now listen to this.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: I get home. You think I’d like to have a nice little drink after my

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: righteous labours and a good square meal--isn’t that so?--but there is

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: no chance of that. My spouse has been on the look-out for me for some

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: time. You’ve hardly started on your soup when she has her claws into

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: you, wretched slave that you are--and wouldn’t you like to go to some

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: amateur theatricals or to a dance? You can’t protest. You are a husband,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: and the word husband when translated into the language of summer

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: residents in the country means a dumb beast which you can load to

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: any extent without fear of the interference of the Society for the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. So you go and blink at “A Family

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Scandal” or something, you applaud when your wife tells you to, and you

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: feel worse and worse and worse until you expect an apoplectic fit to

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: happen any moment. If you go to a dance you have to find partners

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: for your wife, and if there is a shortage of them then you dance the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: quadrilles yourself. You get back from the theatre or the dance after

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: midnight, when you are no longer a man but a useless, limp rag. Well,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: at last you’ve got what you want; you unrobe and get into bed. It’s

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: excellent--you can close your eyes and sleep.... Everything is so nice,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: poetic, and warm, you understand; there are no children squealing

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: behind the wall, and you’ve got rid of your wife, and your conscience is

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: clear--what more can you want? You fall asleep--and suddenly... you

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: hear a buzz!... Gnats! [Jumps up] Gnats! Be they triply accursed Gnats!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: tortures of the Inquisition! Buzz! It sounds so pitiful, so pathetic, as

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: if it’s begging your pardon, but the villain stings so that you have

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: to scratch yourself for an hour after. You smoke, and go for them, and

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: cover yourself from head to foot, but it is no good! At last you have

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: to sacrifice yourself and let the cursed things devour you. You’ve no

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: sooner got used to the gnats when another plague begins: downstairs

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: your wife begins practising sentimental songs with her two friends. They

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: sleep by day and rehearse for amateur concerts by night. Oh, my God!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Those tenors are a torture with which no gnats on earth can compare.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: stand enchanted.” Oh, the beastly things! They’ve about killed me! So

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: as to deafen myself a little I do this: I drum on my ears. This goes on

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: till four o’clock. Oh, give me some more water, brother!... I can’t...

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Well, not having slept, you get up at six o’clock in the morning and

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: off you go to the station. You run so as not to be late, and it’s muddy,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: foggy, cold--brr! Then you get to town and start all over again. So

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: there, brother. It’s a horrible life; I wouldn’t wish one like it for my

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: enemy. You understand--I’m ill! Got asthma, heartburn--I’m always afraid

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: of something. I’ve got indigestion, everything is thick before me...

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: I’ve become a regular psychopath.... [Looking round] Only, between

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: ourselves, I want to go down to see Chechotte or Merzheyevsky. There’s

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: some devil in me, brother. In moments of despair and suffering, when the

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: gnats are stinging or the tenors sing, everything suddenly grows dim;

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: you jump up and race round the whole house like a lunatic and shout, “I

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: want blood! Blood!” And really all the time you do want to let a knife

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: into somebody or hit him over the head with a chair. That’s what life

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: in a summer villa leads to! And nobody has any sympathy for me, and

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: everybody seems to think it’s all as it should be. People even laugh.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: But understand, I am a living being and I want to live! This isn’t

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: farce, it’s tragedy! I say, if you don’t give me your revolver, you

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: might at any rate sympathize.

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: I do sympathize.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: I see how much you sympathize.... Good-bye. I’ve got to buy

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: some anchovies and some sausage... and some tooth-powder, and then to

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: the station.

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: Where are you living?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: At Carrion River.

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: [Delighted] Really? Then you’ll know Olga Pavlovna Finberg,

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: who lives there?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: I know her. We are even acquainted.

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: How perfectly splendid! That’s so convenient, and it would be

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: so good of you...

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: What’s that?

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: My dear fellow, wouldn’t you do one little thing for me? Be a

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: friend! Promise me now.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: What’s that?

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: It would be such a friendly action! I implore you, my dear

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: man. In the first place, give Olga Pavlovna my very kind regards. In the

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: second place, there’s a little thing I’d like you to take down to her.

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: She asked me to get a sewing-machine but I haven’t anybody to send it

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: down to her by.... You take it, my dear! And you might at the same time

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: take down this canary in its cage... only be careful, or you’ll break

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: the door.... What are you looking at me like that for?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: A sewing-machine... a canary in a cage... siskins,

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: chaffinches...

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: Ivan Ivanovitch, what’s the matter with you? Why are you

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: turning purple?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: [Stamping] Give me the sewing-machine! Where’s the bird-cage?

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Now get on top yourself! Eat me! Tear me to pieces! Kill me! [Clenching

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: his fists] I want blood! Blood! Blood!

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: You’ve gone mad!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: [Treading on his feet] I want blood! Blood!

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: [In horror] He’s gone mad! [Shouts] Peter! Maria! Where are

SPEAKER: MURASHKIN
TEXT: you? Help!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: [Chasing him round the room] I want blood! Blood!

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: THE ANNIVERSARY

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: CHARACTERS

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: ANDREY ANDREYEVITCH SHIPUCHIN, Chairman of the N---- Joint Stock

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: Bank, a middle-aged man, with a monocle

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA, his wife, aged 25

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: KUSMA NICOLAIEVITCH KHIRIN, the bank’s aged book-keeper

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: NASTASYA FYODOROVNA MERCHUTKINA, an old woman wearing an old-fashioned

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: cloak

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: DIRECTORS OF THE BANK

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: EMPLOYEES OF THE BANK

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: The action takes place at the Bank

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: leading into the public department. There are two desks. The furniture

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: aims at a deliberately luxurious effect, with armchairs covered in

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: velvet, flowers, statues, carpets, and a telephone. It is midday. KHIRIN

SPEAKER: TOLKACHOV
TEXT: is alone; he wears long felt boots, and is shouting through the door.]

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Send out to the chemist for 15 copecks’ worth of valerian drops,

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: and tell them to bring some drinking water into the Directors’ office!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: This is the hundredth time I’ve asked! [Goes to a desk] I’m absolutely

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: tired out. This is the fourth day I’ve been working, without a chance of

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: shutting my eyes. From morning to evening I work here, from evening to

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: morning at home. [Coughs] And I’ve got an inflammation all over me.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I’m hot and cold, and I cough, and my legs ache, and there’s something

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: dancing before my eyes. [Sits] Our scoundrel of a Chairman, the brute,

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: is going to read a report at a general meeting. “Our Bank, its Present

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: and Future.” You’d think he was a Gambetta.... [At work] Two... one...

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: one... six... nought... seven.... Next, six... nought... one... six....

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: He just wants to throw dust into people’s eyes, and so I sit here and

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: work for him like a galley-slave! This report of his is poetic fiction

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: and nothing more, and here I’ve got to sit day after day and add

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: figures, devil take his soul! [Rattles on his counting-frame] I can’t

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: stand it! [Writing] That is, one... three... seven... two... one...

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: nought.... He promised to reward me for my work. If everything goes well

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: to-day and the public is properly put into blinkers, he’s promised me a

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: gold charm and 300 roubles bonus.... We’ll see. [Works] Yes, but if

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: my work all goes for nothing, then you’d better look out.... I’m very

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: excitable.... If I lose my temper I’m capable of committing some crime,

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: so look out! Yes!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: you! Thank you! I am extremely grateful.” Enter SHIPUCHIN. He wears

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: a frockcoat and white tie; he carries an album which has been just

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: presented to him.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [At the door, addresses the outer office] This present, my

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: dear colleagues, will be preserved to the day of my death, as a memory

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: of the happiest days of my life! Yes, gentlemen! Once more, I thank you!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Kusma Nicolaievitch!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: in with papers for his signature and go out.]

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Standing up] I have the honour to congratulate you, Andrey

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Andreyevitch, on the fiftieth anniversary of our Bank, and hope that...

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Warmly shakes hands] Thank you, my dear sir! Thank you!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: I think that in view of the unique character of the day, as it is an

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: anniversary, we may kiss each other!... [They kiss] I am very, very

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: glad! Thank you for your service... for everything! If, in the course of

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: the time during which I have had the honour to be Chairman of this Bank

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: anything useful has been done, the credit is due, more than to anybody

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: else, to my colleagues. [Sighs] Yes, fifteen years! Fifteen years as my

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: name’s Shipuchin! [Changes his tone] Where’s my report? Is it getting

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: on?

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Yes; there’s only five pages left.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Excellent. Then it will be ready by three?

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: If nothing occurs to disturb me, I’ll get it done. Nothing of

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: any importance is now left.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Splendid. Splendid, as my name’s Shipuchin! The general

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: meeting will be at four. If you please, my dear fellow. Give me the

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: first half, I’ll peruse it.... Quick.... [Takes the report] I base

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: enormous hopes on this report. It’s my _profession de foi_, or, better

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: still, my firework. [Note: The actual word employed.] My firework, as my

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: name’s Shipuchin! [Sits and reads the report to himself] I’m hellishly

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: tired.... My gout kept on giving me trouble last night, all the morning

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: I was running about, and then these excitements, ovations, agitations...

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: I’m tired!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Two... nought... nought... three... nine... two... nought. I

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: can’t see straight after all these figures.... Three... one... six...

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: four... one... five.... [Uses the counting-frame.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Another unpleasantness.... This morning your wife came to

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: see me and complained about you once again. Said that last night you

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: threatened her and her sister with a knife. Kusma Nicolaievitch, what do

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: you mean by that? Oh, oh!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Rudely] As it’s an anniversary, Andrey Andreyevitch, I’ll ask

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: for a special favour. Please, even if it’s only out of respect for my

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: toil, don’t interfere in my family life. Please!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Sighs] Yours is an impossible character, Kusma

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Nicolaievitch! You’re an excellent and respected man, but you behave to

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: women like some scoundrel. Yes, really. I don’t understand why you hate

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: them so?

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I wish I could understand why you love them so! [Pause.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: The employees have just presented me with an album; and the

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Directors, as I’ve heard, are going to give me an address and a silver

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: loving-cup.... [Playing with his monocle] Very nice, as my name’s

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Shipuchin! It isn’t excessive. A certain pomp is essential to the

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: reputation of the Bank, devil take it! You know everything, of

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: course.... I composed the address myself, and I bought the cup myself,

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: too.... Well, then there was 45 roubles for the cover of the address,

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: but you can’t do without that. They’d never have thought of it for

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: themselves. [Looks round] Look at the furniture! Just look at it! They

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: say I’m stingy, that all I want is that the locks on the doors should

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: be polished, that the employees should wear fashionable ties, and that

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: a fat hall-porter should stand by the door. No, no, sirs. Polished locks

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: and a fat porter mean a good deal. I can behave as I like at home, eat

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: and sleep like a pig, get drunk....

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Please don’t make hints.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Nobody’s making hints! What an impossible character

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: yours is.... As I was saying, at home I can live like a tradesman, a

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: _parvenu_, and be up to any games I like, but here everything must be

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: _en grand_. This is a Bank! Here every detail must _imponiren_, so to

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: speak, and have a majestic appearance. [He picks up a paper from the

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: floor and throws it into the fireplace] My service to the Bank has been

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: just this--I’ve raised its reputation. A thing of immense importance is

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: tone! Immense, as my name’s Shipuchin! [Looks over KHIRIN] My dear man,

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: a deputation of shareholders may come here any moment, and there you are

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: in felt boots, wearing a scarf... in some absurdly coloured jacket....

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: You might have put on a frock-coat, or at any rate a dark jacket....

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: My health matters more to me than your shareholders. I’ve an

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: inflammation all over me.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Excitedly] But you will admit that it’s untidy! You spoil

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: the _ensemble_!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: If the deputation comes I can go and hide myself. It won’t

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: matter if... seven... one... seven... two... one... five... nought.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I don’t like untidiness myself.... Seven... two... nine... [Uses the

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: counting-frame] I can’t stand untidiness! It would have been wiser of

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: you not to have invited ladies to to-day’s anniversary dinner....

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Oh, that’s nothing.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I know that you’re going to have the hall filled with them

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: to-night to make a good show, but you look out, or they’ll spoil

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: everything. They cause all sorts of mischief and disorder.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: On the contrary, feminine society elevates!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Yes.... Your wife seems intelligent, but on the Monday of last

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: week she let something off that upset me for two days. In front of a

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: lot of people she suddenly asks: “Is it true that at our Bank my husband

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: bought up a lot of the shares of the Driazhsky-Priazhsky Bank, which

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: have been falling on exchange? My husband is so annoyed about it!” This

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: in front of people. Why do you tell them everything, I don’t understand.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Do you want them to get you into serious trouble?

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Well, that’s enough, enough! All that’s too dull for an

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: anniversary. Which reminds me, by the way. [Looks at the time] My wife

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: ought to be here soon. I really ought to have gone to the station, to

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: meet the poor little thing, but there’s no time.... and I’m tired. I

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: must say I’m not glad of her! That is to say, I am glad, but I’d be

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: gladder if she only stayed another couple of days with her mother.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: She’ll want me to spend the whole evening with her to-night, whereas

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: we have arranged a little excursion for ourselves.... [Shivers] Oh, my

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: nerves have already started dancing me about. They are so strained that

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: I think the very smallest trifle would be enough to make me break into

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: tears! No, I must be strong, as my name’s Shipuchin!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: travelling satchel slung across her shoulder.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Ah! In the nick of time!

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Darling!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: We were only speaking of you just now! [Looks at his watch.]

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Panting] Were you very dull without me? Are you

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: well? I haven’t been home yet, I came here straight from the station.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: I’ve a lot, a lot to tell you.... I couldn’t wait.... I shan’t take off

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: my clothes, I’ll only stay a minute. [To KHIRIN] Good morning, Kusma

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Nicolaievitch! [To her husband] Is everything all right at home?

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Yes, quite. And, you know, you’ve got to look plumper and

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: better this week.... Well, what sort of a time did you have?

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Splendid. Mamma and Katya send their regards.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Vassili Andreitch sends you a kiss. [Kisses him] Aunt sends you a jar

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: of jam, and is annoyed because you don’t write. Zina sends you a kiss.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: frightened to tell you! Oh, if you only knew! But I see by your eyes

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: that you’re sorry I came!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: On the contrary.... Darling.... [Kisses her.]

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Oh, poor Katya, poor Katya! I’m so sorry for her, so

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: sorry for her.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: This is the Bank’s anniversary to-day, darling, we may get a

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: deputation of the shareholders at any moment, and you’re not dressed.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Oh, yes, the anniversary! I congratulate you,

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: gentlemen. I wish you.... So it means that to-day’s the day of the

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: meeting, the dinner.... That’s good. And do you remember that beautiful

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: address which you spent such a long time composing for the shareholders?

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Will it be read to-day?

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Confused] My dear, we don’t talk about these things. You’d

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: really better go home.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: In a minute, in a minute. I’ll tell you everything

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: in one minute and go. I’ll tell you from the very beginning. Well....

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: When you were seeing me off, you remember I was sitting next to that

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: stout lady, and I began to read. I don’t like to talk in the train. I

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: read for three stations and didn’t say a word to anyone.... Well, then

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: the evening set in, and I felt so mournful, you know, with such sad

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: thoughts! A young man was sitting opposite me--not a bad-looking fellow,

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: a brunette.... Well, we fell into conversation.... A sailor came along

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: then, then some student or other.... [Laughs] I told them that I wasn’t

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: married... and they did look after me! We chattered till midnight, the

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: brunette kept on telling the most awfully funny stories, and the sailor

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: kept on singing. My chest began to ache from laughing. And when the

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: sailor--oh, those sailors!--when he got to know my name was TATIANA, you

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: know what he sang? [Sings in a bass voice] “Onegin don’t let me conceal

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: it, I love Tatiana madly!” [Note: From the Opera _Evgeni Onegin_--words

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: by Pushkin.] [Roars with laughter.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Tania, dear, you’re disturbing Kusma Nicolaievitch. Go home,

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: dear.... Later on....

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: No, no, let him hear if he wants to, it’s awfully

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: interesting. I’ll end in a minute. Serezha came to meet me at the

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: station. Some young man or other turns up, an inspector of taxes, I

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: think... quite handsome, especially his eyes.... Serezha introduced me,

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: and the three of us rode off together.... It was lovely weather....

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Enter MERCHUTKINA, waving her arms about.]

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: What are you dragging at me for. What else! I want him

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: himself! [To SHIPUCHIN] I have the honour, your excellency... I am the

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: wife of a civil servant, Nastasya Fyodorovna Merchutkina.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: What do you want?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Well, you see, your excellency, my husband has been ill for

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: five months, and while he was at home, getting better, he was suddenly

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: dismissed for no reason, your excellency, and when I went to get his

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: salary, they, you see, deducted 24 roubles 36 copecks from it. What for?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: I ask. They said, “Well, he drew it from the employees’ account, and the

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: others had to make it up.” How can that be? How could he draw anything

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: without my permission? No, your excellency! I’m a poor woman... my

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: lodgers are all I have to live on.... I’m weak and defenceless....

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Everybody does me some harm, and nobody has a kind word for me.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Excuse me. [Takes a petition from her and reads it standing.]

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [To KHIRIN] Yes, but first we.... Last week I

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: suddenly received a letter from my mother. She writes that a certain

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Grendilevsky has proposed to my sister Katya. A nice, modest, young

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: man, but with no means of his own, and no assured position. And,

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: unfortunately, just think of it, Katya is absolutely gone on him.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: What’s to be done? Mamma writes telling me to come at once and influence

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Katya....

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Angrily] Excuse me, you’ve made me lose my place! You go

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: talking about your mamma and Katya, and I understand nothing; and I’ve

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: lost my place.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: What does that matter? You listen when a lady is

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: talking to you! Why are you so angry to-day? Are you in love? [Laughs.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [To MERCHUTKINA] Excuse me, but what is this? I can’t make

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: head or tail of it.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Are you in love? Aha! You’re blushing!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [To his wife] Tanya, dear, do go out into the public office

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: for a moment. I shan’t be long.

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: All right. [Goes out.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: I don’t understand anything of this. You’ve obviously come

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: to the wrong place, madam. Your petition doesn’t concern us at all. You

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: should go to the department in which your husband was employed.

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: I’ve been there a good many times these five months, and

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: they wouldn’t even look at my petition. I’d given up all hopes, but,

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: thanks to my son-in-law, Boris Matveyitch, I thought of coming to

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: you. “You go, mother,” he says, “and apply to Mr. Shipuchin, he’s an

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: influential man and can do anything.” Help me, your excellency!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: We can’t do anything for you, Mrs. Merchutkina. You must

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: understand that your husband, so far as I can gather, was in the employ

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: of the Army Medical Department, while this is a private, commercial

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: concern, a bank. Don’t you understand that?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency, I can produce a doctor’s certificate of my

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: husband’s illness. Here it is, just look at it....

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Irritated] That’s all right; I quite believe you, but it’s

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: not our business. [Behind the scene, TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA’S laughter is

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: heard, then a man’s. SHIPUCHIN glances at the door] She’s disturbing

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: the employees. [To MERCHUTKINA] It’s strange and it’s even silly. Surely

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: your husband knows where you ought to apply?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency, I don’t let him know anything. He just

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: cried out: “It isn’t your business! Get out of this!” And...

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Madam, I repeat, your husband was in the employ of the Army

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Medical Department, and this is a bank, a private, commercial concern.

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Yes, yes, yes.... I understand, my dear. In that case, your

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: excellency, just order them to pay me 15 roubles! I don’t mind taking

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: that to be going on with.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Sighs] Ouf!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Andrey Andreyevitch, I’ll never finish the report at this rate!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: One moment. [To MERCHUTKINA] I can’t get any sense out of

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: you. But do understand that your taking this business here is as absurd

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: as if you took a divorce petition to a chemist’s or into a gold assay

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: office. [Knock at the door. The voice of TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA is heard,

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: “Can I come in, Andrey?” SHIPUCHIN shouts] Just wait one minute, dear!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: As it happens, madam, this is an anniversary to-day, we’re busy... and

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: somebody may be coming here at any moment.... Excuse me....

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency, have pity on me, an orphan! I’m a weak,

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: defenceless woman.... I’m tired to death.... I’m having trouble with my

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: lodgers, and on account of my husband, and I’ve got the house to look

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: after, and my son-in-law is out of work....

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Mrs. Merchutkina, I... No, excuse me, I can’t talk to you! My

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: head’s even in a whirl.... You are disturbing us and making us waste

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: our time. [Sighs, aside] What a business, as my name’s Shipuchin!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Merchutkina. [Waves his hand and goes out into public department.]

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Approaching MERCHUTKINA, angrily] What do you want?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: I’m a weak, defenceless woman.... I may look all right, but

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: if you were to take me to pieces you wouldn’t find a single healthy bit

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: in me! I can hardly stand on my legs, and I’ve lost my appetite. I drank

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: my coffee to-day and got no pleasure out of it.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I ask you, what do you want?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Tell them, my dear, to give me 15 roubles, and a month

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: later will do for the rest.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: But haven’t you been told perfectly plainly that this is a bank!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Yes, yes.... And if you like I can show you the doctor’s

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: certificate.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Have you got a head on your shoulders, or what?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: My dear, I’m asking for what’s mine by law. I don’t want

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: what isn’t mine.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I ask you, madam, have you got a head on your shoulders, or

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: what? Well, devil take me, I haven’t any time to talk to you! I’m

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: busy.... [Points to the door] That way, please!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: [Surprised] And where’s the money?

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: You haven’t a head, but this [Taps the table and then points to

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: his forehead.]

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: [Offended] What? Well, never mind, never mind.... You can

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: do that to your own wife, but I’m the wife of a civil servant.... You

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: can’t do that to me!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Losing his temper] Get out of this!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: No, no, no... none of that!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: If you don’t get out this second, I’ll call for the hall-porter!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Get out! [Stamping.]

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Never mind, never mind! I’m not afraid! I’ve seen the like

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: of you before! Miser!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I don’t think I’ve ever seen a more awful woman in my life....

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Ouf! It’s given me a headache.... [Breathing heavily] I tell you once

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: more... do you hear me? If you don’t get out of this, you old devil,

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: I’ll grind you into powder! I’ve got such a character that I’m perfectly

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: capable of laming you for life! I can commit a crime!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: I’ve heard barking dogs before. I’m not afraid. I’ve seen

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: the like of you before.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [In despair] I can’t stand it! I’m ill! I can’t! [Sits down at

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: his desk] They’ve let the Bank get filled with women, and I can’t finish

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: my report! I can’t.

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: I don’t want anybody else’s money, but my own, according to

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: law. You ought to be ashamed of yourself! Sitting in a government office

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: in felt boots....

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Following her husband] We spent the evening at the

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Berezhnitskys. Katya was wearing a sky-blue frock of foulard silk, cut

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: low at the neck.... She looks very well with her hair done over her

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: head, and I did her hair myself.... She was perfectly fascinating....

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Who has had enough of it already] Yes, yes...

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: fascinating.... They may be here any moment....

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Dully] What else? What do you want?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency! [Points to KHIRIN] This man... this man

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: tapped the table with his finger, and then his head.... You told him to

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: look after my affair, but he insults me and says all sorts of things.

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: I’m a weak, defenceless woman....

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: All right, madam, I’ll see to it... and take the necessary

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: steps.... Go away now... later on! [Aside] My gout’s coming on!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [In a low tone to SHIPUCHIN] Andrey Andreyevitch, send for the

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: hall-porter and have her turned out neck and crop! What else can we do?

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Frightened] No, no! She’ll kick up a row and we aren’t the

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: only people in the building.

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency.

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [In a tearful voice] But I’ve got to finish my report! I won’t

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: have time! I won’t!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency, when shall I have the money? I want it

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: now.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Aside, in dismay] A re-mark-ab-ly beastly woman! [Politely]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Madam, I’ve already told you, this is a bank, a private, commercial

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: concern.

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Be a father to me, your excellency.... If the doctor’s

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: certificate isn’t enough, I can get you another from the police. Tell

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: them to give me the money!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Panting] Ouf!

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [To MERCHUTKINA] Mother, haven’t you already been

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: told that you’re disturbing them? What right have you?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Mother, beautiful one, nobody will help me. All I do is to

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: eat and drink, and just now I didn’t enjoy my coffee at all.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Exhausted] How much do you want?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: 24 roubles 36 copecks.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: All right! [Takes a 25-rouble note out of his pocket-book and

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: gives it to her] Here are 25 roubles. Take it and... go!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: I thank you very humbly, your excellency. [Hides the

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: money.]

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Sits by her husband] It’s time I went home....

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: and go away.... What a time we had! Yes, what a time! We went to spend

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: the evening at the Berezhnitskys.... It was all right, quite fun, but

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: nothing in particular.... Katya’s devoted Grendilevsky was there, of

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: course.... Well, I talked to Katya, cried, and induced her to talk to

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: Grendilevsky and refuse him. Well, I thought, everything’s, settled

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: the best possible way; I’ve quieted mamma down, saved Katya, and can

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: be quiet myself.... What do you think? Katya and I were going along the

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: avenue, just before supper, and suddenly... [Excitedly] And suddenly

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: we heard a shot.... No, I can’t talk about it calmly! [Waves her

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: handkerchief] No, I can’t!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Sighs] Ouf!

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Weeps] We ran to the summer-house, and there...

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: there poor Grendilevsky was lying... with a pistol in his hand....

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: No, I can’t stand this! I can’t stand it! [To MERCHUTKINA]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: What else do you want?

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency, can’t my husband go back to his job?

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Weeping] He’d shot himself right in the heart...

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: here.... And the poor man had fallen down senseless.... And he was

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: awfully frightened, as he lay there... and asked for a doctor. A doctor

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: came soon... and saved the unhappy man....

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Your excellency, can’t my husband go back to his job?

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: No, I can’t stand this! [Weeps] I can’t stand it! [Stretches

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: out both his hands in despair to KHIRIN] Drive her away! Drive her away,

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: I implore you!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Goes up to TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA] Get out of this!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Not her, but this one... this awful woman.... [Points] That

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: one!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Not understanding, to TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA] Get out of this!

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: What? What are you doing? Have you taken leave of

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: your senses?

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: It’s awful? I’m a miserable man! Drive her out! Out with her!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [To TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA] Out of it! I’ll cripple you! I’ll knock

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: you out of shape! I’ll break the law!

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Running from him; he chases her] How dare you! You

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: impudent fellow! [Shouts] Andrey! Help! Andrey! [Screams.]

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Chasing them] Stop! I implore you! Not such a noise? Have

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: pity on me!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Chasing MERCHUTKINA] Out of this! Catch her! Hit her! Cut her

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: into pieces!

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: [Shouts] Stop! I ask you! I implore you!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Little fathers... little fathers! [Screams] Little

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: fathers!...

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Shouts] Help! Help!... Oh, oh... I’m sick, I’m

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: sick! [Jumps on to a chair, then falls on to the sofa and groans as if

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: in a faint.]

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Chasing MERCHUTKINA] Hit her! Beat her! Cut her to pieces!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: Oh, oh... little fathers, it’s all dark before me! Ah!

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: a VOICE announces THE DEPUTATION] The deputation... reputation...

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: occupation...

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: [Stamps] Get out of it, devil take me! [Turns up his sleeves]

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: Give her to me: I may break the law!

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: the velvet-covered address, another, the loving-cup. Employees look in

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: at the door, from the public department. TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA on the sofa,

SPEAKER: KHIRIN
TEXT: and MERCHUTKINA in SHIPUCHIN’S arms are both groaning.]

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: [Reads aloud] “Deeply respected and dear Andrey

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: Andreyevitch! Throwing a retrospective glance at the past history of

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: our financial administration, and reviewing in our minds its gradual

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: development, we receive an extremely satisfactory impression. It is true

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: that in the first period of its existence, the inconsiderable amount of

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: its capital, and the absence of serious operations of any description,

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: and also the indefinite aims of this bank, made us attach an extreme

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: importance to the question raised by Hamlet, ‘To be or not to be,’

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: and at one time there were even voices to be heard demanding our

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: liquidation. But at that moment you become the head of our concern.

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: Your knowledge, energies, and your native tact were the causes of

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: extraordinary success and widespread extension. The reputation of the

SPEAKER: ONE OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: bank... [Coughs] reputation of the bank...”

SPEAKER: MERCHUTKINA
TEXT: [Groans] Oh! Oh!

SPEAKER: TATIANA ALEXEYEVNA
TEXT: [Groans] Water! Water!

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: [Continues] The reputation [Coughs]... the

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: reputation of the bank has been raised by you to such a height that we

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: are now the rivals of the best foreign concerns.

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: Deputation... reputation... occupation.... Two friends that

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: had a walk at night, held converse by the pale moonlight.... Oh tell me

SPEAKER: SHIPUCHIN
TEXT: not, that youth is vain, that jealousy has turned my brain.

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: [Continues in confusion] “Then, throwing

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: an objective glance at the present condition of things, we, deeply

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: respected and dear Andrey Andreyevitch... [Lowering his voice] In that

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: case, we’ll do it later on.... Yes, later on....” [DEPUTATION goes out

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: in confusion.]

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: THE THREE SISTERS

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION

TEXT: ALEXEY PETROVITCH FEDOTIK, sub-lieutenant
