SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: ACT I

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: large dining-room. It is midday, the sun is shining brightly outside. In

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: the dining-room the table is being laid for lunch.]

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: school, is walking about correcting exercise books; MASHA, in a black

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: dress, with a hat on her knees, sits and reads a book; IRINA, in white,

SPEAKER: THE MEMBER OF THE DEPUTATION
TEXT: stands about, with a thoughtful expression.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: It’s just a year since father died last May the fifth, on your

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: name-day, Irina. It was very cold then, and snowing. I thought I would

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: never survive it, and you were in a dead faint. And now a year has

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: gone by and we are already thinking about it without pain, and you are

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: wearing a white dress and your face is happy. [Clock strikes twelve] And

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: the clock struck just the same way then. [Pause] I remember that there

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: was music at the funeral, and they fired a volley in the cemetery. He

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: was a general in command of a brigade but there were few people present.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Of course, it was raining then, raining hard, and snowing.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Why think about it!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: dining-room, behind the pillars.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: It’s so warm to-day that we can keep the windows open, though the

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: birches are not yet in flower. Father was put in command of a brigade,

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: and he rode out of Moscow with us eleven years ago. I remember perfectly

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: that it was early in May and that everything in Moscow was flowering

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: then. It was warm too, everything was bathed in sunshine. Eleven years

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: have gone, and I remember everything as if we rode out only yesterday.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Oh, God! When I awoke this morning and saw all the light and the spring,

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: joy entered my heart, and I longed passionately to go home.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Will you take a bet on it?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Oh, nonsense.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Don’t whistle, Masha. How can you! [Pause] I’m always having

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: headaches from having to go to the High School every day and then teach

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: till evening. Strange thoughts come to me, as if I were already an old

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: woman. And really, during these four years that I have been working

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: here, I have been feeling as if every day my strength and youth have

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: been squeezed out of me, drop by drop. And only one desire grows and

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: gains in strength...

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: To go away to Moscow. To sell the house, drop everything here,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: and go to Moscow...

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Yes! To Moscow, and as soon as possible.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I expect Andrey will become a professor, but still, he won’t want

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: to live here. Only poor Masha must go on living here.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Masha can come to Moscow every year, for the whole summer.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Everything will be arranged, please God. [Looks out of the

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: window] It’s nice out to-day. I don’t know why I’m so happy: I

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: remembered this morning that it was my name-day, and I suddenly felt

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: glad and remembered my childhood, when mother was still with us. What

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: beautiful thoughts I had, what thoughts!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: You’re all radiance to-day, I’ve never seen you look so lovely.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: And Masha is pretty, too. Andrey wouldn’t be bad-looking, if he wasn’t

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: so stout; it does spoil his appearance. But I’ve grown old and very

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: thin, I suppose it’s because I get angry with the girls at school.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: To-day I’m free. I’m at home. I haven’t got a headache, and I feel

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: younger than I was yesterday. I’m only twenty-eight.... All’s well, God

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: is everywhere, but it seems to me that if only I were married and could

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: stay at home all day, it would be even better. [Pause] I should love my

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: husband.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [To SOLENI] I’m tired of listening to the rot you talk.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: lieutenant-colonel of artillery, is coming to see us to-day. [Sits down

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: to the piano.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: That’s good. I’m glad.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Is he old?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Oh, no. Forty or forty-five, at the very outside. [Plays

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: softly] He seems rather a good sort. He’s certainly no fool, only he

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: likes to hear himself speak.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Is he interesting?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Oh, he’s all right, but there’s his wife, his mother-in-law,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: and two daughters. This is his second wife. He pays calls and tells

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: everybody that he’s got a wife and two daughters. He’ll tell you so

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: here. The wife isn’t all there, she does her hair like a flapper and

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: gushes extremely. She talks philosophy and tries to commit suicide every

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: now and again, apparently in order to annoy her husband. I should have

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: left her long ago, but he bears up patiently, and just grumbles.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: [Enters with CHEBUTIKIN from the dining-room] With one hand I

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: can only lift fifty-four pounds, but with both hands I can lift 180,

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: or even 200 pounds. From this I conclude that two men are not twice as

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: strong as one, but three times, perhaps even more....

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Reads a newspaper as he walks] If your hair is coming

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: out... take an ounce of naphthaline and hail a bottle of spirit...

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: dissolve and use daily.... [Makes a note in his pocket diary] When

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: found make a note of! Not that I want it though.... [Crosses it out] It

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: doesn’t matter.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Ivan Romanovitch, dear Ivan Romanovitch!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: What does my own little girl want?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Ivan Romanovitch, dear Ivan Romanovitch! I feel as if I were

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: sailing under the broad blue sky with great white birds around me. Why

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: is that? Why?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Kisses her hands, tenderly] My white bird....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: When I woke up to-day and got up and dressed myself, I suddenly

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: began to feel as if everything in this life was open to me, and that I

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: knew how I must live. Dear Ivan Romanovitch, I know everything. A man

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: must work, toil in the sweat of his brow, whoever he may be, for that is

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: the meaning and object of his life, his happiness, his enthusiasm. How

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: fine it is to be a workman who gets up at daybreak and breaks stones in

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: the street, or a shepherd, or a schoolmaster, who teaches children, or

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: an engine-driver on the railway.... My God, let alone a man, it’s better

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: to be an ox, or just a horse, so long as it can work, than a young woman

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: who wakes up at twelve o’clock, has her coffee in bed, and then spends

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: two hours dressing.... Oh it’s awful! Sometimes when it’s hot, your

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: thirst can be just as tiresome as my need for work. And if I don’t get

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: up early in future and work, Ivan Romanovitch, then you may refuse me

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: your friendship.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Tenderly] I’ll refuse, I’ll refuse....

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Father used to make us get up at seven. Now Irina wakes at seven

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: and lies and meditates about something till nine at least. And she looks

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: so serious! [Laughs.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: You’re so used to seeing me as a little girl that it seems queer

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: to you when my face is serious. I’m twenty!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: How well I can understand that craving for work, oh God! I’ve

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: never worked once in my life. I was born in Petersburg, a chilly, lazy

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: place, in a family which never knew what work or worry meant. I remember

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: that when I used to come home from my regiment, a footman used to

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: have to pull off my boots while I fidgeted and my mother looked on in

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: adoration and wondered why other people didn’t see me in the same light.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: They shielded me from work; but only just in time! A new age is dawning,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: the people are marching on us all, a powerful, health-giving storm is

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: gathering, it is drawing near, soon it will be upon us and it will drive

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: away laziness, indifference, the prejudice against labour, and rotten

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: dullness from our society. I shall work, and in twenty-five or thirty

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: years, every man will have to work. Every one!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: I shan’t work.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: You don’t matter.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: In twenty-five years’ time, we shall all be dead, thank the

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Lord. In two or three years’ time apoplexy will carry you off, or else

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: I’ll blow your brains out, my pet. [Takes a scent-bottle out of his

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: pocket and sprinkles his chest and hands.]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Laughs] It’s quite true, I never have worked. After I came

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: down from the university I never stirred a finger or opened a book, I

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: just read the papers.... [Takes another newspaper out of his pocket]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Here we are.... I’ve learnt from the papers that there used to be one,

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Dobrolubov [Note: Dobroluboy (1836-81), in spite of the shortness of his

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: career, established himself as one of the classic literary critics

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: of Russia], for instance, but what he wrote--I don’t know... God only

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: knows.... [Somebody is heard tapping on the floor from below] There....

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: They’re calling me downstairs, somebody’s come to see me. I’ll be back

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: in a minute... won’t be long.... [Exit hurriedly, scratching his beard.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: He’s up to something.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Yes, he looked so pleased as he went out that I’m pretty

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: certain he’ll bring you a present in a moment.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: How unpleasant!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Yes, it’s awful. He’s always doing silly things.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: “There stands a green oak by the sea.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: And a chain of bright gold is around it...

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: And a chain of bright gold is around it....”

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: You’re not very bright to-day, Masha. [MASHA sings, putting on her

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: hat] Where are you off to?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Home.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: That’s odd....

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: On a name-day, too!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: It doesn’t matter. I’ll come in the evening. Good-bye, dear.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: old days when father was alive, every time we had a name-day, thirty or

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: forty officers used to come, and there was lots of noise and fun, and

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: to-day there’s only a man and a half, and it’s as quiet as a desert...

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I’m off... I’ve got the hump to-day, and am not at all cheerful, so

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: don’t you mind me. [Laughs through her tears] We’ll have a talk later

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: on, but good-bye for the present, my dear; I’ll go somewhere.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Displeased] You are queer....

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: [Crying] I understand you, Masha.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: When a man talks philosophy, well, it is philosophy or at any

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: rate sophistry; but when a woman, or two women, talk philosophy--it’s

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: all my eye.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: What do you mean by that, you very awful man?

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Oh, nothing. You came down on me before I could say... help!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Angrily, to OLGA] Don’t cry!

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: This way, my dear. Come in, your feet are clean. [To IRINA] From

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: the District Council, from Mihail Ivanitch Protopopov... a cake.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Thank you. Please thank him. [Takes the cake.]

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: What?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Louder] Please thank him.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Give him a pie, nurse. Ferapont, go, she’ll give you a pie.

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: What?

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: Come on, gran’fer, Ferapont Spiridonitch. Come on. [Exeunt.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I don’t like this Mihail Potapitch or Ivanitch, Protopopov. We

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: oughtn’t to invite him here.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I never asked him.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: That’s all right.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: a rumble of dissatisfied surprise.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: [Covers her face with her hands] A samovar! That’s awful! [Exit

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: into the dining-room, to the table.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: My dear Ivan Romanovitch, what are you doing!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Laughs] I told you so!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Ivan Romanovitch, you are simply shameless!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: My dear good girl, you are the only thing, and the dearest

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: thing I have in the world. I’ll soon be sixty. I’m an old man, a lonely

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: worthless old man. The only good thing in me is my love for you, and if

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: it hadn’t been for that, I would have been dead long ago.... [To IRINA]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: My dear little girl, I’ve known you since the day of your birth, I’ve

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: carried you in my arms... I loved your dead mother....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: But your presents are so expensive!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Angrily, through his tears] Expensive presents.... You

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: really, are!... [To the orderly] Take the samovar in there.... [Teasing]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Expensive presents!

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: [Enters and crosses stage] My dear, there’s a strange Colonel

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: come! He’s taken off his coat already. Children, he’s coming here. Irina

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: darling, you’ll be a nice and polite little girl, won’t you.... Should

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: have lunched a long time ago.... Oh, Lord.... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: It must be Vershinin. [Enter VERSHININ] Lieutenant-Colonel

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Vershinin!

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [To MASHA and IRINA] I have the honour to introduce myself,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: my name is Vershinin. I am very glad indeed to be able to come at last.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: How you’ve grown! Oh! oh!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Please sit down. We’re very glad you’ve come.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Gaily] I am glad, very glad! But there are three sisters,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: surely. I remember--three little girls. I forget your faces, but your

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: father, Colonel Prosorov, used to have three little girls, I remember

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: that perfectly, I saw them with my own eyes. How time does fly! Oh,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: dear, how it flies!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Alexander Ignateyevitch comes from Moscow.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: From Moscow? Are you from Moscow?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes, that’s so. Your father used to be in charge of a battery

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: there, and I was an officer in the same brigade. [To MASHA] I seem to

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: remember your face a little.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I don’t remember you.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Olga! Olga! [Shouts into the dining-room] Olga! Come along! [OLGA

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: enters from the dining-room] Lieutenant Colonel Vershinin comes from

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Moscow, as it happens.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I take it that you are Olga Sergeyevna, the eldest, and that

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: you are Maria... and you are Irina, the youngest....

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: So you come from Moscow?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes. I went to school in Moscow and began my service there; I

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: was there for a long time until at last I got my battery and moved over

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: here, as you see. I don’t really remember you, I only remember that

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: there used to be three sisters. I remember your father well; I have only

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: to shut my eyes to see him as he was. I used to come to your house in

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Moscow....

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: I used to think I remembered everybody, but...

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: My name is Alexander Ignateyevitch.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Alexander Ignateyevitch, you’ve come from Moscow. That is really

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: quite a surprise!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: We are going to live there, you see.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: We think we may be there this autumn. It’s our native town, we

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: were born there. In Old Basmanni Road.... [They both laugh for joy.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: We’ve unexpectedly met a fellow countryman. [Briskly] I remember:

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Do you remember, Olga, they used to speak at home of a “lovelorn Major.”

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You were only a Lieutenant then, and in love with somebody, but for some

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: reason they always called you a Major for fun.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Laughs] That’s it... the lovelorn Major, that’s got it!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You only wore moustaches then. You have grown older! [Through her

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: tears] You have grown older!

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes, when they used to call me the lovelorn Major, I was

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: young and in love. I’ve grown out of both now.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: But you haven’t a single white hair yet. You’re older, but you’re

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: not yet old.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I’m forty-two, anyway. Have you been away from Moscow long?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Eleven years. What are you crying for, Masha, you little fool....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: It’s all right. And where did you live?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Old Basmanni Road.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Same as we.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Once I used to live in German Street. That was when the Red

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Barracks were my headquarters. There’s an ugly bridge in between, where

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: the water rushes underneath. One gets melancholy when one is alone

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: there. [Pause] Here the river is so wide and fine! It’s a splendid

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: river!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Yes, but it’s so cold. It’s very cold here, and the midges....

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: What are you saying! Here you’ve got such a fine healthy

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Russian climate. You’ve a forest, a river... and birches. Dear, modest

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: birches, I like them more than any other tree. It’s good to live here.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Only it’s odd that the railway station should be thirteen miles away....

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Nobody knows why.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: I know why. [All look at him] Because if it was near it wouldn’t

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: be far off, and if it’s far off, it can’t be near. [An awkward pause.]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Funny man.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Now I know who you are. I remember.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I used to know your mother.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: She was a good woman, rest her soul.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Mother is buried in Moscow.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: At the Novo-Devichi Cemetery.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Do you know, I’m beginning to forget her face. We’ll be forgotten

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: in just the same way.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes, they’ll forget us. It’s our fate, it can’t be helped. A

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: time will come when everything that seems serious, significant, or very

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: important to us will be forgotten, or considered trivial. [Pause] And

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: the curious thing is that we can’t possibly find out what will come to

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: be regarded as great and important, and what will be feeble, or silly.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Didn’t the discoveries of Copernicus, or Columbus, say, seem unnecessary

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: and ludicrous at first, while wasn’t it thought that some rubbish

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: written by a fool, held all the truth? And it may so happen that our

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: present existence, with which we are so satisfied, will in time appear

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: strange, inconvenient, stupid, unclean, perhaps even sinful....

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Who knows? But on the other hand, they may call our life

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: noble and honour its memory. We’ve abolished torture and capital

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: punishment, we live in security, but how much suffering there is still!

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: [In a feeble voice] There, there.... The Baron will go without

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: his dinner if you only let him talk philosophy.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Vassili Vassilevitch, kindly leave me alone. [Changes his

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: chair] You’re very dull, you know.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: [Feebly] There, there, there.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [To VERSHININ] The sufferings we see to-day--there are so

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: many of them!--still indicate a certain moral improvement in society.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes, yes, of course.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: You said just now, Baron, that they may call our life noble;

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: but we are very petty.... [Stands up] See how little I am. [Violin

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: played behind.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: That’s Andrey playing--our brother.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: He’s the learned member of the family. I expect he will be a

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: professor some day. Father was a soldier, but his son chose an academic

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: career for himself.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: That was father’s wish.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: We ragged him to-day. We think he’s a little in love.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: To a local lady. She will probably come here to-day.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You should see the way she dresses! Quite prettily, quite

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: fashionably too, but so badly! Some queer bright yellow skirt with a

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: wretched little fringe and a red bodice. And such a complexion! Andrey

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: isn’t in love. After all he has taste, he’s simply making fun of us. I

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: heard yesterday that she was going to marry Protopopov, the chairman

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: of the Local Council. That would do her nicely.... [At the side door]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Andrey, come here! Just for a minute, dear! [Enter ANDREY.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: My brother, Andrey Sergeyevitch.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: My name is Vershinin.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Mine is Prosorov. [Wipes his perspiring hands] You’ve come to

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: take charge of the battery?

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Just think, Alexander Ignateyevitch comes from Moscow.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: That’s all right. Now my little sisters won’t give you any rest.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I’ve already managed to bore your sisters.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Just look what a nice little photograph frame Andrey gave me

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: to-day. [Shows it] He made it himself.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Looks at the frame and does not know what to say] Yes....

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: It’s a thing that...

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: And he made that frame there, on the piano as well. [Andrey waves

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: his hand and walks away.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: He’s got a degree, and plays the violin, and cuts all sorts of

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: things out of wood, and is really a domestic Admirable Crichton. Don’t

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: go away, Andrey! He’s got into a habit of always going away. Come here!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Come on, come on!

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Please leave me alone.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You are funny. Alexander Ignateyevitch used to be called the

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: lovelorn Major, but he never minded.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Not the least.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I’d like to call you the lovelorn fiddler!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Or the lovelorn professor!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: He’s in love! little Andrey is in love!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Applauds] Bravo, Bravo! Encore! Little Andrey is in love.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Goes up behind ANDREY and takes him round the waist with

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: both arms] Nature only brought us into the world that we should love!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: takes out of his pocket.]

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: That’s enough, quite enough.... [Wipes his face] I couldn’t

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: sleep all night and now I can’t quite find my feet, so to speak. I read

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: until four o’clock, then tried to sleep, but nothing happened. I thought

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: about one thing and another, and then it dawned and the sun crawled into

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: my bedroom. This summer, while I’m here, I want to translate a book from

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: the English....

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Do you read English?

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Yes father, rest his soul, educated us almost violently. It may

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: seem funny and silly, but it’s nevertheless true, that after his death

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: I began to fill out and get rounder, as if my body had had some great

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: pressure taken off it. Thanks to father, my sisters and I know French,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: German, and English, and Irina knows Italian as well. But we paid dearly

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: for it all!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: A knowledge of three languages is an unnecessary luxury in this

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: town. It isn’t even a luxury but a sort of useless extra, like a sixth

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: finger. We know a lot too much.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Well, I say! [Laughs] You know a lot too much! I don’t think

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: there can really be a town so dull and stupid as to have no place for

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: a clever, cultured person. Let us suppose even that among the hundred

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: thousand inhabitants of this backward and uneducated town, there are

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: only three persons like yourself. It stands to reason that you won’t be

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: able to conquer that dark mob around you; little by little as you grow

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: older you will be bound to give way and lose yourselves in this crowd of

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: a hundred thousand human beings; their life will suck you up in itself,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: but still, you won’t disappear having influenced nobody; later on,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: others like you will come, perhaps six of them, then twelve, and so on,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: until at last your sort will be in the majority. In two or three hundred

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: years’ time life on this earth will be unimaginably beautiful and

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: wonderful. Mankind needs such a life, and if it is not ours to-day then

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: we must look ahead for it, wait, think, prepare for it. We must see and

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: know more than our fathers and grandfathers saw and knew. [Laughs] And

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: you complain that you know too much.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Takes off her hat] I’ll stay to lunch.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Sighs] Yes, all that ought to be written down.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: You say that many years later on, life on this earth will

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: be beautiful and wonderful. That’s true. But to share in it now, even

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: though at a distance, we must prepare by work....

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Gets up] Yes. What a lot of flowers you have. [Looks round]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: It’s a beautiful flat. I envy you! I’ve spent my whole life in rooms

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: with two chairs, one sofa, and fires which always smoke. I’ve never had

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: flowers like these in my life.... [Rubs his hands] Well, well!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Yes, we must work. You are probably thinking to yourself:

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: the German lets himself go. But I assure you I’m a Russian, I can’t even

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: speak German. My father belonged to the Orthodox Church.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Walks about the stage] I often wonder: suppose we could

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: begin life over again, knowing what we were doing? Suppose we could use

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: one life, already ended, as a sort of rough draft for another? I think

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: himself, at the very least he would rearrange his manner of life, he

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: a wife and two daughters, my wife’s health is delicate and so on and so

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: no!

TEXT: [Going up to IRINA] Dear sister, allow me to congratulate you

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: the bottom of my heart, good health and all that one can wish for a girl

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: equivalent.] [To IRINA] In this book you will find a list of all those

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: years. _Feci quod potui, faciant meliora potentes_. [Kisses MASHA.]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

TEXT: stand back.... [Steps away.]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: into dining-room] My dear...

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN

SPEAKER: MASHA

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN

SPEAKER: MASHA

SPEAKER: MASHA

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN

SPEAKER: MASHA

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN

SPEAKER: SOLENI

SPEAKER: IRINA

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH

SPEAKER: IRINA

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH

SPEAKER: IRINA

SPEAKER: NATASHA

SPEAKER: NATASHA

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK

TEXT: public-houses, but how I should like to be sitting just now in Tyestov’s

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: place in Moscow, or at the Great Moscow, old fellow!

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: Moscow? That’s where a contractor was once telling that some

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: merchants or other were eating pancakes; one ate forty pancakes and he

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: went and died, he was saying. Either forty or fifty, I forget which.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: In Moscow you can sit in an enormous restaurant where you don’t

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: know anybody and where nobody knows you, and you don’t feel all the same

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: that you’re a stranger. And here you know everybody and everybody knows

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: you, and you’re a stranger... and a lonely stranger.

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: What? And the same contractor was telling--perhaps he was

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: lying--that there was a cable stretching right across Moscow.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: What for?

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: I can’t tell. The contractor said so.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Rubbish. [He reads] Were you ever in Moscow?

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: [After a pause] No. God did not lead me there. [Pause] Shall I

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: go?

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: You may go. Good-bye. [FERAPONT goes] Good-bye. [Reads] You can

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: come to-morrow and fetch these documents.... Go along.... [Pause] He’s

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: gone. [A ring] Yes, yes.... [Stretches himself and slowly goes into his

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: own room.]

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: VERSHININ come in. While they talk, a maidservant lights candles and a

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: lamp.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I don’t know. [Pause] I don’t know. Of course, habit counts for

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: a great deal. After father’s death, for instance, it took us a long time

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: to get used to the absence of orderlies. But, apart from habit, it seems

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: to me in all fairness that, however it may be in other towns, the best

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: and most-educated people are army men.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I’m thirsty. I should like some tea.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Glancing at her watch] They’ll bring some soon. I was given in

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: marriage when I was eighteen, and I was afraid of my husband because

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: he was a teacher and I’d only just left school. He then seemed to me

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: frightfully wise and learned and important. And now, unfortunately, that

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: has changed.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes... yes.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I don’t speak of my husband, I’ve grown used to him, but

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: civilians in general are so often coarse, impolite, uneducated. Their

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: rudeness offends me, it angers me. I suffer when I see that a man isn’t

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: quite sufficiently refined, or delicate, or polite. I simply suffer

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: agonies when I happen to be among schoolmasters, my husband’s

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: colleagues.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes.... It seems to me that civilians and army men are

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: equally interesting, in this town, at any rate. It’s all the same! If

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: you listen to a member of the local intelligentsia, whether to civilian

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: or military, he will tell you that he’s sick of his wife, sick of

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: his house, sick of his estate, sick of his horses.... We Russians are

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: extremely gifted in the direction of thinking on an exalted plane, but,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: tell me, why do we aim so low in real life? Why?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Why?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Why is a Russian sick of his children, sick of his wife? And

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: why are his wife and children sick of him?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You’re a little downhearted to-day.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Perhaps I am. I haven’t had any dinner, I’ve had nothing

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: since the morning. My daughter is a little unwell, and when my girls are

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: ill, I get very anxious and my conscience tortures me because they

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: have such a mother. Oh, if you had seen her to-day! What a trivial

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: personality! We began quarrelling at seven in the morning and at nine

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I slammed the door and went out. [Pause] I never speak of her, it’s

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: strange that I bear my complaints to you alone. [Kisses her hand] Don’t

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: be angry with me. I haven’t anybody but you, nobody at all.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: What a noise in the oven. Just before father’s death there was a

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: noise in the pipe, just like that.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Are you superstitious?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: That’s strange. [Kisses her hand] You are a splendid,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: wonderful woman. Splendid, wonderful! It is dark here, but I see your

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: sparkling eyes.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Sits on another chair] There is more light here.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I love you, love you, love you... I love your eyes, your

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: movements, I dream of them.... Splendid, wonderful woman!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Laughing] When you talk to me like that, I laugh; I don’t know

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: why, for I’m afraid. Don’t repeat it, please.... [In an undertone] No,

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: go on, it’s all the same to me.... [Covers her face with her hands]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Somebody’s coming, let’s talk about something else.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: My surname is really triple. I am called Baron

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Tuzenbach-Krone-Altschauer, but I am Russian and Orthodox, the same as

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: you. There is very little German left in me, unless perhaps it is the

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: patience and the obstinacy with which I bore you. I see you home every

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: night.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: How tired I am!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: And I’ll come to the telegraph office to see you home every

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: day for ten or twenty years, until you drive me away. [He sees MASHA and

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: VERSHININ; joyfully] Is that you? How do you do.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Well, I am home at last. [To MASHA] A lady came to-day to

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: telegraph to her brother in Saratov that her son died to-day, and she

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: couldn’t remember the address anyhow. So she sent the telegram without

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: an address, just to Saratov. She was crying. And for some reason or

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: other I was rude to her. “I’ve no time,” I said. It was so stupid. Are

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: the entertainers coming to-night?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Sitting down in an armchair] I want a rest. I am tired.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Smiling] When you come home from your work you seem so

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: young, and so unfortunate.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I am tired. No, I don’t like the telegraph office, I don’t like

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: it.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You’ve grown thinner.... [Whistles a little] And you look

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: younger, and your face has become like a boy’s.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: That’s the way she does her hair.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I must find another job, this one won’t do for me. What I wanted,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: what I hoped to get, just that is lacking here. Labour without poetry,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: without ideas.... [A knock on the floor] The doctor is knocking. [To

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: TUZENBACH] Will you knock, dear. I can’t... I’m tired.... [TUZENBACH

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: knocks] He’ll come in a minute. Something ought to be done. Yesterday

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: the doctor and Andrey played cards at the club and lost money. Andrey

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: seems to have lost 200 roubles.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [With indifference] What can we do now?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: He lost money a fortnight ago, he lost money in December. Perhaps

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: if he lost everything we should go away from this town. Oh, my God, I

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: dream of Moscow every night. I’m just like a lunatic. [Laughs] We go

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: there in June, and before June there’s still... February, March, April,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: May... nearly half a year!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Only Natasha mustn’t get to know of these losses.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I expect it will be all the same to her.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: dinner--comes into the dining-room and combs his beard. He then sits by

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: the table and takes a newspaper from his pocket.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Here he is.... Has he paid his rent?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Laughs] No. He’s been here eight months and hasn’t paid a

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: copeck. Seems to have forgotten.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Laughs] What dignity in his pose! [They all laugh. A pause.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Why are you so silent, Alexander Ignateyevitch?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I don’t know. I want some tea. Half my life for a tumbler of

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: tea: I haven’t had anything since morning.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Irina Sergeyevna!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: What is it?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Please come here, Venez ici. [IRINA goes and sits by the

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: table] I can’t do without you. [IRINA begins to play patience.]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Well, if we can’t have any tea, let’s philosophize, at any

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: rate.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Yes, let’s. About what?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: About what? Let us meditate... about life as it will be after

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: our time; for example, in two or three hundred years.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Well? After our time people will fly about in balloons, the

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: cut of one’s coat will change, perhaps they’ll discover a sixth sense

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: and develop it, but life will remain the same, laborious, mysterious,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: and happy. And in a thousand years’ time, people will still be sighing:

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: “Life is hard!”--and at the same time they’ll be just as afraid of

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: death, and unwilling to meet it, as we are.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Thoughtfully] How can I put it? It seems to me that

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: everything on earth must change, little by little, and is already

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: changing under our very eyes. After two or three hundred years, after

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: a thousand--the actual time doesn’t matter--a new and happy age will

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: begin. We, of course, shall not take part in it, but we live and work

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: and even suffer to-day that it should come. We create it--and in that

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: one object is our destiny and, if you like, our happiness.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: What is it?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I don’t know. I’ve been laughing all day, ever since morning.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I finished my education at the same point as you, I have not

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: studied at universities; I read a lot, but I cannot choose my books and

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: perhaps what I read is not at all what I should, but the longer I love,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: the more I want to know. My hair is turning white, I am nearly an old

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: man now, but I know so little, oh, so little! But I think I know the

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: things that matter most, and that are most real. I know them well. And I

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: wish I could make you understand that there is no happiness for us,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: that there should not and cannot be.... We must only work and work, and

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: happiness is only for our distant posterity. [Pause] If not for me, then

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: for the descendants of my descendants.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: strumming on a guitar.]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: According to you, one should not even think about happiness!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: But suppose I am happy!

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Moves his hands and laughs] We do not seem to understand

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: each other. How can I convince you? [MASHA laughs quietly, TUZENBACH

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: continues, pointing at her] Yes, laugh! [To VERSHININ] Not only after

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: two or three centuries, but in a million years, life will still be as it

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: was; life does not change, it remains for ever, following its own laws

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: which do not concern us, or which, at any rate, you will never find out.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Migrant birds, cranes for example, fly and fly, and whatever thoughts,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: high or low, enter their heads, they will still fly and not know why or

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: where. They fly and will continue to fly, whatever philosophers come to

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: life among them; they may philosophize as much as they like, only they

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: will fly....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Still, is there a meaning?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: A meaning.... Now the snow is falling. What meaning? [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: It seems to me that a man must have faith, or must search for a

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: faith, or his life will be empty, empty.... To live and not to know why

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: the cranes fly, why babies are born, why there are stars in the sky....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Either you must know why you live, or everything is trivial, not worth a

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: straw. [A pause.]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Still, I am sorry that my youth has gone.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Gogol says: life in this world is a dull matter, my masters!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: And I say it’s difficult to argue with you, my masters! Hang

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: it all.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Reading] Balzac was married at Berdichev. [IRINA is singing

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: softly] That’s worth making a note of. [He makes a note] Balzac was

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: married at Berdichev. [Goes on reading.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Laying out cards, thoughtfully] Balzac was married at Berdichev.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: The die is cast. I’ve handed in my resignation, Maria

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Sergeyevna.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: So I heard. I don’t see what good it is; I don’t like civilians.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Never mind.... [Gets up] I’m not handsome; what use am I as a

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: soldier? Well, it makes no difference... I shall work. If only just once

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: in my life I could work so that I could come home in the evening,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: fall exhausted on my bed, and go to sleep at once. [Going into the

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: dining-room] Workmen, I suppose, do sleep soundly!

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: [To IRINA] I bought some coloured pencils for you at Pizhikov’s

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: in the Moscow Road, just now. And here is a little knife.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: You have got into the habit of behaving to me as if I am a little

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: girl, but I am grown up. [Takes the pencils and the knife, then, with

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: joy] How lovely!

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: And I bought myself a knife... look at it... one blade,

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: another, a third, an ear-scoop, scissors, nail-cleaners.

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: [Loudly] Doctor, how old are you?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: I? Thirty-two. [Laughter]

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: I’ll show you another kind of patience.... [Lays out cards.]

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: enters and helps by the table; SOLENI arrives and, after greetings, sits

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: by the table.]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: What a wind!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Yes. I’m tired of winter. I’ve already forgotten what summer’s

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: like.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: It’s coming out, I see. We’re going to Moscow.

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: No, it won’t come out. Look, the eight was on the two of

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: spades. [Laughs] That means you won’t go to Moscow.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Reading paper] Tsitsigar. Smallpox is raging here.

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: [Coming up to MASHA] Masha, have some tea, little mother. [To

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: VERSHININ] Please have some, sir... excuse me, but I’ve forgotten your

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: name....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Bring some here, nurse. I shan’t go over there.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Nurse!

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: Coming, coming!

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: [To SOLENI] Children at the breast understand perfectly. I said

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: “Good morning, Bobby; good morning, dear!” And he looked at me in quite

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: an unusual way. You think it’s only the mother in me that is speaking; I

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: assure you that isn’t so! He’s a wonderful child.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: If he was my child I’d roast him on a frying-pan and eat him.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: [Covers her face in her hands] Vulgar, ill-bred man!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: He’s lucky who doesn’t notice whether it’s winter now, or summer.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I think that if I were in Moscow, I shouldn’t mind about the weather.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: A few days ago I was reading the prison diary of a French

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: minister. He had been sentenced on account of the Panama scandal. With

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: what joy, what delight, he speaks of the birds he saw through the prison

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: windows, which he had never noticed while he was a minister. Now, of

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: course, that he is at liberty, he notices birds no more than he did

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: before. When you go to live in Moscow you’ll not notice it, in just

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: the same way. There can be no happiness for us, it only exists in our

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: wishes.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Takes cardboard box from the table] Where are the pastries?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Soleni has eaten them.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: All of them?

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: [Serving tea] There’s a letter for you.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: For me? [Takes the letter] From my daughter. [Reads] Yes, of

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: course... I will go quietly. Excuse me, Maria Sergeyevna. I shan’t have

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: any tea. [Stands up, excited] That eternal story....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: What is it? Is it a secret?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Quietly] My wife has poisoned herself again. I must go. I’ll

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: go out quietly. It’s all awfully unpleasant. [Kisses MASHA’S hand] My

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: dear, my splendid, good woman... I’ll go this way, quietly. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: Where has he gone? And I’d served tea.... What a man.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Angrily] Be quiet! You bother so one can’t have a moment’s

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: peace.... [Goes to the table with her cup] I’m tired of you, old woman!

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: My dear! Why are you offended!

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: ANDREY’S VOICE. Anfisa!

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: [Mocking] Anfisa! He sits there and... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [In the dining-room, by the table angrily] Let me sit down!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: out. Have some tea!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: You are cross, Masha.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: If I am cross, then don’t talk to me. Don’t touch me!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Don’t touch her, don’t touch her....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You’re sixty, but you’re like a boy, always up to some beastly

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: nonsense.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: [Sighs] Dear Masha, why use such expressions? With your

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: beautiful exterior you would be simply fascinating in good society,

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: I tell you so directly, if it wasn’t for your words. _Je vous prie,

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: pardonnez moi, Marie, mais vous avez des manières un peu grossières_.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Restraining his laughter] Give me... give me... there’s some

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: cognac, I think.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: _Il parait, que mon Bobick déjà ne dort pas_, he has awakened.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: He isn’t well to-day. I’ll go to him, excuse me... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Where has Alexander Ignateyevitch gone?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Home. Something extraordinary has happened to his wife again.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Goes to SOLENI with a cognac-flask in his hands] You go on

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: sitting by yourself, thinking of something--goodness knows what. Come

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: and let’s make peace. Let’s have some cognac. [They drink] I expect I’ll

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: have to play the piano all night, some rubbish most likely... well, so

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: be it!

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Why make peace? I haven’t quarrelled with you.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: You always make me feel as if something has taken place

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: between us. You’ve a strange character, you must admit.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: [Declaims] “I am strange, but who is not? Don’t be angry,

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Aleko!”

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: And what has Aleko to do with it? [Pause.]

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: When I’m with one other man I behave just like everybody else,

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: but in company I’m dull and shy and... talk all manner of rubbish. But

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: I’m more honest and more honourable than very, very many people. And I

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: can prove it.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: I often get angry with you, you always fasten on to me

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: in company, but I like you all the same. I’m going to drink my fill

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: to-night, whatever happens. Drink, now!

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Let’s drink. [They drink] I never had anything against you,

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Baron. But my character is like Lermontov’s [In a low voice] I even

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: rather resemble Lermontov, they say.... [Takes a scent-bottle from his

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: pocket, and scents his hands.]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: I’ve sent in my resignation. Basta! I’ve been thinking about

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: it for five years, and at last made up my mind. I shall work.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: [Declaims] “Do not be angry, Aleko... forget, forget, thy dreams

SPEAKER: SOLENI
