TEXT: used to say.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: They keep on asking me to get up a concert in aid of the

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: sufferers.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: As if one could do anything....

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: It might be arranged, if necessary. In my opinion Maria

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Sergeyevna is an excellent pianist.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Yes, excellent!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: She’s forgotten everything. She hasn’t played for three years...

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: or four.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: In this town absolutely nobody understands music, not a soul

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: except myself, but I do understand it, and assure you on my word of

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: honour that Maria Sergeyevna plays excellently, almost with genius.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: You are right, Baron, I’m awfully fond of Masha. She’s very

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: fine.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: To be able to play so admirably and to realize at the same

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: time that nobody, nobody can understand you!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: [Sighs] Yes.... But will it be quite all right for her to take

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: part in a concert? [Pause] You see, I don’t know anything about it.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Perhaps it will even be all to the good. Although I must admit that our

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Director is a good man, a very good man even, a very clever man, still

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: he has such views.... Of course it isn’t his business but still, if you

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: wish it, perhaps I’d better talk to him.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: I got so dirty while the fire was on, I don’t look like

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: anybody on earth. [Pause] Yesterday I happened to hear, casually, that

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: they want to transfer our brigade to some distant place. Some said to

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Poland, others, to Chita.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: I heard so, too. Well, if it is so, the town will be quite

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: empty.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: And we’ll go away, too!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Drops the clock which breaks to pieces] To smithereens!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: [Gathering up the pieces] To smash such a valuable object--oh,

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Ivan Romanovitch, Ivan Romanovitch! A very bad mark for your

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: misbehaviour!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: That clock used to belong to our mother.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Perhaps.... To your mother, your mother. Perhaps I didn’t

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: break it; it only looks as if I broke it. Perhaps we only think that

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: we exist, when really we don’t. I don’t know anything, nobody knows

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: anything. [At the door] What are you looking at? Natasha has a little

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: romance with Protopopov, and you don’t see it.... There you sit and see

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: nothing, and Natasha has a little romance with Protopovov.... [Sings]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Won’t you please accept this date.... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Yes. [Laughs] How strange everything really is! [Pause] When

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: the fire broke out, I hurried off home; when I get there I see the house

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: is whole, uninjured, and in no danger, but my two girls are standing by

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: the door in just their underclothes, their mother isn’t there, the crowd

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: is excited, horses and dogs are running about, and the girls’ faces are

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: so agitated, terrified, beseeching, and I don’t know what else. My heart

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: was pained when I saw those faces. My God, I thought, what these girls

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: will have to put up with if they live long! I caught them up and ran,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: and still kept on thinking the one thing: what they will have to live

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: through in this world! [Fire-alarm; a pause] I come here and find their

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: mother shouting and angry. [MASHA enters with a pillow and sits on

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: the sofa] And when my girls were standing by the door in just their

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: underclothes, and the street was red from the fire, there was a dreadful

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: noise, and I thought that something of the sort used to happen many

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: years ago when an enemy made a sudden attack, and looted, and burned....

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: And at the same time what a difference there really is between the

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: present and the past! And when a little more time has gone by, in two or

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: three hundred years perhaps, people will look at our present life with

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: just the same fear, and the same contempt, and the whole past will seem

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: clumsy and dull, and very uncomfortable, and strange. Oh, indeed, what a

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: life there will be, what a life! [Laughs] Forgive me, I’ve dropped

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: into philosophy again. Please let me continue. I do awfully want to

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: philosophize, it’s just how I feel at present. [Pause] As if they

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: are all asleep. As I was saying: what a life there will be! Only just

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: imagine.... There are only three persons like yourselves in the town

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: just now, but in future generations there will be more and more, and

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: still more, and the time will come when everything will change and

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: become as you would have it, people will live as you do, and then you

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: too will go out of date; people will be born who are better than

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: you.... [Laughs] Yes, to-day I am quite exceptionally in the vein. I am

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: devilishly keen on living.... [Sings.]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: “The power of love all ages know,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: From its assaults great good does grow.” [Laughs.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Trum-tum-tum...

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Tum-tum...

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Tra-ra-ra?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Tra-ta-ta. [Laughs.]

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: [Dancing] I’m burnt out, I’m burnt out! Down to the ground!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I don’t see anything funny about it. Is everything burnt?

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: [Laughs] Absolutely. Nothing left at all. The guitar’s burnt,

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: and the photographs are burnt, and all my correspondence.... And I was

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: going to make you a present of a note-book, and that’s burnt too.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: No, you can’t come here, Vassili Vassilevitch. Please go away.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Why can the Baron come here and I can’t?

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: We really must go. How’s the fire?

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: They say it’s going down. No, I absolutely don’t see why the

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Baron can, and I can’t? [Scents his hands.]

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Trum-tum-tum.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Trum-tum.

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Laughs to SOLENI] Let’s go into the dining-room.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Very well, we’ll make a note of it. “If I should try to make

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: this clear, the geese would be annoyed, I fear.” [Looks at TUZENBACH]

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: There, there, there.... [Goes out with VERSHININ and FEDOTIK.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: How Soleni smelt of tobacco.... [In surprise] The Baron’s asleep!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Baron! Baron!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Waking] I am tired, I must say.... The brickworks....

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: No, I’m not wandering, I mean it; I’m going to start work soon at the

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: brickworks... I’ve already talked it over. [Tenderly, to IRINA] You’re

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: so pale, and beautiful, and charming.... Your paleness seems to shine

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: through the dark air as if it was a light.... You are sad, displeased

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: with life.... Oh, come with me, let’s go and work together!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Nicolai Lvovitch, go away from here.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Laughs] Are you here? I didn’t see you. [Kisses IRINA’S

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: hand] good-bye, I’ll go... I look at you now and I remember, as if it

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: was long ago, your name-day, when you, cheerfully and merrily, were

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: talking about the joys of labour.... And how happy life seemed to me,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: then! What has happened to it now? [Kisses her hand] There are tears in

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: your eyes. Go to bed now; it is already day... the morning begins.... If

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: only I was allowed to give my life for you!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Nicolai Lvovitch, go away! What business...

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: I’m off. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Lies down] Are you asleep, Feodor?

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Eh?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Shouldn’t you go home.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: My dear Masha, my darling Masha....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: She’s tired out. You might let her rest, Fedia.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: I’ll go at once. My wife’s a good, splendid... I love you, my

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: only one....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Angrily] Amo, amas, amat, amamus, amatis, amant.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: [Laughs] No, she really is wonderful. I’ve been your husband

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: seven years, and it seems as if I was only married yesterday. On

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: my word. No, you really are a wonderful woman. I’m satisfied, I’m

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: satisfied, I’m satisfied!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I’m bored, I’m bored, I’m bored.... [Sits up] But I can’t get it

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: out of my head.... It’s simply disgraceful. It has been gnawing away at

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: me... I can’t keep silent. I mean about Andrey.... He has mortgaged this

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: house with the bank, and his wife has got all the money; but the house

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: doesn’t belong to him alone, but to the four of us! He ought to know

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: that, if he’s an honourable man.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: What’s the use, Masha? Andrey is in debt all round; well, let

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: him do as he pleases.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: It’s disgraceful, anyway. [Lies down]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: You and I are not poor. I work, take my classes, give private

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: lessons... I am a plain, honest man... _Omnia mea mecum porto_, as they

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: say.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I don’t want anything, but the unfairness of it disgusts me.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: [Kisses her] You’re tired, just rest for half an hour, and I’ll

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: sit and wait for you. Sleep.... [Going] I’m satisfied, I’m satisfied,

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: I’m satisfied. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Yes, really, our Andrey has grown smaller; how he’s snuffed

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: out and aged with that woman! He used to want to be a professor, and

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: yesterday he was boasting that at last he had been made a member of the

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: district council. He is a member, and Protopopov is chairman.... The

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: whole town talks and laughs about it, and he alone knows and sees

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: nothing.... And now everybody’s gone to look at the fire, but he sits

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: alone in his room and pays no attention, only just plays on his fiddle.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: any longer!... I can’t, I can’t!... [OLGA comes in and clears up at her

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: little table. IRINA is sobbing loudly] Throw me out, throw me out, I

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: can’t bear any more!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: [Alarmed] What is it, what is it? Dear!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Sobbing] Where? Where has everything gone? Where is it all?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Oh my God, my God! I’ve forgotten everything, everything... I don’t

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: remember what is the Italian for window or, well, for ceiling... I

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: forget everything, every day I forget it, and life passes and will never

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: return, and we’ll never go away to Moscow... I see that we’ll never

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Dear, dear....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Controlling herself] Oh, I am unhappy... I can’t work, I shan’t

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: work. Enough, enough! I used to be a telegraphist, now I work at the

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: town council offices, and I have nothing but hate and contempt for all

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: they give me to do... I am already twenty-three, I have already been

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: at work for a long while, and my brain has dried up, and I’ve grown

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: thinner, plainer, older, and there is no relief of any sort, and time

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: goes and it seems all the while as if I am going away from the real, the

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: beautiful life, farther and farther away, down some precipice. I’m in

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: despair and I can’t understand how it is that I am still alive, that I

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: haven’t killed myself.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Don’t cry, dear girl, don’t cry... I suffer, too.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I’m not crying, not crying.... Enough.... Look, I’m not crying

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: any more. Enough... enough!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Dear, I tell you as a sister and a friend if you want my advice,

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: marry the Baron. [IRINA cries softly] You respect him, you think highly

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: of him.... It is true that he is not handsome, but he is so honourable

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: and clean... people don’t marry from love, but in order to do one’s

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: duty. I think so, at any rate, and I’d marry without being in love.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Whoever he was, I should marry him, so long as he was a decent man. Even

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: if he was old....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I was always waiting until we should be settled in Moscow, there

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I should meet my true love; I used to think about him, and love him....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: But it’s all turned out to be nonsense, all nonsense....

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: [Embraces her sister] My dear, beautiful sister, I understand

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: everything; when Baron Nicolai Lvovitch left the army and came to us in

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: evening dress, [Note: I.e. in the correct dress for making a proposal of

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: marriage.] he seemed so bad-looking to me that I even started crying....

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: He asked, “What are you crying for?” How could I tell him! But if God

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: brought him to marry you, I should be happy. That would be different,

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: quite different.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: saying anything.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Sitting up] She walks as if she’s set something on fire.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Masha, you’re silly, you’re the silliest of the family. Please

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: forgive me for saying so. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I want to make a confession, dear sisters. My soul is in pain.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I will confess to you, and never again to anybody... I’ll tell you this

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: minute. [Softly] It’s my secret but you must know everything... I can’t

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: be silent.... [Pause] I love, I love... I love that man.... You saw him

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: only just now.... Why don’t I say it... in one word. I love Vershinin.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: [Goes behind her screen] Stop that, I don’t hear you in any case.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: What am I to do? [Takes her head in her hands] First he seemed

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: queer to me, then I was sorry for him... then I fell in love with

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: him... fell in love with his voice, his words, his misfortunes, his two

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: daughters.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: [Behind the screen] I’m not listening. You may talk any nonsense

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: you like, it will be all the same, I shan’t hear.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Oh, Olga, you are foolish. I am in love--that means that is to be

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: my fate. It means that is to be my lot.... And he loves me.... It is all

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: awful. Yes; it isn’t good, is it? [Takes IRINA’S hand and draws her to

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: her] Oh, my dear.... How are we going to live through our lives, what is

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: to become of us.... When you read a novel it all seems so old and easy,

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: but when you fall in love yourself, then you learn that nobody knows

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: anything, and each must decide for himself.... My dear ones, my

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: sisters... I’ve confessed, now I shall keep silence.... Like the

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: lunatics in Gogol’s story, I’m going to be silent... silent...

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: [Angrily] What do you want? I don’t understand.

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: [At the door, impatiently] I’ve already told you ten times,

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: Andrey Sergeyevitch.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: In the first place I’m not Andrey Sergeyevitch, but sir. [Note:

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Quite literally, “your high honour,” to correspond to Andrey’s rank as a

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: civil servant.]

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: The firemen, sir, ask if they can go across your garden to the

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: river. Else they go right round, right round; it’s a nuisance.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: All right. Tell them it’s all right. [Exit FERAPONT] I’m tired

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: of them. Where is Olga? [OLGA comes out from behind the screen] I came

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: to you for the key of the cupboard. I lost my own. You’ve got a little

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: key. [OLGA gives him the key; IRINA goes behind her screen; pause] What

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: a huge fire! It’s going down now. Hang it all, that Ferapont made me so

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: angry that I talked nonsense to him.... Sir, indeed.... [A pause] Why

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: are you so silent, Olga? [Pause] It’s time you stopped all that nonsense

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: and behaved as if you were properly alive.... You are here, Masha.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Irina is here, well, since we’re all here, let’s come to a complete

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: understanding, once and for all. What have you against me? What is it?

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Please don’t, Audrey dear. We’ll talk to-morrow. [Excited] What an

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: awful night!

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: [Much confused] Don’t excite yourself. I ask you in perfect

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: calmness; what have you against me? Tell me straight.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: VERSHININ’S VOICE. Trum-tum-tum!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Stands; loudly] Tra-ta-ta! [To OLGA] Goodbye, Olga, God bless

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: you. [Goes behind screen and kisses IRINA] Sleep well.... Good-bye,

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Andrey. Go away now, they’re tired... you can explain to-morrow....

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: I’ll only say this and go. Just now.... In the first place,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: you’ve got something against Natasha, my wife; I’ve noticed it since

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: the very day of my marriage. Natasha is a beautiful and honest creature,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: straight and honourable--that’s my opinion. I love and respect my wife;

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: understand it, I respect her, and I insist that others should respect

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: her too. I repeat, she’s an honest and honourable person, and all your

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: disapproval is simply silly... [Pause] In the second place, you seem to

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: be annoyed because I am not a professor, and am not engaged in study.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: But I work for the zemstvo, I am a member of the district council, and

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: I consider my service as worthy and as high as the service of science.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: I am a member of the district council, and I am proud of it, if you want

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: to know. [Pause] In the third place, I have still this to say... that I

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: have mortgaged the house without obtaining your permission.... For that

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: I am to blame, and ask to be forgiven. My debts led me into doing it...

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: thirty-five thousand... I do not play at cards any more, I stopped long

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: ago, but the chief thing I have to say in my defence is that you girls

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: receive a pension, and I don’t... my wages, so to speak.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: [At the door] Is Masha there? [Excitedly] Where is she? It’s

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: queer.... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: They don’t hear. Natasha is a splendid, honest person. [Walks

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: about in silence, then stops] When I married I thought we should be

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: happy... all of us.... But, my God.... [Weeps] My dear, dear sisters,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: don’t believe me, don’t believe me.... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [behind her screen] Olga, who’s knocking on the floor?

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: It’s doctor Ivan Romanovitch. He’s drunk.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: What a restless night! [Pause] Olga! [Looks out] Did you hear?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: They are taking the brigade away from us; it’s going to be transferred

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: to some place far away.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: It’s only a rumour.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Then we shall be left alone.... Olga!

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Well?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: My dear, darling sister, I esteem, I highly value the Baron, he’s

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: a splendid man; I’ll marry him, I’ll consent, only let’s go to Moscow!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I implore you, let’s go! There’s nothing better than Moscow on earth!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Let’s go, Olga, let’s go!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Curtain

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: ACT IV

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: of firs, at the end of which the river can be seen. There is a forest

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: on the far side of the river. On the right is the terrace of the house:

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: bottles and tumblers are on a table here; it is evident that champagne

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: has just been drunk. It is midday. Every now and again passers-by walk

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: across the garden, from the road to the river; five soldiers go past

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: rapidly. CHEBUTIKIN, in a comfortable frame of mind which does not

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: desert him throughout the act, sits in an armchair in the garden,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: waiting to be called. He wears a peaked cap and has a stick. IRINA,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: KULIGIN with a cross hanging from his neck and without his moustaches,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: and TUZENBACH are standing on the terrace seeing off FEDOTIK and RODE,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: who are coming down into the garden; both officers are in service

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: uniform.]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Exchanges kisses with FEDOTIK] You’re a good sort, we got on

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: so well together. [Exchanges kisses with RODE] Once again.... Good-bye,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: old man!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Au revoir!

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: It isn’t au revoir, it’s good-bye; we’ll never meet again!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Who knows! [Wipes his eyes; smiles] Here I’ve started crying!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: We’ll meet again sometime.

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: After ten years--or fifteen? We’ll hardly know one another

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: then; we’ll say, “How do you do?” coldly.... [Takes a snapshot] Keep

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: still.... Once more, for the last time.

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: [Embracing TUZENBACH] We shan’t meet again.... [Kisses IRINA’S

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: hand] Thank you for everything, for everything!

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: [Grieved] Don’t be in such a hurry!

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: We shall meet again, if God wills it. Write to us. Be sure to

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: write.

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: [Looking round the garden] Good-bye, trees! [Shouts] Yo-ho!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Best wishes. Go and get yourselves wives there in Poland....

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Your Polish wife will clasp you and call you “kochanku!” [Note:

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Darling.] [Laughs.]

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: [Looking at the time] There’s less than an hour left. Soleni

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: is the only one of our battery who is going on the barge; the rest of

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: us are going with the main body. Three batteries are leaving to-day,

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: another three to-morrow and then the town will be quiet and peaceful.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: And terribly dull.

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: And where is Maria Sergeyevna?

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Masha is in the garden.

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: We’d like to say good-bye to her.

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: Good-bye, I must go, or else I’ll start weeping.... [Quickly

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: embraces KULIGIN and TUZENBACH, and kisses IRINA’S hand] We’ve been so

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: happy here....

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: [To KULIGIN] Here’s a keepsake for you... a note-book with a

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: pencil.... We’ll go to the river from here.... [They go aside and both

SPEAKER: FEDOTIK
TEXT: look round.]

SPEAKER: RODE
TEXT: [Shouts] Yo-ho!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: [Shouts] Good-bye!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: and go out with her.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: They’ve gone.... [Sits on the bottom step of the terrace.]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: And they forgot to say good-bye to me.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: But why is that?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: I just forgot, somehow. Though I’ll soon see them again, I’m

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: going to-morrow. Yes... just one day left. I shall be retired in a year,

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: then I’ll come here again, and finish my life near you. I’ve only one

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: year before I get my pension.... [Puts one newspaper into his pocket and

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: takes another out] I’ll come here to you and change my life radically...

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: I’ll be so quiet... so agree... agreeable, respectable....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Yes, you ought to change your life, dear man, somehow or other.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Yes, I feel it. [Sings softly.]    “Tarara-boom-deay....”

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: We won’t reform Ivan Romanovitch! We won’t reform him!

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: If only I was apprenticed to you! Then I’d reform.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Feodor has shaved his moustache! I can’t bear to look at him.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Well, what about it?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: I could tell you what your face looks like now, but it

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: wouldn’t be polite.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Well! It’s the custom, it’s modus vivendi. Our Director is

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: clean-shaven, and so I too, when I received my inspectorship, had

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: my moustaches removed. Nobody likes it, but it’s all one to me. I’m

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: satisfied. Whether I’ve got moustaches or not, I’m satisfied.... [Sits.]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: sleeping infant.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Ivan Romanovitch, be a darling. I’m awfully worried. You were out

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: on the boulevard last night; tell me, what happened?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: What happened? Nothing. Quite a trifling matter. [Reads

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: paper] Of no importance!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: They say that Soleni and the Baron met yesterday on the

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: boulevard near the theatre....

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Stop! What right... [Waves his hand and goes into the house.]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Near the theatre... Soleni started behaving offensively to the

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Baron, who lost his temper and said something nasty....

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: I don’t know. It’s all bunkum.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: At some seminary or other a master wrote “bunkum” on an essay,

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: and the student couldn’t make the letters out--thought it was a Latin

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: word “luckum.” [Laughs] Awfully funny, that. They say that Soleni is in

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: love with Irina and hates the Baron.... That’s quite natural. Irina is

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: a very nice girl. She’s even like Masha, she’s so thoughtful.... Only,

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Irina your character is gentler. Though Masha’s character, too, is a

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: very good one. I’m very fond of Masha. [Shouts of “Yo-ho!” are heard

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: behind the stage.]

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Shudders] Everything seems to frighten me today. [Pause] I’ve

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: got everything ready, and I send my things off after dinner. The

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Baron and I will be married to-morrow, and to-morrow we go away to

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: the brickworks, and the next day I go to the school, and the new life

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: begins. God will help me! When I took my examination for the teacher’s

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: post, I actually wept for joy and gratitude.... [Pause] The cart will be

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: here in a minute for my things....

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Somehow or other, all this doesn’t seem at all serious. As if

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: it was all ideas, and nothing really serious. Still, with all my soul I

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: wish you happiness.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [With deep feeling] My splendid... my dear, precious

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: girl.... You’ve gone on far ahead, I won’t catch up with you. I’m left

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: behind like a migrant bird grown old, and unable to fly. Fly, my

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: dear, fly, and God be with you! [Pause] It’s a pity you shaved your

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: moustaches, Feodor Ilitch.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Oh, drop it! [Sighs] To-day the soldiers will be gone, and

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: everything will go on as in the old days. Say what you will, Masha is

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: a good, honest woman. I love her very much, and thank my fate for her.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: People have such different fates. There’s a Kosirev who works in the

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: excise department here. He was at school with me; he was expelled

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: from the fifth class of the High School for being entirely unable to

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: understand _ut consecutivum_. He’s awfully hard up now and in very

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: poor health, and when I meet him I say to him, “How do you do, _ut

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: consecutivum_.” “Yes,” he says, “precisely _consecutivum_...” and

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: coughs. But I’ve been successful all my life, I’m happy, and I even have

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: a Stanislaus Cross, of the second class, and now I myself teach others

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: that _ut consecutivum_. Of course, I’m a clever man, much cleverer than

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: many, but happiness doesn’t only lie in that....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: To-morrow night I shan’t hear that “Maiden’s Prayer” any more,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: and I shan’t be meeting Protopopov.... [Pause] Protopopov is sitting

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: there in the drawing-room; and he came to-day...

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: Hasn’t the head-mistress come yet?

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: No. She has been sent for. If you only knew how difficult it is

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: for me to live alone, without Olga.... She lives at the High School;

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: she, a head-mistress, busy all day with her affairs and I’m alone,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: bored, with nothing to do, and hate the room I live in.... I’ve made

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: up my mind: if I can’t live in Moscow, then it must come to this. It’s

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: fate. It can’t be helped. It’s all the will of God, that’s the truth.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Nicolai Lvovitch made me a proposal.... Well? I thought it over and made

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: up my mind. He’s a good man... it’s quite remarkable how good he is....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: And suddenly my soul put out wings, I became happy, and light-hearted,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: and once again the desire for work, work, came over me.... Only

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: something happened yesterday, some secret dread has been hanging over

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Luckum. Rubbish.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: [At the window] The head-mistress.

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: The head-mistress has come. Let’s go. [Exit with IRINA into the

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: house.]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: “It is my washing day.... Tara-ra... boom-deay.”

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Here you are, sitting here, doing nothing.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: What then?

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Sits] Nothing.... [Pause] Did you love my mother?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Very much.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: And did she love you?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [After a pause] I don’t remember that.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Is my man here? When our cook Martha used to ask about her

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: gendarme, she used to say my man. Is he here?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Not yet.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: When you take your happiness in little bits, in snatches, and

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: then lose it, as I have done, you gradually get coarser, more bitter.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: perambulator] There’s our brother Andrey.... All our hopes in him have

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: gone. There was once a great bell, a thousand persons were hoisting it,

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: much money and labour had been spent on it, when it suddenly fell

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: and was broken. Suddenly, for no particular reason.... Andrey is like

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: that....

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: When are they going to stop making such a noise in the house?

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: It’s awful.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: They won’t be much longer. [Looks at his watch] My watch is

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: very old-fashioned, it strikes the hours.... [Winds the watch and makes

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: it strike] The first, second, and fifth batteries are to leave at one

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: o’clock precisely. [Pause] And I go to-morrow.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: For good?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: I don’t know. Perhaps I’ll return in a year. The devil

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: only knows... it’s all one.... [Somewhere a harp and violin are being

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: played.]

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: The town will grow empty. It will be as if they put a cover over

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: it. [Pause] Something happened yesterday by the theatre. The whole town

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: knows of it, but I don’t.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Nothing. A silly little affair. Soleni started irritating

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: the Baron, who lost his temper and insulted him, and so at last Soleni

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: had to challenge him. [Looks at his watch] It’s about time, I think....

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: At half-past twelve, in the public wood, that one you can see from here

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: across the river.... Piff-paff. [Laughs] Soleni thinks he’s Lermontov,

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: and even writes verses. That’s all very well, but this is his third

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: duel.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Whose?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Soleni’s.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: And the Baron?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: What about the Baron? [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: Everything’s all muddled up in my head.... But I say it ought not

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: to be allowed. He might wound the Baron or even kill him.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: The Baron is a good man, but one Baron more or less--what

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: difference does it make? It’s all the same! [Beyond the garden somebody

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: shouts “Co-ee! Hallo! “] You wait. That’s Skvortsov shouting; one of the

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: seconds. He’s in a boat. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: In my opinion it’s simply immoral to fight in a duel, or to be

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: present, even in the quality of a doctor.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: It only seems so.... We don’t exist, there’s nothing on

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: earth, we don’t really live, it only seems that we live. Does it matter,

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: anyway!

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: You talk and talk the whole day long. [Going] You live in

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: a climate like this, where it might snow any moment, and there you

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: talk.... [Stops] I won’t go into the house, I can’t go there.... Tell me

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: when Vershinin comes.... [Goes along the avenue] The migrant birds are

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: already on the wing.... [Looks up] Swans or geese.... My dear, happy

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: things.... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Our house will be empty. The officers will go away, you are

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: going, my sister is getting married, and I alone will remain in the

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: house.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: And your wife?

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: A wife’s a wife. She’s honest, well-bred, yes; and kind, but

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: with all that there is still something about her that degenerates her

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: into a petty, blind, even in some respects misshapen animal. In any

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: case, she isn’t a man. I tell you as a friend, as the only man to whom I

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: can lay bare my soul. I love Natasha, it’s true, but sometimes she seems

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: extraordinarily vulgar, and then I lose myself and can’t understand why

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: I love her so much, or, at any rate, used to love her....

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Rises] I’m going away to-morrow, old chap, and perhaps

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: we’ll never meet again, so here’s my advice. Put on your cap, take a

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: stick in your hand, go... go on and on, without looking round. And the

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: farther you go, the better.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: sight of CHEBUTIKIN, and turns to him, the officers go on.]

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: Doctor, it’s time. It’s half-past twelve already. [Shakes hands

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: with ANDREY.]

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Half a minute. I’m tired of the lot of you. [To ANDREY] If

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: anybody asks for me, say I’ll be back soon.... [Sighs] Oh, oh, oh!

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: “He didn’t have the time to sigh. The bear sat on him heavily.”

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Stop it!

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: How’s your health?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Angry] Mind your own business.

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: The old man is unnecessarily excited. I won’t go far, I’ll only

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: just bring him down like a snipe. [Takes out his scent-bottle and scents

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: his hands] I’ve poured out a whole bottle of scent to-day and they still

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: smell... of a dead body. [Pause] Yes.... You remember the poem

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: “But he, the rebel seeks the storm,

SPEAKER: SOLENI
TEXT: As if the storm will bring him rest...”?

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: “He didn’t have the time to sigh,

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: The bear sat on him heavily.”

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: Documents to sign....

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: [Irritated]. Go away! Leave me! Please! [Goes away with the

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: perambulator.]

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: That’s what documents are for, to be signed. [Retires to back

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: of stage.]

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: stage, shouting “Co-ee, Masha, co-ee!”]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: He seems to be the only man in the town who is glad that the

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: soldiers are going.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: One can understand that. [Pause] The town will be empty.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: My dear, I shall return soon.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Where are you going?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: I must go into the town and then... see the others off.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: It’s not true... Nicolai, why are you so absentminded to-day?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Making a movement of impatience] In an hour’s time I shall

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: return and be with you again. [Kisses her hands] My darling... [Looking

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: her closely in the face] it’s five years now since I fell in love with

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: you, and still I can’t get used to it, and you seem to me to grow more

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: and more beautiful. What lovely, wonderful hair! What eyes! I’m going to

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: take you away to-morrow. We shall work, we shall be rich, my dreams will

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: come true. You will be happy. There’s only one thing, one thing only:

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: you don’t love me!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: It isn’t in my power! I shall be your wife, I shall be true to

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: you, and obedient to you, but I can’t love you. What can I do! [Cries] I

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: have never been in love in my life. Oh, I used to think so much of love,

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I have been thinking about it for so long by day and by night, but

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: my soul is like an expensive piano which is locked and the key lost.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: I didn’t sleep at night. There is nothing in my life so awful

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: as to be able to frighten me, only that lost key torments my soul and

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: does not let me sleep. Say something to me [Pause] say something to

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: What can I say, what?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Anything.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Don’t! don’t! [Pause.]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: It is curious how silly trivial little things, sometimes

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: for no apparent reason, become significant. At first you laugh at these

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: things, you think they are of no importance, you go on and you feel that

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: you haven’t got the strength to stop yourself. Oh don’t let’s talk about

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: it! I am happy. It is as if for the first time in my life I see these

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: firs, maples, beeches, and they all look at me inquisitively and wait.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: What beautiful trees and how beautiful, when one comes to think of it,

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: life must be near them! [A shout of Co-ee! in the distance] It’s time

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: I went.... There’s a tree which has dried up but it still sways in the

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: breeze with the others. And so it seems to me that if I die, I shall

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: still take part in life in one way or another. Good-bye, dear....

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: the calendar.

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: I am coming with you.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Nervously] No, no! [He goes quickly and stops in the avenue]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Irina!

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: What is it?

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: [Not knowing what to say] I haven’t had any coffee to-day.

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: Tell them to make me some.... [He goes out quickly.]

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: and sits on a swing. ANDREY comes in with the perambulator and FERAPONT

SPEAKER: TUZENBACH
TEXT: also appears.]

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: Andrey Sergeyevitch, it isn’t as if the documents were mine,

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: they are the government’s. I didn’t make them.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: Oh, what has become of my past and where is it? I used to be

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: young, happy, clever, I used to be able to think and frame clever ideas,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: the present and the future seemed to me full of hope. Why do we, almost

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: before we have begun to live, become dull, grey, uninteresting, lazy,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: apathetic, useless, unhappy.... This town has already been in existence

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: for two hundred years and it has a hundred thousand inhabitants, not one

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: of whom is in any way different from the others. There has never been,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: now or at any other time, a single leader of men, a single scholar, an

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: artist, a man of even the slightest eminence who might arouse envy or a

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: passionate desire to be imitated. They only eat, drink, sleep, and then

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: they die... more people are born and also eat, drink, sleep, and so

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: as not to go silly from boredom, they try to make life many-sided

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: with their beastly backbiting, vodka, cards, and litigation. The wives

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: deceive their husbands, and the husbands lie, and pretend they see

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: nothing and hear nothing, and the evil influence irresistibly oppresses

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: the children and the divine spark in them is extinguished, and they

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: become just as pitiful corpses and just as much like one another as

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: their fathers and mothers.... [Angrily to FERAPONT] What do you want?

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: What? Documents want signing.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: I’m tired of you.

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: [Handing him papers] The hall-porter from the law courts was

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: saying just now that in the winter there were two hundred degrees of

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: frost in Petersburg.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: The present is beastly, but when I think of the future, how good

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: it is! I feel so light, so free; there is a light in the distance, I see

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: freedom. I see myself and my children freeing ourselves from vanities,

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: from kvass, from goose baked with cabbage, from after-dinner naps, from

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: base idleness....

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: He was saying that two thousand people were frozen to death.

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: The people were frightened, he said. In Petersburg or Moscow, I don’t

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: remember which.

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: [Overcome by a tender emotion] My dear sisters, my beautiful

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: sisters! [Crying] Masha, my sister....

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: [At the window] Who’s talking so loudly out here? Is that you,

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: Andrey? You’ll wake little Sophie. _Il ne faut pas faire du bruit, la

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: Sophie est dormée deja. Vous êtes un ours._ [Angrily] If you want

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: to talk, then give the perambulator and the baby to somebody else.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: Ferapont, take the perambulator!

SPEAKER: FERAPONT
TEXT: Yes’m. [Takes the perambulator.]

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: [Confused] I’m speaking quietly.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: [At the window, nursing her boy] Bobby! Naughty Bobby! Bad

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: little Bobby!

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: [Looking through the papers] All right, I’ll look them over and

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: sign if necessary, and you can take them back to the offices....

SPEAKER: ANDREY
TEXT: back of the garden.]

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: [At the window] Bobby, what’s your mother’s name? Dear, dear!

SPEAKER: NATASHA

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: Olga!”

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: a harp. VERSHININ, OLGA, and ANFISA come out of the house and listen for

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: a minute in silence; IRINA comes up to them.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Our garden might be a public thoroughfare, from the way people

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: walk and ride across it. Nurse, give those musicians something!

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: [Gives money to the musicians] Go away with God’s blessing on

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: you. [The musicians bow and go away] A bitter sort of people. You don’t

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: play on a full stomach. [To IRINA] How do you do, Arisha! [Kisses her]

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: Well, little girl, here I am, still alive! Still alive! In the High

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: School, together with little Olga, in her official apartments... so the

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: Lord has appointed for my old age. Sinful woman that I am, I’ve never

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: lived like that in my life before.... A large flat, government property,

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: and I’ve a whole room and bed to myself. All government property. I wake

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: up at nights and, oh God, and Holy Mother, there isn’t a happier person

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: than I!

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: [Looks at his watch] We are going soon, Olga Sergeyevna. It’s

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: Sergeyevna?

SPEAKER: IRINA

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: I’ll go and look, too. [Shouts] Little Masha, co-ee! [Goes out

SPEAKER: ANFISA
TEXT: with IRINA down into the garden] Co-ee, co-ee!

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: at his watch] The town gave us a sort of farewell breakfast, we had

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: champagne to drink and the mayor made a speech, and I ate and listened,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: used to you now.

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: here another two months. If anything happens, or if anything has to be

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: won’t be a single soldier left in the town, it will all be a memory,

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: me.

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: anything? [Laughs] Life is heavy. To many of us it seems dull and

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: be absorbed in wars, and all its existence was filled with campaigns,

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: went....

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: VERSHININ

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: her, Olga Sergeyevna... it’s time... I’m late...

SPEAKER: VERSHININ
TEXT: and goes out quickly.]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: And a chain of bright gold is around it....”

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I’m going off my head... “There stands... a green oak... by the sea.”...

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Don’t, Masha, don’t... give her some water....

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: I’m not crying any more....

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: She’s not crying any more... she’s a good... [A shot is heard

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: from a distance.]

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: “There stands a green oak by the sea,

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: And a chain of bright gold is around it...

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: An oak of green gold....”

SPEAKER: MASHA

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: anything more now... I’ll be all right in a moment.... It doesn’t

SPEAKER: MASHA

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: thoughts are all tangled.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: Be quiet, Masha. There’s a good girl.... Let’s go in.

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: [Angrily] I shan’t go in there. [Sobs, but controls herself at

SPEAKER: MASHA
TEXT: once] I’m not going to go into the house, I won’t go....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: to-morrow.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: KULIGIN

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: Don’t, Masha!

SPEAKER: KULIGIN
TEXT: It’s a very good likeness....

TEXT: [To the maid] What? Mihail Ivanitch Protopopov will sit with

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: little Sophie, and Andrey Sergeyevitch can take little Bobby out.

SPEAKER: NATASHA
TEXT: Children are such a bother.... [To IRINA] Irina, it’s such a pity you’re

TEXT: going away to-morrow. Do stop just another week. [Sees KULIGIN and

SPEAKER: NATASHA

SPEAKER: NATASHA

SPEAKER: NATASHA

SPEAKER: NATASHA

SPEAKER: MASHA

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: her.]

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: tell you, dear....

SPEAKER: IRINA
TEXT: [Cries softly] I knew it, I knew it....

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN
TEXT: [Sits on a bench at the back of the stage] I’m tired....

SPEAKER: CHEBUTIKIN

SPEAKER: IRINA

SPEAKER: IRINA

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: OLGA

SPEAKER: OLGA

TEXT: THE CHERRY ORCHARD
