SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: ACT ONE

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: ANYA’S room. It is close on sunrise. It is May. The cherry-trees are

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: in flower but it is chilly in the garden. There is an early frost.

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: The windows of the room are shut. DUNYASHA comes in with a candle, and

SPEAKER: OLGA
TEXT: LOPAKHIN with a book in his hand.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: The train’s arrived, thank God. What’s the time?

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: It will soon be two. [Blows out candle] It is light already.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: How much was the train late? Two hours at least. [Yawns and

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: stretches himself] I have made a rotten mess of it! I came here on

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: purpose to meet them at the station, and then overslept myself... in my

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: chair. It’s a pity. I wish you’d wakened me.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I thought you’d gone away. [Listening] I think I hear them

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: coming.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Listens] No.... They’ve got to collect their luggage and so

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: on.... [Pause] Lubov Andreyevna has been living abroad for five years;

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I don’t know what she’ll be like now.... She’s a good sort--an easy,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: simple person. I remember when I was a boy of fifteen, my father, who

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: is dead--he used to keep a shop in the village here--hit me on the face

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: with his fist, and my nose bled.... We had gone into the yard together

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: for something or other, and he was a little drunk. Lubov Andreyevna, as

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I remember her now, was still young, and very thin, and she took me to

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: the washstand here in this very room, the nursery. She said, “Don’t

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: cry, little man, it’ll be all right in time for your wedding.” [Pause]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: “Little man”.... My father was a peasant, it’s true, but here I am in a

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: white waistcoat and yellow shoes... a pearl out of an oyster. I’m rich

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: now, with lots of money, but just think about it and examine me, and

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: you’ll find I’m still a peasant down to the marrow of my bones. [Turns

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: over the pages of his book] Here I’ve been reading this book, but I

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: understood nothing. I read and fell asleep. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: The dogs didn’t sleep all night; they know that they’re

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: coming.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: What’s up with you, Dunyasha...?

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: My hands are shaking. I shall faint.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: You’re too sensitive, Dunyasha. You dress just like a lady,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: and you do your hair like one too. You oughtn’t. You should know your

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: place.

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: [Enters with a bouquet. He wears a short jacket and

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: brilliantly polished boots which squeak audibly. He drops the bouquet as

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: he enters, then picks it up] The gardener sent these; says they’re to go

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: into the dining-room. [Gives the bouquet to DUNYASHA.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: And you’ll bring me some kvass.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: Very well. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: There’s a frost this morning--three degrees, and the

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: cherry-trees are all in flower. I can’t approve of our climate. [Sighs]

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: I can’t. Our climate is indisposed to favour us even this once. And,

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: Ermolai Alexeyevitch, allow me to say to you, in addition, that I bought

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: myself some boots two days ago, and I beg to assure you that they squeak

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: in a perfectly unbearable manner. What shall I put on them?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Go away. You bore me.

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: Some misfortune happens to me every day. But I don’t

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: complain; I’m used to it, and I can smile. [DUNYASHA comes in and

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: brings LOPAKHIN some kvass] I shall go. [Knocks over a chair] There....

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: I am in, so to speak. It is even simply marvellous. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I may confess to you, Ermolai Alexeyevitch, that Epikhodov has

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: proposed to me.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Ah!

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I don’t know what to do about it. He’s a nice young man, but

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: every now and again, when he begins talking, you can’t understand a word

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: he’s saying. I think I like him. He’s madly in love with me. He’s an

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: unlucky man; every day something happens. We tease him about it. They

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: call him “Two-and-twenty troubles.”

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Listens] There they come, I think.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: They’re coming! What’s the matter with me? I’m cold all over.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: There they are, right enough. Let’s go and meet them. Will she

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: know me? We haven’t seen each other for five years.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: [Excited] I shall faint in a minute.... Oh, I’m fainting!

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: quickly go out. The stage is empty. A noise begins in the next room.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: FIERS, leaning on a stick, walks quickly across the stage; he has just

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: been to meet LUBOV ANDREYEVNA. He wears an old-fashioned livery and a

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: tall hat. He is saying something to himself, but not a word of it can be

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: made out. The noise behind the stage gets louder and louder. A voice is

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: heard: “Let’s go in there.” Enter LUBOV ANDREYEVNA, ANYA, and CHARLOTTA

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: IVANOVNA with a little dog on a chain, and all dressed in travelling

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: clothes, VARYA in a long coat and with a kerchief on her head. GAEV,

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: SIMEONOV-PISCHIN, LOPAKHIN, DUNYASHA with a parcel and an umbrella, and

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: a servant with luggage--all cross the room.]

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Let’s come through here. Do you remember what this room is,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: mother?

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Joyfully, through her tears] The nursery!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: How cold it is! My hands are quite numb. [To LUBOV ANDREYEVNA]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Your rooms, the white one and the violet one, are just as they used to

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: be, mother.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: My dear nursery, oh, you beautiful room.... I used to sleep

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: here when I was a baby. [Weeps] And here I am like a little girl again.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: she used to be, just like a nun. And I knew Dunyasha. [Kisses her.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: The train was two hours late. There now; how’s that for

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: punctuality?

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: [To PISCHIN] My dog eats nuts too.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Astonished] To think of that, now!

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: We did have to wait for you!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: I didn’t get any sleep for four nights on the journey.... I’m

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: awfully cold.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: You went away during Lent, when it was snowing and frosty, but

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: now? Darling! [Laughs and kisses her] We did have to wait for you, my

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: joy, my pet.... I must tell you at once, I can’t bear to wait a minute.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Tired] Something else now...?

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: The clerk, Epikhodov, proposed to me after Easter.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Always the same.... [Puts her hair straight] I’ve lost all my

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: hairpins.... [She is very tired, and even staggers as she walks.]

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I don’t know what to think about it. He loves me, he loves me

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: so much!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Looks into her room; in a gentle voice] My room, my windows, as

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: if I’d never gone away. I’m at home! To-morrow morning I’ll get up and

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: have a run in the garden....Oh, if I could only get to sleep! I didn’t

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: sleep the whole journey, I was so bothered.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: Peter Sergeyevitch came two days ago.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Joyfully] Peter!

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: He sleeps in the bath-house, he lives there. He said he was

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: afraid he’d be in the way. [Looks at her pocket-watch] I ought to wake

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: him, but Barbara Mihailovna told me not to. “Don’t wake him,” she said.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Dunyasha, some coffee, quick. Mother wants some.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: This minute. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Well, you’ve come, glory be to God. Home again. [Caressing her]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: My darling is back again! My pretty one is back again!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: I did have an awful time, I tell you.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I can just imagine it!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: I went away in Holy Week; it was very cold then. Charlotta talked

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: the whole way and would go on performing her tricks. Why did you tie

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Charlotta on to me?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: You couldn’t go alone, darling, at seventeen!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: We went to Paris; it’s cold there and snowing. I talk French

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: perfectly horribly. My mother lives on the fifth floor. I go to her, and

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: find her there with various Frenchmen, women, an old abbé with a book,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: and everything in tobacco smoke and with no comfort at all. I suddenly

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: became very sorry for mother--so sorry that I took her head in my arms

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: and hugged her and wouldn’t let her go. Then mother started hugging me

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: and crying....

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Weeping] Don’t say any more, don’t say any more....

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: She’s already sold her villa near Mentone; she’s nothing left,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: nothing. And I haven’t a copeck left either; we only just managed to get

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: here. And mother won’t understand! We had dinner at a station; she asked

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: for all the expensive things, and tipped the waiters one rouble each.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: And Charlotta too. Yasha wants his share too--it’s too bad. Mother’s got

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: a footman now, Yasha; we’ve brought him here.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I saw the wretch.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: How’s business? Has the interest been paid?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Not much chance of that.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Oh God, oh God...

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: The place will be sold in August.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: O God....

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Looks in at the door and moos] Moo!... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Through her tears] I’d like to.... [Shakes her fist.]

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Embraces VARYA, softly] Varya, has he proposed to you? [VARYA

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: shakes head] But he loves you.... Why don’t you make up your minds? Why

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: do you keep on waiting?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I think that it will all come to nothing. He’s a busy man. I’m

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: not his affair... he pays no attention to me. Bless the man, I don’t

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: want to see him.... But everybody talks about our marriage, everybody

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: congratulates me, and there’s nothing in it at all, it’s all like a

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: dream. [In another tone] You’ve got a brooch like a bee.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Sadly] Mother bought it. [Goes into her room, and talks lightly,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: like a child] In Paris I went up in a balloon!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: My darling’s come back, my pretty one’s come back! [DUNYASHA has

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: already returned with the coffee-pot and is making the coffee, VARYA

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: stands near the door] I go about all day, looking after the house, and

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I think all the time, if only you could marry a rich man, then I’d be

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: happy and would go away somewhere by myself, then to Kiev... to Moscow,

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: and so on, from one holy place to another. I’d tramp and tramp. That

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: would be splendid!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: The birds are singing in the garden. What time is it now?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: It must be getting on for three. Time you went to sleep, darling.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Crossing the stage: Politely] May I go this way?

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I hardly knew you, Yasha. You have changed abroad.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Hm... and who are you?

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: When you went away I was only so high. [Showing with her hand]

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I’m Dunyasha, the daughter of Theodore Kozoyedov. You don’t remember!

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Oh, you little cucumber!

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: goes out quickly.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [In the doorway: In an angry voice] What’s that?

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: [Through her tears] I’ve broken a saucer.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: It may bring luck.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Coming out of her room] We must tell mother that Peter’s here.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I told them not to wake him.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Thoughtfully] Father died six years ago, and a month later my

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: brother Grisha was drowned in the river--such a dear little boy of

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: seven! Mother couldn’t bear it; she went away, away, without looking

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: round.... [Shudders] How I understand her; if only she knew! [Pause] And

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Peter Trofimov was Grisha’s tutor, he might tell her....

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: [Goes to the coffee-pot, nervously] The mistress is going to

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: have some food here.... [Puts on white gloves] Is the coffee ready? [To

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: DUNYASHA, severely] You! Where’s the cream?

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: Oh, dear me...! [Rapid exit.]

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: [Fussing round the coffee-pot] Oh, you bungler.... [Murmurs

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: to himself] Back from Paris... the master went to Paris once... in a

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: carriage.... [Laughs.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: What are you talking about, Fiers?

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: I beg your pardon? [Joyfully] The mistress is home again. I’ve

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: lived to see her! Don’t care if I die now.... [Weeps with joy.]

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: latter in a long jacket of thin cloth and loose trousers. GAEV, coming

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: in, moves his arms and body about as if he is playing billiards.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Let me remember now. Red into the corner! Twice into the centre!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Right into the pocket! Once upon a time you and I used both to

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: sleep in this room, and now I’m fifty-one; it does seem strange.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Yes, time does go.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Who does?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I said that time does go.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: It smells of patchouli here.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: I’m going to bed. Good-night, mother. [Kisses her.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: My lovely little one. [Kisses her hand] Glad to be at home? I

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: can’t get over it.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Good-night, uncle.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Kisses her face and hands] God be with you. How you do resemble

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: your mother! [To his sister] You were just like her at her age, Luba.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: door behind her.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: She’s awfully tired.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: It’s a very long journey.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [To LOPAKHIN and PISCHIN] Well, sirs, it’s getting on for three,

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: quite time you went.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Laughs] You’re just the same as ever, Varya. [Draws her close

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: and kisses her] I’ll have some coffee now, then we’ll all go. [FIERS

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: lays a cushion under her feet] Thank you, dear. I’m used to coffee. I

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: drink it day and night. Thank you, dear old man. [Kisses FIERS.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I’ll go and see if they’ve brought in all the luggage. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Is it really I who am sitting here? [Laughs] I want to jump

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: about and wave my arms. [Covers her face with her hands] But suppose I’m

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: dreaming! God knows I love my own country, I love it deeply; I couldn’t

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: look out of the railway carriage, I cried so much. [Through her tears]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Still, I must have my coffee. Thank you, Fiers. Thank you, dear old man.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I’m so glad you’re still with us.

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: The day before yesterday.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: He doesn’t hear well.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I’ve got to go off to Kharkov by the five o’clock train. I’m

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: awfully sorry! I should like to have a look at you, to gossip a little.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: You’re as fine-looking as ever.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Breathes heavily] Even finer-looking... dressed in Paris

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: fashions... confound it all.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Your brother, Leonid Andreyevitch, says I’m a snob, a usurer,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: but that is absolutely nothing to me. Let him talk. Only I do wish you

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: would believe in me as you once did, that your wonderful, touching eyes

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: would look at me as they did before. Merciful God! My father was the

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: serf of your grandfather and your own father, but you--you more than

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: anybody else--did so much for me once upon a time that I’ve forgotten

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: everything and love you as if you belonged to my family... and even

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: more.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I can’t sit still, I’m not in a state to do it. [Jumps up and

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: walks about in great excitement] I’ll never survive this happiness....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You can laugh at me; I’m a silly woman.... My dear little cupboard.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Nurse has died in your absence.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Sits and drinks coffee] Yes, bless her soul. I heard by letter.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: And Anastasius has died too. Peter Kosoy has left me and now lives

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: in town with the Commissioner of Police. [Takes a box of sugar-candy out

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: of his pocket and sucks a piece.]

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: My daughter, Dashenka, sends her love.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I want to say something very pleasant, very delightful, to

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: you. [Looks at his watch] I’m going away at once, I haven’t much time...

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: but I’ll tell you all about it in two or three words. As you already

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: know, your cherry orchard is to be sold to pay your debts, and the sale

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: is fixed for August 22; but you needn’t be alarmed, dear madam, you

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: may sleep in peace; there’s a way out. Here’s my plan. Please attend

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: carefully! Your estate is only thirteen miles from the town, the railway

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: runs by, and if the cherry orchard and the land by the river are broken

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: up into building lots and are then leased off for villas you’ll get at

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: least twenty-five thousand roubles a year profit out of it.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: How utterly absurd!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I don’t understand you at all, Ermolai Alexeyevitch.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: You will get twenty-five roubles a year for each dessiatin

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: from the leaseholders at the very least, and if you advertise now I’m

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: willing to bet that you won’t have a vacant plot left by the autumn;

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: they’ll all go. In a word, you’re saved. I congratulate you. Only,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: of course, you’ll have to put things straight, and clean up.... For

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: instance, you’ll have to pull down all the old buildings, this house,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: which isn’t any use to anybody now, and cut down the old cherry

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: orchard....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Cut it down? My dear man, you must excuse me, but you don’t

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: understand anything at all. If there’s anything interesting or

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: remarkable in the whole province, it’s this cherry orchard of ours.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: The only remarkable thing about the orchard is that it’s very

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: large. It only bears fruit every other year, and even then you don’t

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: know what to do with them; nobody buys any.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: This orchard is mentioned in the “Encyclopaedic Dictionary.”

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Looks at his watch] If we can’t think of anything and don’t

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: make up our minds to anything, then on August 22, both the cherry

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: orchard and the whole estate will be up for auction. Make up your mind!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I swear there’s no other way out, I’ll swear it again.

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: In the old days, forty or fifty years back, they dried the

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: cherries, soaked them and pickled them, and made jam of them, and it

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: used to happen that...

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Be quiet, Fiers.

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: And then we’d send the dried cherries off in carts to Moscow and

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: Kharkov. And money! And the dried cherries were soft, juicy, sweet, and

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: nicely scented.... They knew the way....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: What was the way?

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: They’ve forgotten. Nobody remembers.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [To LUBOV ANDREYEVNA] What about Paris? Eh? Did you eat frogs?

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I ate crocodiles.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: To think of that, now.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Up to now in the villages there were only the gentry and the

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: labourers, and now the people who live in villas have arrived. All towns

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: now, even small ones, are surrounded by villas. And it’s safe to say

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: that in twenty years’ time the villa resident will be all over the

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: place. At present he sits on his balcony and drinks tea, but it may well

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: come to pass that he’ll begin to cultivate his patch of land, and then

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: your cherry orchard will be happy, rich, splendid....

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Angry] What rot!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: There are two telegrams for you, little mother. [Picks out a key

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: and noisily unlocks an antique cupboard] Here they are.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: They’re from Paris.... [Tears them up without reading them] I’ve

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: done with Paris.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: And do you know, Luba, how old this case is? A week ago I took out

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: the bottom drawer; I looked and saw figures burnt out in it. That case

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: was made exactly a hundred years ago. What do you think of that? What?

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: We could celebrate its jubilee. It hasn’t a soul of its own, but still,

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: say what you will, it’s a fine bookcase.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Astonished] A hundred years.... Think of that!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Yes... it’s a real thing. [Handling it] My dear and honoured case!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I congratulate you on your existence, which has already for more than

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: a hundred years been directed towards the bright ideals of good and

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: justice; your silent call to productive labour has not grown less in the

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: hundred years [Weeping] during which you have upheld virtue and faith

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: in a better future to the generations of our race, educating us up

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: to ideals of goodness and to the knowledge of a common consciousness.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Yes....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You’re just the same as ever, Leon.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [A little confused] Off the white on the right, into the corner

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: pocket. Red ball goes into the middle pocket!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Looks at his watch] It’s time I went.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Giving LUBOV ANDREYEVNA her medicine] Will you take your pills

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: now?

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: You oughtn’t to take medicines, dear madam; they do you neither

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: harm nor good.... Give them here, dear madam. [Takes the pills, turns

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: them out into the palm of his hand, blows on them, puts them into his

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: mouth, and drinks some kvass] There!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Frightened] You’re off your head!

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I’ve taken all the pills.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Gormandizer! [All laugh.]

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: They were here in Easter week and ate half a pailful of

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: cucumbers.... [Mumbles.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: What’s he driving at?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: He’s been mumbling away for three years. We’re used to that.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Senile decay.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: thin and tightly laced; has a lorgnette at her waist.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Excuse me, Charlotta Ivanovna, I haven’t said “How do you do”

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: to you yet. [Tries to kiss her hand.]

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: [Takes her hand away] If you let people kiss your hand, then

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: they’ll want your elbow, then your shoulder, and then...

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: My luck’s out to-day! [All laugh] Show us a trick, Charlotta

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Ivanovna!

SPEAKER: LUBOV ANDREYEVNA
TEXT: Charlotta, do us a trick.

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: It’s not necessary. I want to go to bed. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: We shall see each other in three weeks. [Kisses LUBOV

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: ANDREYEVNA’S hand] Now, good-bye. It’s time to go. [To GAEV] See you

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: again. [Kisses PISCHIN] Au revoir. [Gives his hand to VARYA, then to

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: FIERS and to YASHA] I don’t want to go away. [To LUBOV ANDREYEVNA]. If

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: you think about the villas and make up your mind, then just let me

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: know, and I’ll raise a loan of 50,000 roubles at once. Think about it

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: seriously.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Angrily] Do go, now!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I’m going, I’m going.... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Snob. Still, I beg pardon.... Varya’s going to marry him, he’s

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Varya’s young man.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Don’t talk too much, uncle.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Why not, Varya? I should be very glad. He’s a good man.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: To speak the honest truth... he’s a worthy man.... And my

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Dashenka... also says that... she says lots of things. [Snores, but

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: wakes up again at once] But still, dear madam, if you could lend me...

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: 240 roubles... to pay the interest on my mortgage to-morrow...

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Frightened] We haven’t got it, we haven’t got it!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: It’s quite true. I’ve nothing at all.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I’ll find it all right [Laughs] I never lose hope. I used to

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: think, “Everything’s lost now. I’m a dead man,” when, lo and behold, a

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: railway was built over my land... and they paid me for it. And something

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: else will happen to-day or to-morrow. Dashenka may win 20,000 roubles...

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: she’s got a lottery ticket.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: The coffee’s all gone, we can go to bed.

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: [Brushing GAEV’S trousers; in an insistent tone] You’ve put on

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: the wrong trousers again. What am I to do with you?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Quietly] Anya’s asleep. [Opens window quietly] The sun has risen

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: already; it isn’t cold. Look, little mother: what lovely trees! And the

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: air! The starlings are singing!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Opens the other window] The whole garden’s white. You haven’t

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: forgotten, Luba? There’s that long avenue going straight, straight, like

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: a stretched strap; it shines on moonlight nights. Do you remember? You

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: haven’t forgotten?

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Looks out into the garden] Oh, my childhood, days of my

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: innocence! In this nursery I used to sleep; I used to look out from here

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: into the orchard. Happiness used to wake with me every morning, and then

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: it was just as it is now; nothing has changed. [Laughs from joy] It’s

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: all, all white! Oh, my orchard! After the dark autumns and the cold

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: winters, you’re young again, full of happiness, the angels of heaven

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: haven’t left you.... If only I could take my heavy burden off my breast

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: and shoulders, if I could forget my past!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Yes, and they’ll sell this orchard to pay off debts. How strange

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: it seems!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Look, there’s my dead mother going in the orchard... dressed in

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: white! [Laughs from joy] That’s she.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Where?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: God bless you, little mother.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: There’s nobody there; I thought I saw somebody. On the right, at

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: the turning by the summer-house, a white little tree bent down, looking

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: just like a woman. [Enter TROFIMOV in a worn student uniform and

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: spectacles] What a marvellous garden! White masses of flowers, the blue

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: sky....

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Lubov Andreyevna! [She looks round at him] I only want to show

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: myself, and I’ll go away. [Kisses her hand warmly] I was told to wait

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: till the morning, but I didn’t have the patience.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Crying] It’s Peter Trofimov.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Peter Trofimov, once the tutor of your Grisha.... Have I

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: changed so much?

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Confused] That’s enough, that’s enough, Luba.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Weeps] But I told you, Peter, to wait till to-morrow.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: My Grisha... my boy... Grisha... my son.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: What are we to do, little mother? It’s the will of God.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: [Softly, through his tears] It’s all right, it’s all right.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Still weeping] My boy’s dead; he was drowned. Why? Why, my

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: friend? [Softly] Anya’s asleep in there. I am speaking so loudly, making

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: such a noise.... Well, Peter? What’s made you look so bad? Why have you

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: grown so old?

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: In the train an old woman called me a decayed gentleman.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You were quite a boy then, a nice little student, and now your

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: hair is not at all thick and you wear spectacles. Are you really still a

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: student? [Goes to the door.]

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: I suppose I shall always be a student.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Kisses her brother, then VARYA] Well, let’s go to bed.... And

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: you’ve grown older, Leonid.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Follows her] Yes, we’ve got to go to bed.... Oh, my gout! I’ll

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: stay the night here. If only, Lubov Andreyevna, my dear, you could get

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: me 240 roubles to-morrow morning--

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Still the same story.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Two hundred and forty roubles... to pay the interest on the

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: mortgage.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I haven’t any money, dear man.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I’ll give it back... it’s a small sum....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Well, then, Leonid will give it to you.... Let him have it,

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Leonid.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: By all means; hold out your hand.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Why not? He wants it; he’ll give it back.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: YASHA remain.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: My sister hasn’t lost the habit of throwing money about. [To

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: YASHA] Stand off, do; you smell of poultry.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Grins] You are just the same as ever, Leonid Andreyevitch.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Really? [To VARYA] What’s he saying?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [To YASHA] Your mother’s come from the village; she’s been

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: sitting in the servants’ room since yesterday, and wants to see you....

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Bless the woman!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Shameless man.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: A lot of use there is in her coming. She might have come tomorrow

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: just as well. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Mother hasn’t altered a scrap, she’s just as she always was.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: She’d give away everything, if the idea only entered her head.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Yes.... [Pause] If there’s any illness for which people offer many

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: remedies, you may be sure that particular illness is incurable, I think.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I work my brains to their hardest. I’ve several remedies, very many,

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: and that really means I’ve none at all. It would be nice to inherit a

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: fortune from somebody, it would be nice to marry our Anya to a rich

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: man, it would be nice to go to Yaroslav and try my luck with my aunt the

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Countess. My aunt is very, very rich.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Weeps] If only God helped us.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Don’t cry. My aunt’s very rich, but she doesn’t like us. My

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: sister, in the first place, married an advocate, not a noble.... [ANYA

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: appears in the doorway] She not only married a man who was not a noble,

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: but she behaved herself in a way which cannot be described as proper.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: She’s nice and kind and charming, and I’m very fond of her, but say what

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: you will in her favour and you still have to admit that she’s wicked;

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: you can feel it in her slightest movements.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Whispers] Anya’s in the doorway.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Really? [Pause] It’s curious, something’s got into my right eye...

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I can’t see properly out of it. And on Thursday, when I was at the

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: District Court...

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Why aren’t you in bed, Anya?

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Can’t sleep. It’s no good.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: My darling! [Kisses ANYA’S face and hands] My child.... [Crying]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: You’re not my niece, you’re my angel, you’re my all.... Believe in me,

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: believe...

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: I do believe in you, uncle. Everybody loves you and respects

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: you... but, uncle dear, you ought to say nothing, no more than that.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: What were you saying just now about my mother, your own sister? Why did

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: you say those things?

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Yes, yes. [Covers his face with her hand] Yes, really, it was

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: awful. Save me, my God! And only just now I made a speech before a

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: bookcase... it’s so silly! And only when I’d finished I knew how silly

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: it was.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Yes, uncle dear, you really ought to say less. Keep quiet, that’s

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: all.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: You’d be so much happier in yourself if you only kept quiet.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: All right, I’ll be quiet. [Kisses their hands] I’ll be quiet. But

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: let’s talk business. On Thursday I was in the District Court, and a lot

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: of us met there together, and we began to talk of this, that, and the

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: other, and now I think I can arrange a loan to pay the interest into the

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: bank.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: If only God would help us!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I’ll go on Tuesday. I’ll talk with them about it again. [To VARYA]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Don’t howl. [To ANYA] Your mother will have a talk to Lopakhin; he, of

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: course, won’t refuse... And when you’ve rested you’ll go to Yaroslav to

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: the Countess, your grandmother. So you see, we’ll have three irons in

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: the fire, and we’ll be safe. We’ll pay up the interest. I’m certain.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: you will, that the estate will not be sold! [Excitedly] I swear on my

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: happiness! Here’s my hand. You may call me a dishonourable wretch if I

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: let it go to auction! I swear by all I am!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [She is calm again and happy] How good and clever you are, uncle.

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: [Reproachfully] Leonid Andreyevitch, don’t you fear God? When are

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: you going to bed?

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Soon, soon. You go away, Fiers. I’ll undress myself. Well,

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: children, bye-bye...! I’ll give you the details to-morrow, but let’s go

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: to bed now. [Kisses ANYA and VARYA] I’m a man of the eighties.... People

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: don’t praise those years much, but I can still say that I’ve suffered

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: for my beliefs. The peasants don’t love me for nothing, I assure you.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: We’ve got to learn to know the peasants! We ought to learn how....

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: You’re doing it again, uncle!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Be quiet, uncle!

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: [Angrily] Leonid Andreyevitch!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I’m coming, I’m coming.... Go to bed now. Off two cushions into

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: the middle! I turn over a new leaf.... [Exit. FIERS goes out after him.]

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: I’m quieter now. I don’t want to go to Yaroslav, I don’t like

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: grandmother; but I’m calm now; thanks to uncle. [Sits down.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: It’s time to go to sleep. I’ll go. There’s been an unpleasantness

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: here while you were away. In the old servants’ part of the house, as you

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: know, only the old people live--little old Efim and Polya and Evstigney,

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: and Karp as well. They started letting some tramps or other spend the

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: night there--I said nothing. Then I heard that they were saying that I

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: had ordered them to be fed on peas and nothing else; from meanness, you

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: see.... And it was all Evstigney’s doing.... Very well, I thought,

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: if that’s what the matter is, just you wait. So I call Evstigney....

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: arm] Let’s go to bye-bye.... Come along!... [Leads her] My darling’s

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: gone to sleep! Come on.... [They go. In the distance, the other side of

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: the orchard, a shepherd plays his pipe. TROFIMOV crosses the stage and

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: stops on seeing VARYA and ANYA] Sh! She’s asleep, asleep. Come on, dear.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Quietly, half-asleep] I’m so tired... all the bells... uncle,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: dear! Mother and uncle!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Come on, dear, come on! [They go into ANYA’S room.]

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: [Moved] My sun! My spring!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: ACT TWO

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: it a well and large stones, which apparently are old tombstones, and

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: an old garden seat. The road is seen to GAEV’S estate. On one side rise

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: dark poplars, behind them begins the cherry orchard. In the distance

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: is a row of telegraph poles, and far, far away on the horizon are the

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: indistinct signs of a large town, which can only be seen on the finest

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: and clearest days. It is close on sunset. CHARLOTTA, YASHA, and DUNYASHA

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: are sitting on the seat; EPIKHODOV stands by and plays on a guitar; all

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: seem thoughtful. CHARLOTTA wears a man’s old peaked cap; she has unslung

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: a rifle from her shoulders and is putting to rights the buckle on the

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: strap.]

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: [Thoughtfully] I haven’t a real passport. I don’t know how

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: old I am, and I think I’m young. When I was a little girl my father and

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: mother used to go round fairs and give very good performances and I used

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: to do the _salto mortale_ and various little things. And when papa and

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: mamma died a German lady took me to her and began to teach me. I liked

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: it. I grew up and became a governess. And where I came from and who

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: I am, I don’t know.... Who my parents were--perhaps they weren’t

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: married--I don’t know. [Takes a cucumber out of her pocket and eats] I

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: don’t know anything. [Pause] I do want to talk, but I haven’t anybody to

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: talk to... I haven’t anybody at all.

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: [Plays on the guitar and sings]

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: “What is this noisy earth to me,

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: What matter friends and foes?”

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: I do like playing on the mandoline!

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: That’s a guitar, not a mandoline. [Looks at herself in a

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: little mirror and powders herself.]

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: For the enamoured madman, this is a mandoline. [Sings]

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: “Oh that the heart was warmed,

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: By all the flames of love returned!”

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: These people sing terribly.... Foo! Like jackals.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: [To YASHA] Still, it must be nice to live abroad.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Yes, certainly. I cannot differ from you there. [Yawns and lights

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: a cigar.]

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: That is perfectly natural. Abroad everything is in full

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: complexity.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: That goes without saying.

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: I’m an educated man, I read various remarkable books, but I

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: cannot understand the direction I myself want to go--whether to live

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: or to shoot myself, as it were. So, in case, I always carry a revolver

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: about with me. Here it is. [Shows a revolver.]

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: I’ve done. Now I’ll go. [Slings the rifle] You, Epikhodov,

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: are a very clever man and very terrible; women must be madly in love

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: with you. Brrr! [Going] These wise ones are all so stupid. I’ve nobody

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: to talk to. I’m always alone, alone; I’ve nobody at all... and I don’t

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: know who I am or why I live. [Exit slowly.]

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: As a matter of fact, independently of everything else, I must

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: express my feeling, among other things, that fate has been as pitiless

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: in her dealings with me as a storm is to a small ship. Suppose, let

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: us grant, I am wrong; then why did I wake up this morning, to give an

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: example, and behold an enormous spider on my chest, like that. [Shows

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: with both hands] And if I do drink some kvass, why is it that there is

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: bound to be something of the most indelicate nature in it, such as a

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: beetle? [Pause] Have you read Buckle? [Pause] I should like to trouble

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: you, Avdotya Fedorovna, for two words.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: Say on.

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: I should prefer to be alone with you. [Sighs.]

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: [Shy] Very well, only first bring me my little cloak.... It’s

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: by the cupboard. It’s a little damp here.

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: Very well... I’ll bring it.... Now I know what to do with my

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: revolver. [Takes guitar and exits, strumming.]

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Two-and-twenty troubles! A silly man, between you and me and the

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: gatepost. [Yawns.]

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I hope to goodness he won’t shoot himself. [Pause] I’m so

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: nervous, I’m worried. I went into service when I was quite a little

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: girl, and now I’m not used to common life, and my hands are white, white

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: as a lady’s. I’m so tender and so delicate now; respectable and afraid

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: of everything.... I’m so frightened. And I don’t know what will happen

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: to my nerves if you deceive me, Yasha.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Kisses her] Little cucumber! Of course, every girl must respect

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: herself; there’s nothing I dislike more than a badly behaved girl.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: I’m awfully in love with you; you’re educated, you can talk

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: about everything. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Yawns] Yes. I think this: if a girl loves anybody, then that

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: means she’s immoral. [Pause] It’s nice to smoke a cigar out in the open

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: air.... [Listens] Somebody’s coming. It’s the mistress, and people with

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: her. [DUNYASHA embraces him suddenly] Go to the house, as if you’d been

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: bathing in the river; go by this path, or they’ll meet you and will

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: think I’ve been meeting you. I can’t stand that sort of thing.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: [Coughs quietly] My head’s aching because of your cigar.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: GAEV, and LOPAKHIN.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: You must make up your mind definitely--there’s no time to

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: waste. The question is perfectly plain. Are you willing to let the land

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: for villas or no? Just one word, yes or no? Just one word!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Who’s smoking horrible cigars here? [Sits.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: They built that railway; that’s made this place very handy. [Sits]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Went to town and had lunch... red in the middle! I’d like to go in now

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: and have just one game.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You’ll have time.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Just one word! [Imploringly] Give me an answer!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Yawns] Really!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Looks in her purse] I had a lot of money yesterday, but there’s

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: very little to-day. My poor Varya feeds everybody on milk soup to

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: save money, in the kitchen the old people only get peas, and I spend

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: recklessly. [Drops the purse, scattering gold coins] There, they are all

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: over the place.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Permit me to pick them up. [Collects the coins.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Please do, Yasha. And why did I go and have lunch there?... A

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: horrid restaurant with band and tablecloths smelling of soap.... Why

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: do you drink so much, Leon? Why do you eat so much? Why do you talk so

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: much? You talked again too much to-day in the restaurant, and it wasn’t

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: at all to the point--about the seventies and about decadents. And to

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: whom? Talking to the waiters about decadents!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Waves his hand] I can’t be cured, that’s obvious.... [Irritably

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: to YASHA] What’s the matter? Why do you keep twisting about in front of

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: me?

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Laughs] I can’t listen to your voice without laughing.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [To his sister] Either he or I...

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Go away, Yasha; get out of this....

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Gives purse to LUBOV ANDREYEVNA] I’ll go at once. [Hardly able

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: to keep from laughing] This minute.... [Exit.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: That rich man Deriganov is preparing to buy your estate. They

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: say he’ll come to the sale himself.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Where did you hear that?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: They say so in town.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Our Yaroslav aunt has promised to send something, but I don’t know

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: when or how much.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: How much will she send? A hundred thousand roubles? Or two,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: perhaps?

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I’d be glad of ten or fifteen thousand.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: You must excuse my saying so, but I’ve never met such

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: frivolous people as you before, or anybody so unbusinesslike and

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: peculiar. Here I am telling you in plain language that your estate will

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: be sold, and you don’t seem to understand.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: What are we to do? Tell us, what?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I tell you every day. I say the same thing every day. Both the

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: cherry orchard and the land must be leased off for villas and at once,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: immediately--the auction is staring you in the face: Understand! Once

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: you do definitely make up your minds to the villas, then you’ll have as

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: much money as you want and you’ll be saved.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Villas and villa residents--it’s so vulgar, excuse me.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I entirely agree with you.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I must cry or yell or faint. I can’t stand it! You’re too much

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: for me! [To GAEV] You old woman!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Really!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Old woman! [Going out.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Frightened] No, don’t go away, do stop; be a dear. Please.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Perhaps we’ll find some way out!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: What’s the good of trying to think!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Please don’t go away. It’s nicer when you’re here.... [Pause]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I keep on waiting for something to happen, as if the house is going to

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: collapse over our heads.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Thinking deeply] Double in the corner... across the middle....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: We have been too sinful....

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: What sins have you committed?

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Puts candy into his mouth] They say that I’ve eaten all my

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: substance in sugar-candies. [Laughs.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Oh, my sins.... I’ve always scattered money about without holding

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: myself in, like a madwoman, and I married a man who made nothing but

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: debts. My husband died of champagne--he drank terribly--and to my

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: misfortune, I fell in love with another man and went off with him, and

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: just at that time--it was my first punishment, a blow that hit me right

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: on the head--here, in the river... my boy was drowned, and I went away,

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: quite away, never to return, never to see this river again...I shut my

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: eyes and ran without thinking, but _he_ ran after me... without pity,

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: without respect. I bought a villa near Mentone because _he_ fell ill

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: there, and for three years I knew no rest either by day or night; the

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: sick man wore me out, and my soul dried up. And last year, when they

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: had sold the villa to pay my debts, I went away to Paris, and there

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: he robbed me of all I had and threw me over and went off with another

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: woman. I tried to poison myself.... It was so silly, so shameful....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: And suddenly I longed to be back in Russia, my own land, with my little

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: girl.... [Wipes her tears] Lord, Lord be merciful to me, forgive me my

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: sins! Punish me no more! [Takes a telegram out of her pocket] I had

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: this to-day from Paris.... He begs my forgiveness, he implores me to

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: return.... [Tears it up] Don’t I hear music? [Listens.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: That is our celebrated Jewish band. You remember--four violins, a

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: flute, and a double-bass.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: LUBOV So it still exists? It would be nice if they came along some

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: evening.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Listens] I can’t hear.... [Sings quietly] “For money will the

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Germans make a Frenchman of a Russian.” [Laughs] I saw such an awfully

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: funny thing at the theatre last night.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I’m quite sure there wasn’t anything at all funny. You oughtn’t

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: to go and see plays, you ought to go and look at yourself. What a grey

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: life you lead, what a lot you talk unnecessarily.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: It’s true. To speak the straight truth, we live a silly life.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: didn’t teach me, he was always drunk, and always used a stick on me. In

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: point of fact, I’m a fool and an idiot too. I’ve never learned anything,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: my handwriting is bad, I write so that I’m quite ashamed before people,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: like a pig!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You ought to get married, my friend.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Yes... that’s true.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Why not to our Varya? She’s a nice girl.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: She’s quite homely in her ways, works all day, and, what matters

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: most, she’s in love with you. And you’ve liked her for a long time.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Well? I don’t mind... she’s a nice girl. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I’m offered a place in a bank. Six thousand roubles a year.... Did

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: you hear?

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: What’s the matter with you! Stay where you are....

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: [To GAEV] Please, sir, put this on, it’s damp.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Putting it on] You’re a nuisance, old man.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: FIERS It’s all very well.... You went away this morning without telling

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: me. [Examining GAEV.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: How old you’ve grown, Fiers!

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: I beg your pardon?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: She says you’ve grown very old!

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: I’ve been alive a long time. They were already getting ready

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: to marry me before your father was born.... [Laughs] And when the

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: Emancipation came I was already first valet. Only I didn’t agree with

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: the Emancipation and remained with my people.... [Pause] I remember

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: everybody was happy, but they didn’t know why.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: It was very good for them in the old days. At any rate, they

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: used to beat them.

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: [Not hearing] Rather. The peasants kept their distance from the

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: masters and the masters kept their distance from the peasants, but now

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: everything’s all anyhow and you can’t understand anything.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Be quiet, Fiers. I’ve got to go to town tomorrow. I’ve been

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: promised an introduction to a General who may lend me money on a bill.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Nothing will come of it. And you won’t pay your interest,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: don’t you worry.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: He’s talking rubbish. There’s no General at all.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Here they are.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Mother’s sitting down here.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Tenderly] Come, come, my dears.... [Embracing ANYA and VARYA] If

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: you two only knew how much I love you. Sit down next to me, like that.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Our eternal student is always with the ladies.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: That’s not your business.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: He’ll soon be fifty, and he’s still a student.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Leave off your silly jokes!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Getting angry, eh, silly?

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Shut up, can’t you.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Laughs] I wonder what you think of me?

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: I think, Ermolai Alexeyevitch, that you’re a rich man,

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: and you’ll soon be a millionaire. Just as the wild beast which eats

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: everything it finds is needed for changes to take place in matter, so

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: you are needed too.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Better tell us something about the planets, Peter.

SPEAKER: LUBOV ANDREYEVNA
TEXT: No, let’s go on with yesterday’s talk!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: About what?

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: About the proud man.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yesterday we talked for a long time but we didn’t come to

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: anything in the end. There’s something mystical about the proud man, in

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: your sense. Perhaps you are right from your point of view, but if you

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: take the matter simply, without complicating it, then what pride can

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: there be, what sense can there be in it, if a man is imperfectly made,

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: physiologically speaking, if in the vast majority of cases he is coarse

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: and stupid and deeply unhappy? We must stop admiring one another. We

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: must work, nothing more.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: You’ll die, all the same.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Who knows? And what does it mean--you’ll die? Perhaps a man

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: has a hundred senses, and when he dies only the five known to us are

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: destroyed and the remaining ninety-five are left alive.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: How clever of you, Peter!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Ironically] Oh, awfully!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: The human race progresses, perfecting its powers.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Everything that is unattainable now will some day be near at hand and

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: comprehensible, but we must work, we must help with all our strength

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: those who seek to know what fate will bring. Meanwhile in Russia only

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: a very few of us work. The vast majority of those intellectuals whom I

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: know seek for nothing, do nothing, and are at present incapable of hard

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: work. They call themselves intellectuals, but they use “thou” and “thee”

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: to their servants, they treat the peasants like animals, they learn

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: badly, they read nothing seriously, they do absolutely nothing, about

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: science they only talk, about art they understand little. They are

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: all serious, they all have severe faces, they all talk about important

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: things. They philosophize, and at the same time, the vast majority

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: of us, ninety-nine out of a hundred, live like savages, fighting and

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: cursing at the slightest opportunity, eating filthily, sleeping in the

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: dirt, in stuffiness, with fleas, stinks, smells, moral filth, and so

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: on... And it’s obvious that all our nice talk is only carried on to

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: distract ourselves and others. Tell me, where are those créches we hear

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: so much of? and where are those reading-rooms? People only write novels

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: about them; they don’t really exist. Only dirt, vulgarity, and Asiatic

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: plagues really exist.... I’m afraid, and I don’t at all like serious

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: faces; I don’t like serious conversations. Let’s be quiet sooner.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: You know, I get up at five every morning, I work from

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: morning till evening, I am always dealing with money--my own and other

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: people’s--and I see what people are like. You’ve only got to begin to

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: do anything to find out how few honest, honourable people there are.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Sometimes, when I can’t sleep, I think: “Oh Lord, you’ve given us huge

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: forests, infinite fields, and endless horizons, and we, living here,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: ought really to be giants.”

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You want giants, do you?... They’re only good in stories, and

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: even there they frighten one. [EPIKHODOV enters at the back of the stage

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: playing his guitar. Thoughtfully:] Epikhodov’s there.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Thoughtfully] Epikhodov’s there.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: The sun’s set, ladies and gentlemen.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: GAEV [Not loudly, as if declaiming] O Nature, thou art wonderful, thou

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: shinest with eternal radiance! Oh, beautiful and indifferent one, thou

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: whom we call mother, thou containest in thyself existence and death,

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: thou livest and destroyest....

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Entreatingly] Uncle, dear!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Uncle, you’re doing it again!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: You’d better double the red into the middle.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I’ll be quiet, I’ll be quiet.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: heard. Suddenly a distant sound is heard as if from the sky, the sound

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: of a breaking string, which dies away sadly.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: What’s that?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I don’t know. It may be a bucket fallen down a well somewhere.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: But it’s some way off.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Or perhaps it’s some bird... like a heron.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Or an owl.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Shudders] It’s unpleasant, somehow. [A pause.]

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: Before the misfortune the same thing happened. An owl screamed

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: and the samovar hummed without stopping.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Before what misfortune?

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: Before the Emancipation. [A pause.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You know, my friends, let’s go in; it’s evening now. [To ANYA]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: You’ve tears in your eyes.... What is it, little girl? [Embraces her.]

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: It’s nothing, mother.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Some one’s coming.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: drunk.]

SPEAKER: TRAMP
TEXT: Excuse me, may I go this way straight through to the station?

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: You may. Go along this path.

SPEAKER: TRAMP
TEXT: I thank you from the bottom of my heart. [Hiccups] Lovely

SPEAKER: TRAMP
TEXT: weather.... [Declaims] My brother, my suffering brother.... Come out on

SPEAKER: TRAMP
TEXT: the Volga, you whose groans... [To VARYA] Mademoiselle, please give a

SPEAKER: TRAMP
TEXT: hungry Russian thirty copecks....

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Angrily] There’s manners everybody’s got to keep!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [With a start] Take this... here you are.... [Feels in her purse]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: There’s no silver.... It doesn’t matter, here’s gold.

SPEAKER: TRAMP
TEXT: I am deeply grateful to you! [Exit. Laughter.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Frightened] I’m going, I’m going.... Oh, little mother, at home

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: there’s nothing for the servants to eat, and you gave him gold.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: What is to be done with such a fool as I am! At home I’ll give

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: you everything I’ve got. Ermolai Alexeyevitch, lend me some more!...

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Very well.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Let’s go, it’s time. And Varya, we’ve settled your affair; I

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: congratulate you.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Crying] You shouldn’t joke about this, mother.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Oh, feel me, get thee to a nunnery.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: My hands are all trembling; I haven’t played billiards for a long

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: time.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Oh, feel me, nymph, remember me in thine orisons.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Come along; it’ll soon be supper-time.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: He did frighten me. My heart is beating hard.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Let me remind you, ladies and gentlemen, on August 22 the

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: cherry orchard will be sold. Think of that!... Think of that!...

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Laughs] Thanks to the tramp who frightened Barbara, we’re alone

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: now.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Varya’s afraid we may fall in love with each other and won’t

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: get away from us for days on end. Her narrow mind won’t allow her to

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: understand that we are above love. To escape all the petty and deceptive

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: things which prevent our being happy and free, that is the aim and

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: meaning of our lives. Forward! We go irresistibly on to that bright star

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: which burns there, in the distance! Don’t lag behind, friends!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Clapping her hands] How beautifully you talk! [Pause] It is

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: glorious here to-day!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yes, the weather is wonderful.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: What have you done to me, Peter? I don’t love the cherry orchard

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: as I used to. I loved it so tenderly, I thought there was no better

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: place in the world than our orchard.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: All Russia is our orchard. The land is great and beautiful,

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: there are many marvellous places in it. [Pause] Think, Anya, your

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: grandfather, your great-grandfather, and all your ancestors were

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: serf-owners, they owned living souls; and now, doesn’t something human

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: look at you from every cherry in the orchard, every leaf and every

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: stalk? Don’t you hear voices...? Oh, it’s awful, your orchard is

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: terrible; and when in the evening or at night you walk through the

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: orchard, then the old bark on the trees sheds a dim light and the old

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: cherry-trees seem to be dreaming of all that was a hundred, two hundred

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: years ago, and are oppressed by their heavy visions. Still, at any

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: rate, we’ve left those two hundred years behind us. So far we’ve gained

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: nothing at all--we don’t yet know what the past is to be to us--we only

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: philosophize, we complain that we are dull, or we drink vodka. For it’s

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: so clear that in order to begin to live in the present we must first

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: redeem the past, and that can only be done by suffering, by strenuous,

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: uninterrupted labour. Understand that, Anya.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: The house in which we live has long ceased to be our house; I

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: shall go away. I give you my word.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: If you have the housekeeping keys, throw them down the well

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: and go away. Be as free as the wind.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Enthusiastically] How nicely you said that!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Believe me, Anya, believe me! I’m not thirty yet, I’m young,

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: I’m still a student, but I have undergone a great deal! I’m as hungry

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: as the winter, I’m ill, I’m shaken. I’m as poor as a beggar, and where

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: haven’t I been--fate has tossed me everywhere! But my soul is always my

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: own; every minute of the day and the night it is filled with unspeakable

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: presentiments. I know that happiness is coming, Anya, I see it

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: already....

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Thoughtful] The moon is rising.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: rises. Somewhere by the poplars VARYA is looking for ANYA and calling,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: “Anya, where are you?”]

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yes, the moon has risen. [Pause] There is happiness, there it

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: comes; it comes nearer and nearer; I hear its steps already. And if we

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: do not see it we shall not know it, but what does that matter? Others

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: will see it!

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: Anya! Where are you?

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: That’s Varya again! [Angry] Disgraceful!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Never mind. Let’s go to the river. It’s nice there.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: TROFIMOV Let’s go. [They go out.]

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: Anya! Anya!

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: ACT THREE

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: lighted. A Jewish band, the one mentioned in Act II, is heard playing

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: in another room. Evening. In the drawing-room the grand rond is being

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: danced. Voice of SIMEONOV PISCHIN “Promenade a une paire!” Dancers

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: come into the reception-room; the first pair are PISCHIN and CHARLOTTA

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: IVANOVNA; the second, TROFIMOV and LUBOV ANDREYEVNA; the third, ANYA and

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: the POST OFFICE CLERK; the fourth, VARYA and the STATION-MASTER, and

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: so on. VARYA is crying gently and wipes away her tears as she dances.

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: DUNYASHA is in the last pair. They go off into the drawing-room,

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: PISCHIN shouting, “Grand rond, balancez:” and “Les cavaliers à genou

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: et remerciez vos dames!” FIERS, in a dress-coat, carries a tray with

SPEAKER: THE VOICE OF VARYA
TEXT: seltzer-water across. Enter PISCHIN and TROFIMOV from the drawing-room.]

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I’m full-blooded and have already had two strokes; it’s hard

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: for me to dance, but, as they say, if you’re in Rome, you must do as

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Rome does. I’ve got the strength of a horse. My dead father, who liked

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: a joke, peace to his bones, used to say, talking of our ancestors,

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: that the ancient stock of the Simeonov-Pischins was descended from that

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: identical horse that Caligula made a senator.... [Sits] But the trouble

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: is, I’ve no money! A hungry dog only believes in meat. [Snores and wakes

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: up again immediately] So I... only believe in money....

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yes. There is something equine about your figure.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Well... a horse is a fine animal... you can sell a horse.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: arch.]

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: [Teasing] Madame Lopakhin! Madame Lopakhin!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Angry] Decayed gentleman!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yes, I am a decayed gentleman, and I’m proud of it!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Bitterly] We’ve hired the musicians, but how are they to be

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: paid? [Exit.]

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: [To PISCHIN] If the energy which you, in the course of your

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: life, have spent in looking for money to pay interest had been used

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: for something else, then, I believe, after all, you’d be able to turn

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: everything upside down.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Nietzsche... a philosopher... a very great, a most celebrated

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: man... a man of enormous brain, says in his books that you can forge

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: bank-notes.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: And have you read Nietzsche?

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Well... Dashenka told me. Now I’m in such a position, I

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: wouldn’t mind forging them... I’ve got to pay 310 roubles the day after

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: to-morrow... I’ve got 130 already.... [Feels his pockets, nervously]

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I’ve lost the money! The money’s gone! [Crying] Where’s the money?

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Humming a Caucasian dance] Why is Leonid away so long? What’s he

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: doing in town? [To DUNYASHA] Dunyasha, give the musicians some tea.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Business is off, I suppose.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: And the musicians needn’t have come, and we needn’t have got up

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: this ball.... Well, never mind.... [Sits and sings softly.]

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: [Gives a pack of cards to PISCHIN] Here’s a pack of cards,

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: think of any one card you like.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I’ve thought of one.

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: Now shuffle. All right, now. Give them here, oh my dear

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: Mr. Pischin. _Ein, zwei, drei_! Now look and you’ll find it in your

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: coat-tail pocket.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Takes a card out of his coat-tail pocket] Eight of spades,

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: quite right! [Surprised] Think of that now!
