SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: the most beautiful thing in the world! I’ve bought the estate where my

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: grandfather and my father were slaves, where they weren’t even allowed

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: into the kitchen. I’m asleep, it’s only a dream, an illusion.... It’s

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: the fruit of imagination, wrapped in the fog of the unknown.... [Picks

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: up the keys, nicely smiling] She threw down the keys, she wanted to show

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: she was no longer mistress here.... [Jingles keys] Well, it’s all one!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: and look at Ermolai Lopakhin laying his axe to the cherry orchard,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: come and look at the trees falling! We’ll build villas here, and our

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: grandsons and great-grandsons will see a new life here.... Play on,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: music! [The band plays. LUBOV ANDREYEVNA sinks into a chair and weeps

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: bitterly. LOPAKHIN continues reproachfully] Why then, why didn’t you

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: take my advice? My poor, dear woman, you can’t go back now. [Weeps] Oh,

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: if only the whole thing was done with, if only our uneven, unhappy life

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: were changed!

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Takes his arm; in an undertone] She’s crying. Let’s go into

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: the drawing-room and leave her by herself... come on.... [Takes his arm

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: and leads him out.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: What’s that? Bandsmen, play nicely! Go on, do just as I want

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: you to! [Ironically] The new owner, the owner of the cherry orchard is

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: coming! [He accidentally knocks up against a little table and nearly

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: upsets the candelabra] I can pay for everything! [Exit with PISCHIN]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: ANDREYEVNA, who sits huddled up and weeping bitterly. The band plays

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: softly. ANYA and TROFIMOV come in quickly. ANYA goes up to her

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: mother and goes on her knees in front of her. TROFIMOV stands at the

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: drawing-room entrance.]

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Mother! mother, are you crying? My dear, kind, good mother, my

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: beautiful mother, I love you! Bless you! The cherry orchard is sold,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: we’ve got it no longer, it’s true, true, but don’t cry mother, you’ve

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: still got your life before you, you’ve still your beautiful pure soul...

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Come with me, come, dear, away from here, come! We’ll plant a new

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: garden, finer than this, and you’ll see it, and you’ll understand, and

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: deep joy, gentle joy will sink into your soul, like the evening sun, and

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: you’ll smile, mother! Come, dear, let’s go!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: ACT FOUR

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: pictures; only a few pieces of furniture are left; they are piled up in

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: a corner as if for sale. The emptiness is felt. By the door that

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: leads out of the house and at the back of the stage, portmanteaux and

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: travelling paraphernalia are piled up. The door on the left is open; the

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: voices of VARYA and ANYA can be heard through it. LOPAKHIN stands and

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: waits. YASHA holds a tray with little tumblers of champagne. Outside,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: EPIKHODOV is tying up a box. Voices are heard behind the stage. The

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: peasants have come to say good-bye. The voice of GAEV is heard: “Thank

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: you, brothers, thank you.”]

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: The common people have come to say good-bye. I am of the

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: opinion, Ermolai Alexeyevitch, that they’re good people, but they don’t

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: understand very much.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: but is pale, and her face trembles; she can hardly speak.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: You gave them your purse, Luba. You can’t go on like that, you

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: can’t!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I couldn’t help myself, I couldn’t! [They go out.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [In the doorway, calling after them] Please, I ask you most

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: humbly! Just a little glass to say good-bye. I didn’t remember to bring

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: any from town and I only found one bottle at the station. Please, do!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: knew--I wouldn’t have bought any. Well, I shan’t drink any either.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: any rate.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: To those departing! And good luck to those who stay behind!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Eight roubles a bottle. [Pause] It’s devilish cold here.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: There are no fires to-day, we’re going away. [Laughs]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: What’s the matter with you?

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: I’m just pleased.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: It’s October outside, but it’s as sunny and as quiet as if

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: it were summer. Good for building. [Looking at his watch and speaking

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: through the door] Ladies and gentlemen, please remember that it’s only

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: forty-seven minutes till the train goes! You must go off to the station

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: in twenty minutes. Hurry up.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: I think it’s time we went. The carriages are waiting. Where

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: the devil are my goloshes? They’re lost. [Through the door] Anya, I

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: can’t find my goloshes! I can’t!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I’ve got to go to Kharkov. I’m going in the same train as you.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I’m going to spend the whole winter in Kharkov. I’ve been hanging about

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: with you people, going rusty without work. I can’t live without working.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I must have something to do with my hands; they hang about as if they

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: weren’t mine at all.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: We’ll go away now and then you’ll start again on your useful

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: labours.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Have a glass.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: I won’t.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: So you’re off to Moscow now?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: TROFIMOV Yes. I’ll see them into town and to-morrow I’m off to Moscow.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Yes.... I expect the professors don’t lecture nowadays;

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: they’re waiting till you turn up!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: That’s not your business.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: How many years have you been going to the university?

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Think of something fresh. This is old and flat. [Looking for

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: his goloshes] You know, we may not meet each other again, so just let me

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: give you a word of advice on parting: “Don’t wave your hands about! Get

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: rid of that habit of waving them about. And then, building villas and

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: reckoning on their residents becoming freeholders in time--that’s the

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: same thing; it’s all a matter of waving your hands about.... Whether

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: I want to or not, you know, I like you. You’ve thin, delicate fingers,

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: like those of an artist, and you’ve a thin, delicate soul....”

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Embraces him] Good-bye, dear fellow. Thanks for all you’ve

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: said. If you want any, take some money from me for the journey.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Why should I? I don’t want it.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: But you’ve nothing!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yes, I have, thank you; I’ve got some for a translation. Here

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: it is in my pocket. [Nervously] But I can’t find my goloshes!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [From the other room] Take your rubbish away! [Throws a pair of

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: rubber goloshes on to the stage.]

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Why are you angry, Varya? Hm! These aren’t my goloshes!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: In the spring I sowed three thousand acres of poppies, and now

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: I’ve made forty thousand roubles net profit. And when my poppies were

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: in flower, what a picture it was! So I, as I was saying, made forty

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: thousand roubles, and I mean I’d like to lend you some, because I can

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: afford it. Why turn up your nose at it? I’m just a simple peasant....

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Your father was a peasant, mine was a chemist, and that means

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: absolutely nothing. [LOPAKHIN takes out his pocket-book] No, no....

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Even if you gave me twenty thousand I should refuse. I’m a free man. And

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: everything that all you people, rich and poor, value so highly and so

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: dearly hasn’t the least influence over me; it’s like a flock of down in

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: the wind. I can do without you, I can pass you by. I’m strong and proud.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Mankind goes on to the highest truths and to the highest happiness such

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: as is only possible on earth, and I go in the front ranks!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Will you get there?

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: I will. [Pause] I’ll get there and show others the way. [Axes

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: cutting the trees are heard in the distance.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Well, good-bye, old man. It’s time to go. Here we stand

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: pulling one another’s noses, but life goes its own way all the time.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: When I work for a long time, and I don’t get tired, then I think more

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: easily, and I think I get to understand why I exist. And there are so

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: many people in Russia, brother, who live for nothing at all. Still, work

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: goes on without that. Leonid Andreyevitch, they say, has accepted a post

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: in a bank; he will get sixty thousand roubles a year.... But he won’t

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: stand it; he’s very lazy.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [At the door] Mother asks if you will stop them cutting down the

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: orchard until she has gone away.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Yes, really, you ought to have enough tact not to do that.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: LOPAKHIN, All right, all right... yes, he’s right. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Has Fiers been sent to the hospital?

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: I gave the order this morning. I suppose they’ve sent him.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [To EPIKHODOV, who crosses the room] Simeon Panteleyevitch, please

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: make inquiries if Fiers has been sent to the hospital.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Offended] I told Egor this morning. What’s the use of asking ten

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: times!

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: The aged Fiers, in my conclusive opinion, isn’t worth

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: mending; his forefathers had better have him. I only envy him. [Puts

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: a trunk on a hat-box and squashes it] Well, of course. I thought so!

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Grinning] Two-and-twenty troubles.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Behind the door] Has Fiers been taken away to the hospital?

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Why didn’t they take the letter to the doctor?

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: It’ll have to be sent after him. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [In the next room] Where’s Yasha? Tell him his mother’s come and

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: wants to say good-bye to him.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Waving his hand] She’ll make me lose all patience!

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: is left alone, she goes up to him.]

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: If you only looked at me once, Yasha. You’re going away,

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: leaving me behind.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: What’s the use of crying? [Drinks champagne] In six days I’ll be

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: again in Paris. To-morrow we get into the express and off we go. I can

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: hardly believe it. Vive la France! It doesn’t suit me here, I can’t live

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: here... it’s no good. Well, I’ve seen the uncivilized world; I have had

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: enough of it. [Drinks champagne] What do you want to cry for? You behave

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: yourself properly, and then you won’t cry.

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: [Looks in a small mirror and powders her face] Send me a

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: letter from Paris. You know I loved you, Yasha, so much! I’m a sensitive

SPEAKER: DUNYASHA
TEXT: creature, Yasha.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: Somebody’s coming.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: GAEV, ANYA, and CHARLOTTA IVANOVNA.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: We’d better be off. There’s no time left. [Looks at YASHA]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Somebody smells of herring!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: We needn’t get into our carriages for ten minutes.... [Looks

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: round the room] Good-bye, dear house, old grandfather. The winter will

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: go, the spring will come, and then you’ll exist no more, you’ll be

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: pulled down. How much these walls have seen! [Passionately kisses her

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: daughter] My treasure, you’re radiant, your eyes flash like two jewels!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Are you happy? Very?

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Very! A new life is beginning, mother!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Gaily] Yes, really, everything’s all right now. Before the cherry

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: orchard was sold we all were excited and we suffered, and then, when

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: the question was solved once and for all, we all calmed down, and even

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: became cheerful. I’m a bank official now, and a financier... red in the

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: middle; and you, Luba, for some reason or other, look better, there’s no

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: doubt about it.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: LUBOV Yes. My nerves are better, it’s true. [She puts on her coat and

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: hat] I sleep well. Take my luggage out, Yasha. It’s time. [To ANYA] My

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: little girl, we’ll soon see each other again.... I’m off to Paris. I’ll

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: live there on the money your grandmother from Yaroslav sent along to buy

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: the estate--bless her!--though it won’t last long.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: You’ll come back soon, soon, mother, won’t you? I’ll get ready,

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: and pass the exam at the Higher School, and then I’ll work and help

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: you. We’ll read all sorts of books to one another, won’t we? [Kisses

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: her mother’s hands] We’ll read in the autumn evenings; we’ll read

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: many books, and a beautiful new world will open up before us....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I’ll come, my darling. [Embraces her.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Charlotta is happy; she sings!

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: [Takes a bundle, looking like a wrapped-up baby] My little

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: baby, bye-bye. [The baby seems to answer, “Oua! Oua!”] Hush, my nice

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: little boy. [“Oua! Oua!”] I’m so sorry for you! [Throws the bundle back]

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: So please find me a new place. I can’t go on like this.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: We’ll find one, Charlotta Ivanovna, don’t you be afraid.

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Everybody’s leaving us. Varya’s going away... we’ve suddenly

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: become unnecessary.

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: I’ve nowhere to live in town. I must go away. [Hums] Never

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA
TEXT: mind.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Nature’s marvel!

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Puffing] Oh, let me get my breath back.... I’m fagged out...

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: My most honoured, give me some water....

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: Come for money, what? I’m your humble servant, and I’m going out

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: of the way of temptation. [Exit.]

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I haven’t been here for ever so long... dear madam. [To

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: LOPAKHIN] You here? Glad to see you... man of immense brain... take

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: this... take it.... [Gives LOPAKHIN money] Four hundred roubles.... That

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: leaves 840....

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Shrugs his shoulders in surprise] As if I were dreaming.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Where did you get this from?

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Stop... it’s hot.... A most unexpected thing happened. Some

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Englishmen came along and found some white clay on my land.... [To LUBOV

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: ANDREYEVNA] And here’s four hundred for you... beautiful lady.... [Gives

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: her money] Give you the rest later.... [Drinks water] Just now a young

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: man in the train was saying that some great philosopher advises us all

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: to jump off roofs. “Jump!” he says, and that’s all. [Astonished] To

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: think of that, now! More water!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Who were these Englishmen?

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: I’ve leased off the land with the clay to them for twenty-four

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: years.... Now, excuse me, I’ve no time.... I must run off.... I must

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: go to Znoikov and to Kardamonov... I owe them all money.... [Drinks]

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Good-bye. I’ll come in on Thursday.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: We’re just off to town, and to-morrow I go abroad.

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: [Agitated] What? Why to town? I see furniture... trunks....

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Well, never mind. [Crying] Never mind. These Englishmen are men of

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: immense intellect.... Never mind.... Be happy.... God will help you....

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: Never mind.... Everything in this world comes to an end.... [Kisses

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: LUBOV ANDREYEVNA’S hand] And if you should happen to hear that my end

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: has come, just remember this old... horse and say: “There was one

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: such and such a Simeonov-Pischin, God bless his soul....” Wonderful

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: weather... yes.... [Exit deeply moved, but returns at once and says in

SPEAKER: PISCHIN
TEXT: the door] Dashenka sent her love! [Exit.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Now we can go. I’ve two anxieties, though. The first is poor

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Fiers [Looks at her watch] We’ve still five minutes....

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Mother, Fiers has already been sent to the hospital. Yasha sent

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: him off this morning.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: The second is Varya. She’s used to getting up early and to work,

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: and now she’s no work to do she’s like a fish out of water. She’s grown

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: thin and pale, and she cries, poor thing.... [Pause] You know very well,

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Ermolai Alexeyevitch, that I used to hope to marry her to you, and I

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: suppose you are going to marry somebody? [Whispers to ANYA, who nods to

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: CHARLOTTA, and they both go out] She loves you, she’s your sort, and I

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: don’t understand, I really don’t, why you seem to be keeping away from

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: each other. I don’t understand!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: To tell the truth, I don’t understand it myself. It’s all so

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: strange.... If there’s still time, I’ll be ready at once... Let’s get it

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: over, once and for all; I don’t feel as if I could ever propose to her

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: without you.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Excellent. It’ll only take a minute. I’ll call her.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: The champagne’s very appropriate. [Looking at the tumblers]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: They’re empty, somebody’s already drunk them. [YASHA coughs] I call that

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: licking it up....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [Animated] Excellent. We’ll go out. Yasha, allez. I’ll call her

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: in.... [At the door] Varya, leave that and come here. Come! [Exit with

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [Looks at his watch] Yes.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: comes in.]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Looking at the luggage in silence] I can’t seem to find it....

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: What are you looking for?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I packed it myself and I don’t remember. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Where are you going to now, Barbara Mihailovna?

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I? To the Ragulins.... I’ve got an agreement to go and look after

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: their house... as housekeeper or something.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Is that at Yashnevo? It’s about fifty miles. [Pause] So life

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: in this house is finished now....

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Looking at the luggage] Where is it?... perhaps I’ve put it away

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: in the trunk.... Yes, there’ll be no more life in this house....

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: And I’m off to Kharkov at once... by this train. I’ve a lot of

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: business on hand. I’m leaving Epikhodov here... I’ve taken him on.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Well, well!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Last year at this time the snow was already falling, if you

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: remember, and now it’s nice and sunny. Only it’s rather cold.... There’s

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: three degrees of frost.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: I didn’t look. [Pause] And our thermometer’s broken.... [Pause.]

SPEAKER: VOICE AT THE DOOR
TEXT: Ermolai Alexeyevitch!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: [As if he has long been waiting to be called] This minute.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: weeps gently. The door opens. LUBOV ANDREYEVNA enters carefully.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Well? [Pause] We must go.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Not crying now, wipes her eyes] Yes, it’s quite time, little

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: mother. I’ll get to the Ragulins to-day, if I don’t miss the train....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: [At the door] Anya, put on your things. [Enter ANYA, then GAEV,

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA IVANOVNA
TEXT: GAEV wears a warm overcoat with a cape. A servant

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA IVANOVNA
TEXT: and drivers come in. EPIKHODOV bustles around the luggage] Now we can go

SPEAKER: CHARLOTTA IVANOVNA
TEXT: away.

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Joyfully] Away!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: My friends, my dear friends! Can I be silent, in leaving this

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: house for evermore?--can I restrain myself, in saying farewell, from

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: expressing those feelings which now fill my whole being...?

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: [Imploringly] Uncle!

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Uncle, you shouldn’t!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Stupidly] Double the red into the middle.... I’ll be quiet.

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Well, it’s time to be off.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Epikhodov, my coat!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: I’ll sit here one more minute. It’s as if I’d never really

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: noticed what the walls and ceilings of this house were like, and now I

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: look at them greedily, with such tender love....

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: I remember, when I was six years old, on Trinity Sunday, I sat at

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: this window and looked and saw my father going to church....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Have all the things been taken away?

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Yes, all, I think. [To EPIKHODOV, putting on his coat] You see

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: that everything’s quite straight, Epikhodov.

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: [Hoarsely] You may depend upon me, Ermolai Alexeyevitch!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: What’s the matter with your voice?

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: I swallowed something just now; I was having a drink of

SPEAKER: EPIKHODOV
TEXT: water.

SPEAKER: YASHA
TEXT: [Suspiciously] What manners....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: We go away, and not a soul remains behind.

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Till the spring.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: [Drags an umbrella out of a bundle, and seems to be waving it

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: about. LOPAKHIN appears to be frightened] What are you doing?... I never

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: thought...

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Come along, let’s take our seats... it’s time! The train will

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: be in directly.

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: Peter, here they are, your goloshes, by that trunk. [In tears]

SPEAKER: VARYA
TEXT: And how old and dirty they are....

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: [Putting them on] Come on!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [Deeply moved, nearly crying] The train... the station.... Cross

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: in the middle, a white double in the corner....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: Let’s go!

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Are you all here? There’s nobody else? [Locks the side-door on

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: the left] There’s a lot of things in there. I must lock them up. Come!

SPEAKER: ANYA
TEXT: Good-bye, home! Good-bye, old life!

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: Welcome, new life! [Exit with ANYA.]

SPEAKER: TROFIMOV
TEXT: with her little dog, go out.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: Till the spring, then! Come on... till we meet again! [Exit.]

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: waiting for that. They fall into each other’s arms and sob restrainedly

SPEAKER: LOPAKHIN
TEXT: and quietly, fearing that somebody might hear them.]

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: [In despair] My sister, my sister....

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: My dear, my gentle, beautiful orchard! My life, my youth, my

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: happiness, good-bye! Good-bye!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: ANYA’S VOICE. [Gaily] Mother!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: TROFIMOV’S VOICE. [Gaily, excited] Coo-ee!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: To look at the walls and the windows for the last time.... My

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: dead mother used to like to walk about this room....

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: My sister, my sister!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: ANYA’S VOICE. Mother!

SPEAKER: GAEV
TEXT: TROFIMOV’S VOICE. Coo-ee!

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: We’re coming! [They go out.]

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: heard, and then the noise of the carriages going away. It is quiet. Then

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: the sound of an axe against the trees is heard in the silence sadly and

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: by itself. Steps are heard. FIERS comes in from the door on the right.

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: He is dressed as usual, in a short jacket and white waistcoat; slippers

SPEAKER: LUBOV
TEXT: on his feet. He is ill. He goes to the door and tries the handle.]

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: It’s locked. They’ve gone away. [Sits on a sofa] They’ve

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: forgotten about me.... Never mind, I’ll sit here.... And Leonid

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: Andreyevitch will have gone in a light overcoat instead of putting on

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: his fur coat.... [Sighs anxiously] I didn’t see.... Oh, these young

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: people! [Mumbles something that cannot be understood] Life’s gone on as

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: if I’d never lived. [Lying down] I’ll lie down.... You’ve no strength

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: left in you, nothing left at all.... Oh, you... bungler!

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: of a breaking string, dying away sadly. Silence follows it, and only the

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: sound is heard, some way away in the orchard, of the axe falling on the

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: trees.]

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: Curtain.

SPEAKER: FIERS
TEXT: End of Project Gutenberg’s Plays by Chekhov, Second Series, by Anton Chekhov
